Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *this*.

It wasn't one single thing. It was a lot of things, swirling around in my head, making me feel like I was drowning.

First, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want to do with my life, let alone being responsible for another human being. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not financially stable, I'm still in school, and I just… I'm not equipped to give a baby the life it deserves.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about *wanting* the baby to have the best possible life. A life with parents who are ready and able to provide for it, emotionally and financially. A life with stability and opportunity.

I thought about what my mom would do, and honestly? She'd probably run away and leave me to deal with it. And that's not what I wanted. I wanted something better for the baby.

Then there was Mark and Vanessa. They were… perfect. They were kind, and loving, and they had a beautiful home. They were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. And when I met them, I just knew that they would be amazing parents.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever had to make. I cried a lot. I second-guessed myself a million times. But ultimately, I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby *up*. Giving it a chance at a life I couldn't provide. It was about putting the baby's needs before my own.

And honestly, it was about being honest with myself. I'm not a mom. Not yet, anyway. And I need to focus on my own future, on becoming the person I want to be.

So yeah. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't a selfish decision. It was a selfless one. And it was the hardest, bravest thing I've ever done. And I still think about the baby, you know? All the time. But I know, deep down, that it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved.

Ugh, okay. Now you're just trying to make me cry. But fine. I'll bite.

Love… I always thought love was this big, dramatic thing. Like in the movies. All grand gestures and sweeping declarations. Turns out, it's a lot more subtle than that. It's in the small things. Like Bren making me pancakes when I'm feeling down. Or my dad trying to understand me, even when he doesn't get it. Or Mark and Vanessa genuinely wanting the best for the baby.

I learned that love isn't always about *having* something. Sometimes, it's about *giving* something up. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. And that's… really hard. But it's also really beautiful.

And responsibility… oh boy. I thought responsibility was just doing your homework and cleaning your room. Turns out, it's a whole lot more complicated than that. It's about owning your choices, even the bad ones. It's about facing the consequences of your actions. It's about being accountable for your own life.

I learned that responsibility isn't something that's imposed on you. It's something you choose. You choose to be a good person. You choose to do the right thing. Even when it's difficult.

This whole experience forced me to grow up really fast. I had to learn to be responsible for my own actions, and for the life growing inside me. And I had to learn to love unconditionally, even when it meant letting go.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But it taught me a lot about myself, and about the world. It taught me that love and responsibility aren't just abstract concepts. They're real things. And they're worth fighting for.

And honestly? I think I'm a better person because of it. A little bit bruised, a little bit battered, but definitely stronger. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit wiser. Don't tell anyone I said that, though. I have a reputation to maintain.

Oh, *that's* a good question. Finally, something I'm actually qualified to talk about. Seriously, if I didn't have my sarcasm, I'd probably have dissolved into a puddle of teenage angst a long time ago.

It's like… a shield, you know? When things are awful, and you feel like you're drowning in emotions, cracking a joke is a way to create some distance. It's like saying, "Okay, this is terrible, but I can still find something to laugh about." It doesn't make the problem go away, but it makes it feel… less overwhelming.

And it's a way to control the narrative, I guess. When people are staring at you, or whispering behind your back, you can either crumble under the pressure, or you can make a joke and take the power back. It's like saying, "Yeah, I know this is weird. But I'm going to own it."

Plus, it's just… fun. I genuinely enjoy making people laugh. It's a good feeling. And sometimes, making someone else laugh is the best way to cheer yourself up.

Bren always says my humor is a defense mechanism. And she's probably right. But it's a defense mechanism that works. It's a way to protect myself from getting hurt, and a way to connect with other people.

It wasn't always appropriate, of course. There were times when I probably should have been more serious. But honestly, I don't think I could have gotten through this without my sense of humor. It's a part of who I am. It's how I cope. It's how I survive.

So yeah. Sarcasm. It's my superpower. Don't underestimate the power of a well-timed quip. It can save your life. Or at least, make it a little bit more bearable.

Ugh, okay, now we're getting *really* personal. You're basically asking me to spill my guts. Fine. But don't expect a neatly packaged, inspirational story. It's messy. Like me.

Before… everything… I thought I had it all figured out. I was sarcastic, independent, a little bit cynical. I had my music, my vintage clothes, my best friend Leah. I thought that was enough. I thought that *was* me.

But then I got pregnant, and suddenly everything changed. My carefully constructed facade crumbled. I was terrified, confused, and completely overwhelmed. I realized I didn't know who I was anymore. I wasn't just Juno MacGuff, the quirky teenager. I was Juno MacGuff, the pregnant teenager. And that felt… wrong.

I spent a lot of time trying to hide my vulnerability. I put up walls, I made sarcastic jokes, I tried to pretend I wasn't scared. But it didn't work. The fear and sadness were still there, lurking beneath the surface.

It was Bren who helped me to see that vulnerability wasn't a weakness. It was a strength. She encouraged me to be honest about my feelings, to ask for help, to let people see the real me.

And as I started to let go of my defenses, I started to discover who I really was. I realized that I was stronger than I thought. I realized that I was capable of making difficult decisions. I realized that I was worthy of love and support.

The search for identity wasn't about finding a fixed, unchanging self. It was about embracing the messiness and complexity of being human. It was about accepting that I was a work in progress.

Giving the baby up for adoption wasn't about giving up on my dreams. It was about choosing a path that was right for me, and for the baby. It was about recognizing my limitations and making a selfless decision.

So, yeah. My vulnerability and search for identity shaped my journey in a profound way. They forced me to confront my fears, to challenge my assumptions, and to grow as a person. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it. I'm still figuring things out, but I'm a little bit closer to understanding who I am. And that's all I can ask for.

And honestly? It's kinda cool to be a work in progress. It means there's always room for growth. And that's something to be excited about. Even if it's a little bit scary.

Okay, this is… important. I can actually talk about this without getting all choked up. Mostly.

Honestly? I wouldn't have gotten through any of this without the people around me. I thought I was strong, you know? Independent. Capable of handling things on my own. And I *am* those things, to a certain extent. But this was… different. This was bigger than me.

My dad, Mac, he was… quiet. He wasn't really sure what to say or do at first. But he was *there*. He just… showed up. He made me breakfast, he drove me to appointments, he just let me know that he loved me, no matter what. And that meant the world.

Leah… things were complicated with Leah. She was hurt and confused, and she needed space. But even when we weren't talking, I knew she was thinking about me. And when we finally did talk, she was surprisingly supportive. She didn't judge me, she just listened.

But Bren… Bren was everything. She was my rock. She didn't try to fix things, she didn't try to tell me what to do. She just listened, and she asked questions, and she helped me to explore my options. She made me feel safe enough to be honest about my feelings, even the scary ones.

She helped me to see that I had choices. That I wasn't trapped. That I could make a decision that was right for me, and for the baby. She helped me to understand that giving the baby up for adoption wasn't a failure, it was an act of love.

And Mark and Vanessa… they were so kind and understanding. They made me feel like I was making a good decision. They reassured me that the baby would be loved and cared for.

Their support wasn't about fixing my problem. It was about empowering me to make my own decision. It was about reminding me that I wasn't alone. It was about giving me the strength to face the future, even when it felt scary and uncertain.

I think that's what true support looks like. It's not about having all the answers. It's about being there for someone, no matter what. And I'm incredibly grateful for the people who were there for me. They helped me to find my strength, and they helped me to make the best decision I could. And I don't know where I'd be without them. Seriously.

Ugh. Okay. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't like in the movies, you know? No dramatic music, no slow-motion crying. It was just… a test. Two pink lines. And then a whole lot of panic.

Honestly? My first thought was, "This is a disaster." A complete and utter disaster. My life was already… complicated enough. I was just starting to figure things out, and then *this* happened.

I felt… numb, at first. Like I was watching everything happen to someone else. Then the numbness wore off, and the fear set in. I was terrified. Terrified of telling my dad, terrified of what my friends would think, terrified of what my future would look like.

I remember sitting on the bathroom floor, staring at the test, and just… crying. Not sobbing, just quiet tears. I felt so overwhelmed, so lost, so completely unprepared.

And then I felt… angry. Angry at myself, angry at Paul (you don't need to know about him, he's not important), angry at the universe for throwing this at me. It just didn't seem fair.

It took a while for me to process everything. It took a lot of talking, a lot of crying, and a lot of soul-searching. And it wasn't easy. It still isn't easy.

But eventually, I realized that I had a choice. I could let this destroy my life, or I could try to make the best of it. And I decided to try to make the best of it.

It wasn't the life I imagined for myself, but it was my life. And I was going to face it head-on, with as much courage and honesty as I could muster.

So yeah. That's how I felt. Scared, angry, overwhelmed, and completely unprepared. But also… determined. Determined to figure things out, and to make the right decision. Even if it was the hardest decision of my life.

Ugh. Okay, brace yourself. This is… a messy topic. It wasn't pretty.

With my dad, Mac, it was… awkward at first. He was definitely shocked. He's not the most emotionally expressive guy, so he didn't say a lot. But he was supportive, in his own way. He just… started doing things. Like, making sure I had everything I needed, driving me to appointments, being there when I needed him. It wasn't a lot of talking, but it was a lot of *doing*. And I appreciated that.

Bren, my stepmom, was amazing. I already told you that. She was my rock. She didn't judge me, she just listened and offered support. She helped me navigate the whole situation, and she made me feel like I wasn't alone. I honestly don't know what I would have done without her.

But with Leah… that was the hardest part. Leah and I were inseparable. We told each other everything. Or, we *used* to. When I told her I was pregnant, she just… shut down. She was angry. She said I was being irresponsible and selfish. She said I was ruining my life.

It was awful. We had a huge fight, and we didn't talk for weeks. Eventually, we started talking again, but things were never the same. She was distant and withdrawn. She didn't understand why I was choosing adoption. She thought I should have kept the baby.

It was really painful. Losing Leah felt like losing a part of myself. We'd been through so much together, and I thought our friendship could withstand anything. But it couldn't.

I think she was scared. Scared of what my pregnancy meant for our future. Scared of losing me. But she didn't know how to express those feelings in a healthy way.

It's still hard to talk about. I miss her. But I also know that I made the right decision for myself. And I hope that one day, Leah will understand that.

So yeah. My pregnancy definitely had a big impact on my relationships. It strengthened some bonds, and it broke others. It was a painful lesson in the complexities of friendship and family. And it taught me that sometimes, even the people you love the most can disappoint you. It just… sucks.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. It wasn't pretty, let me tell you. It wasn't like in the movies, where everything magically works out and everyone learns a valuable lesson. It was messy and confusing and really, really hard.

At first, I just… shut down. I pretended it wasn't happening. I kept going to school, hanging out with my friends (well, Leah, before things got weird), and trying to act normal. But inside, I was a total wreck. I was scared, and confused, and angry. And I didn't know what to do.

Then, I started talking to Bren. She was the first person I really opened up to. And she didn't judge me. She just listened. And she asked me questions. And she helped me to sort through my feelings.

I also started writing in a journal. It was a way to get my thoughts and feelings out of my head and onto paper. It was like talking to a friend, but without having to worry about what they thought of me.

And I listened to a lot of music. Sad music, angry music, hopeful music. Music helped me to process my emotions and to feel less alone.

But honestly, the hardest part was dealing with the guilt. I felt guilty about getting pregnant, about not being able to raise the baby, about letting everyone down. It was a really heavy burden to carry.

Bren helped me with that too. She reminded me that I wasn't to blame. That it was a mistake, but it wasn't the end of the world. And she helped me to focus on making the best decision for everyone involved.

It wasn't easy. There were a lot of tears, and a lot of sleepless nights. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. Even if it's just a tiny little flicker. You just have to hold onto it. And maybe eat a cookie or two. Seriously, cookies are underrated.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. This is… a sensitive topic. And honestly, it's not something I like talking about. But you asked.

It wasn't about *choosing* an abortion, okay? It was about choosing… the least awful option. And Havenbrooke… Havenbrooke just felt *wrong*.

It was all so… sterile. And judgmental. The people there were protesting, holding signs, trying to guilt-trip you. It felt like they didn't care about *me*, they just cared about their own beliefs. It felt like they were trying to punish me for making a difficult decision.

Women Now, on the other hand… it felt different. It was calmer. More respectful. The people there were kind and supportive. They didn't try to tell me what to do, they just listened and offered information. They treated me like a person, not a problem.

And Paul, the guy who runs the clinic… he was just… real. He didn't sugarcoat anything, but he didn't judge me either. He just explained my options and let me make my own decision.

It wasn't about being pro-choice or pro-life. It was about finding a place where I felt safe and respected. A place where I felt like I could be honest about my feelings. A place where I felt like I was in control.

Havenbrooke felt like a prison. Women Now felt like a sanctuary.

It was a hard decision, and I still have mixed feelings about it. But I know I made the right choice. For me. And that's all that matters.

Can we… talk about something else now? Please? This is bringing up a lot of stuff. Maybe we can talk about vintage clothes? Or music? Anything but this.

It wasn't some grand romantic gesture, or a carefully planned decision. It was… stupid. Just plain, dumb, teenage stupidity.

Bleeker and I were… comfortable. We'd been friends for a while, and there was this… connection. A quiet understanding. He's a sweet guy, Bleeker. Really sweet. And I was feeling… vulnerable. My mom had just left again, and I was feeling really lost and alone.

We were at his house, listening to records, and we were talking. And then we weren't. It just… happened. It wasn't like a movie, all passionate and dramatic. It was awkward and clumsy and… quick.

Honestly, I think we both just wanted to feel *something*. To feel connected to someone. To feel less alone.

I didn't think about the consequences. I didn't think about birth control. I didn't think about anything except the moment. Which, in retrospect, was incredibly irresponsible.

I regret it, obviously. Not because I regret knowing Bleeker, he's a good person. But I regret being so careless. I regret not thinking things through.

It was a mistake. A big one. And it changed my life forever.

It's not a story I like to tell. It's embarrassing and painful. But it's the truth. And I guess that's what you wanted to know.

I don't know. It's complicated. He's not the kind of guy I ever thought I'd be into. He's not cool, or popular, or anything like that. But he's… good. He's a good person. And he makes me laugh.

So, yeah. I like Bleeker. A lot. Don't tell him I said that, though. He'd probably freak out. And honestly, so would I. It's just… easier to pretend I'm not completely smitten with a guitar-playing, perpetually awkward teenager. It's safer that way.

But… he's pretty great. Okay? There. I said it. Now leave me alone. I need to go listen to some music and pretend I'm not thinking about him.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone wants to know *why*. Like there's some simple answer, some easy explanation. There isn't. It was a lot of things.

First, and I know this sounds selfish, but I wasn't ready. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm not ready to be a mom. I can barely keep my room clean, let alone raise a human being. It wouldn't be fair to the baby.

Second, I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life with parents who were financially secure and emotionally prepared. I could give a baby love, sure, but I couldn't give it everything it needed. Mark and Vanessa can. They *want* to.

Third, I realized that being a mother isn't just about carrying a baby for nine months. It's about being there for that baby for the rest of its life. And I knew I couldn't do that. Not right now. Maybe not ever.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. I cried a lot. I second-guessed myself a million times. But ultimately, I knew it was the right thing to do.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby the best possible chance at a happy life. It was about being selfless, even when it hurt like hell.

And honestly? It was about admitting that I needed help. That I couldn't do this on my own. And that's okay. It's okay to ask for help. It's okay to admit that you're not perfect.

So yeah. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't a glamorous decision, or a heroic one. It was just… the right one. For everyone involved. And I'm trying to be okay with that. I'm trying to believe that I made the best decision I could, given the circumstances. And I'm hoping that the baby will be happy. That's all I want.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… not a good day. Actually, it was a spectacularly awful day.

Okay, so, Bleeker. Sweet, clueless Bleeker. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. Just… not exactly the sharpest tool in the shed. And definitely not prepared for a conversation about unplanned pregnancy.

I remember I was trying to be cool, you know? Like, "Hey, no big deal, I'm pregnant, let's grab a smoothie." But inside, I was a total mess. My hands were shaking, my voice was all wobbly, and I was pretty sure I was going to throw up right there in the hallway.

And he just… stared at me. Like I'd grown a second head. He didn't say anything for a *really* long time. It was the most awkward silence of my entire life.

Then he finally stammered out something about… needing to go to the bathroom. Which, okay, fair enough. But it wasn't exactly the reaction I was hoping for.

He kept apologizing, like *he* had done something wrong. And he kept saying things like, "Are you sure?" and "This is… a lot." Which, yeah, no kidding.

It wasn't that he was mean or anything. He was just… completely overwhelmed. He didn't know what to say, or what to do. And honestly, neither did I.

It was a really sad moment, because I realized that we were just too different. We were at different places in our lives. He was still figuring things out, and I was suddenly facing this huge responsibility.

It was the end of us, really. Not because I was pregnant, but because he couldn't handle it. And I needed someone who could.

It hurt, of course. But it also felt… inevitable. It was a relief, in a weird way, to know that we weren't meant to be.

So yeah. Telling Bleeker was awful. It was awkward, and heartbreaking, and just… a really bad experience. I still cringe when I think about it. But it was also a necessary step. It helped me to realize what I needed, and to move on with my life. And honestly, Bleeker is probably happier just sticking to guitar and being generally… Bleeker.

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? The question everyone's been tiptoeing around.

But… (she hesitates) …there's also a part of me that feels… something. A little flicker of excitement, maybe? A little bit of love? It's weird. It's like, even though I know this isn't the right time, even though I know I can't keep the baby, I still feel connected to it.

That's why this decision is so hard. It's not like I don't care about the baby. I do. I really do. But I know that I'm not ready to be a mom right now. And I want the baby to have a life that I can't give it.

So, yeah. It's terrifying. It's heartbreaking. It's complicated. It's everything. And it's something I'm going to have to live with for a long time. But I'm trying to focus on the fact that I'm making the best decision I can, for everyone involved. Even if it's the hardest decision I've ever had to make.

(She looks away, her voice barely a whisper.)

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, Bleeker. That's… complicated. It always was.

Honestly? I'm not entirely sure our relationship *has* a future, now. Before, it was this… awkward, sweet, kinda goofy thing. We bonded over music and Dungeons & Dragons and just generally being weirdos. It was comfortable. Safe.

But now… now there's a baby involved. And a whole lot of responsibility. And Bleeker… well, Bleeker is Bleeker. He's a good guy, don't get me wrong. He's sweet and kind and he tries really hard. But he's also… not exactly the most decisive person in the world.

He was supportive when I told him, which I appreciated. But it was mostly just a lot of stammering and wide-eyed staring. I think our relationship will probably shift from… whatever it was… to more of a friendship. A friendly co-parenting situation, maybe. If he wants that. I'm not going to force it.

I need someone who's strong and reliable, someone who can handle the pressure. And honestly, I'm not sure Bleeker is that person. Not yet, anyway. He's still figuring things out, just like I am.

It's sad, I guess. I liked him. But I need to focus on what's best for the baby, and for myself. And sometimes, that means letting go of things that aren't going to work. Even if they're sweet and goofy and involve a lot of shared musical tastes.

So yeah. I think our relationship will change. Probably for the worse, if I'm being honest. But maybe, just maybe, we can still be friends. If he can handle being around a pregnant teenager who's giving a baby up for adoption. It's a lot to ask, I know.

Ugh. Okay, this is the part I really hate talking about. It's… not fun. It's like being under a microscope, except everyone's pointing and whispering instead of taking notes.

Honestly? At first, I just tried to ignore it. I pretended it wasn't happening. I wore headphones and avoided eye contact and just tried to blend into the background. Which, let's be real, is hard to do when you're visibly pregnant.

But that didn't work. The whispers followed me everywhere. The stares burned into my back. And the rumors… oh, the rumors. People were saying all sorts of things. Things that weren't true. Things that were just… mean.

So then I tried being defensive. Sarcastic. I'd snap at people who asked questions, and I'd roll my eyes at the whispers. It felt good in the moment, but it just made things worse. It just made me look angry and hostile.

Then Bren talked to me. She said I couldn't control what other people thought or said, but I *could* control how I reacted to it. She said I needed to focus on my own well-being, and to surround myself with people who supported me.

So that's what I started to do. I started spending more time with Bren and my dad. I reconnected with a few of my friends who were actually supportive. And I started ignoring the haters.

It's not easy. It still stings when I hear someone whispering about me. It still hurts when someone judges me. But I'm learning to let it go. I'm learning to focus on the people who matter, and to ignore the rest.

I also remind myself that their judgment says more about *them* than it does about me. They're probably just insecure or judgmental people who are projecting their own issues onto me.

And honestly, sometimes I just want to scream. But I don't. I take a deep breath, and I remind myself that I'm strong. And I keep moving forward.

It's a work in progress, but I'm getting better at it. And I'm learning to be kinder to myself. Because everyone deserves a little bit of grace, especially when they're going through a tough time. And this? This is a *really* tough time.

Okay. This is… the big one, isn't it? It's not something I talk about easily. It still feels raw, even after all this time.

The adoption process itself… it's been a lot. A lot of paperwork, a lot of appointments, a lot of emotional conversations. It's been exhausting, and scary, and overwhelming. But it's also been… surprisingly empowering.

It's forced me to confront my feelings, to think about what I want for the future, and to make some really difficult decisions. And it's shown me that I'm stronger than I thought I was.

As for the choice I've made… it's complicated. There are days when I feel really confident and at peace with it. I know I'm doing what's best for the baby, and for myself. I know that Mark and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents.

But then there are other days when I feel… a lot of things. Sadness, guilt, fear. I worry about whether I'm making the right decision. I wonder what the baby's life will be like. I miss the baby already, and I haven't even met him or her yet.

It's not like I don't care. I care *a lot*. But I know that I'm not ready to be a mother right now. I'm still a kid myself. I have my own life to live, my own dreams to pursue. And I want the baby to have a life that's full of love and stability and opportunity.

I've spent a lot of time talking to Mark and Vanessa, and I feel really good about their intentions. They want an open adoption, which means I'll still be a part of the baby's life. I'll get updates, and maybe even visit. It's not the same as raising the baby myself, but it's something.

It's not a perfect solution. There's no such thing as a perfect solution. But it's the best solution I could come up with. And I'm trying to trust that it's the right one.

It's still hard, though. Really hard. But I'm learning to accept it, and to move forward. And I'm hoping that one day, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the best decision I could, under the circumstances. It's a lot to carry, but I'm trying. I really am.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big question. A really big question. It's like, before, I had this whole idea of who I was. I was Juno, the sarcastic, music-obsessed, vintage-loving teenager. I had my friends, my hobbies, my plans for the future. It wasn't a *perfect* life, but it was *my* life.

Ugh, where do I even begin? The adoption process wasn't exactly a walk in the park. It was more like… wading through a swamp filled with paperwork and emotional landmines.

Another challenge was **dealing with other people's opinions**. Some people were supportive, but others were judgmental. They didn't understand why I was choosing adoption, and they weren't afraid to tell me. It was really hurtful.

And then there was the **getting to know Mark and Vanessa**. It was weird, getting close to the people who were going to raise my baby. I wanted them to love him or her, but I also felt a little bit jealous. It was a really complicated mix of emotions.

But honestly, the hardest part was just **letting go**. Saying goodbye to the baby after he or she was born was the most difficult thing I've ever done. It felt like a piece of my heart was being ripped away.

It was a long and challenging process, but it was also a rewarding one. I knew I was doing something good, and that the baby would be loved and cared for. And that made it all worthwhile. But don't get me wrong, it still sucked. A lot.

I wrote: "Bleeker, you're a genuinely good egg. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. And please, for the love of all that is holy, learn to play the guitar. Seriously. - Juno."

I debated for *hours* about what to write. I wanted it to be funny, but also sincere. I didn't want to come on too strong, but I also didn't want to be dismissive. It was a lot of pressure for a yearbook message.

I ended up going with something simple and honest. He was a sweet guy, Bleeker. A little awkward, a little clueless, but genuinely kind. And he was the only one who didn't treat me like a freak after… well, you know.

I still wonder if he ever learned to play the guitar. Probably not. He was more of a drum guy, I think. But it was a nice thought.

And honestly, looking back, it was a pretty good message. It was me. Sarcastic, but also hopeful. And a little bit vulnerable. Which, let's be real, is basically my brand.

Don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *Her*. Okay, buckle up, because this is a saga.

Mrs. Bleeker… let's just say she's… discerning. And by discerning, I mean she thinks I'm a delinquent who's going to corrupt her precious son. She's got this whole "good girl" aesthetic going on, and I definitely don't fit the bill.

The first time I met her, she gave me this look like I'd just crawled out from under a rock. And she kept asking me about my "future plans," which, at the time, consisted mostly of listening to music and avoiding responsibility. Not exactly what she wanted to hear.

She's always subtly (and not-so-subtly) trying to steer Bleeker away from me. Like, suggesting he join the debate team or volunteer at the library. Anything to keep him occupied and away from my "negative influence."

She's also really into organic food and holistic medicine. She tried to give me a herbal tea once, claiming it would "balance my energies." I politely declined.

Honestly, I think she just doesn't understand me. She sees me as rebellious and irresponsible, but she doesn't see the things that matter to me – my creativity, my intelligence, my loyalty.

Bleeker tries to defend me, but he's kind of a pushover. He loves his mom, and he doesn't want to upset her. It's sweet, but also frustrating.

I've learned to just ignore her. It's easier that way. But sometimes, when she gives me that look, I just want to tell her to mind her own business. But I don't. Because that would just make things worse.

So yeah. Mrs. Bleeker and I? We're not exactly friends. It's more of a… tense truce. And I suspect it will remain that way for the foreseeable future. She's a piece of work, that woman. A *piece of work*.

(Takes a deep breath, fiddles with the hem of my shirt)

Ugh. Don't even *ask*. It's… looming. Like a really big, dark cloud. I've been putting it off for as long as humanly possible, but Bren says I can't avoid it forever. Which, surprise surprise, she's right about.

My dad… he's a good guy. He's just… not great with emotions. I'm worried he's going to be really disappointed. And angry. I can already picture the lecture. It'll be long, and rambling, and full of dad jokes that aren't funny.

And Bren… she's going to be supportive, I know she is. But I still feel guilty. Like I've let her down. She's always been so good to me, and I just… messed up.

I've rehearsed what I'm going to say a million times in my head. But every time I try to picture the actual conversation, my throat closes up and I start to panic.

I'm mostly just terrified of ruining everything. Of changing the way they see me. Of losing their trust.

I know they love me, but this is… a lot. It's not exactly the kind of news you want to share with your parents.

I'm thinking of telling them after dinner, when we're all watching TV. Maybe that way it won't be so intense. Or maybe I should just rip off the band-aid and tell them right away. I don't know. I'm completely paralyzed with anxiety.

Honestly, I'd rather face a room full of angry bees than have this conversation. But I have to do it. It's the right thing to do. Even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

Just… wish me luck. I'm going to need it. A *lot* of luck. And maybe a really big piece of chocolate cake. For emotional support.

Ugh, okay, that's… a loaded question. It's not like they *wouldn't* help, exactly. It's just… complicated.

With my mom, it's obvious, right? She's… not around. She's a free spirit, remember? She's off chasing her dreams, which is fine, I guess. But she's not exactly the reliable type. I can't exactly call her up and be like, "Hey, Mom, I'm pregnant. Can you come home and help?" She'd probably just say, "Wow, that's intense!" and then tell me a story about her latest adventure. It's not that she doesn't care, she just… doesn't *do* responsibility.

With my dad and Bren, it's different. They're good people. They love me. But I didn't want to disappoint them. I knew they had plans for me. College, a good career, a stable life. And I knew that getting pregnant would throw a wrench into all of that.

I also didn't want to burden them. They already have enough on their plates. And I didn't want to make them worry. I'm pretty good at pretending everything's okay, and I thought I could handle this on my own.

But mostly, I think I was just scared. Scared of their reaction. Scared of being judged. Scared of ruining everything.

It was easier to just… keep it to myself. To try to figure things out on my own. It wasn't the smartest thing to do, I know. But it felt like the right thing at the time.

I eventually told them, of course. Bren found out first, and she was amazing. My dad was… surprised. But he came around. They both were really supportive, in their own way.

But it took me a long time to ask for help. And it's still something I struggle with. It's hard to be vulnerable, to admit that you're not okay. But I'm learning. Slowly but surely. And I'm learning that it's okay to lean on the people who love you. Even if it's scary.

Okay, let's just get this out there. It's not a *happy* decision. It's a hard one. A really, really hard one. And it's not something I took lightly. It wasn't like, "Oh, a baby? That's inconvenient, let's just give it away." It was… a lot more complicated than that.

But after a lot of thinking, and a lot of talking, I realized that adoption was the most responsible thing to do. For everyone involved.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being ready to raise a whole other human being. I'm not financially stable. I'm still in school. I have dreams and goals that I want to pursue. And honestly, I don't think I could give a baby the life it deserves right now.

And that's not a selfish thing to admit. It's just… realistic.

I want this baby to have a loving, stable home. I want it to have parents who are prepared and excited to raise it. I want it to have opportunities that I couldn't provide.

Mark and Vanessa, they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're financially secure, they have a beautiful home, and they're just… genuinely good people. They're so excited about the prospect of becoming parents, and I know they'll love this baby unconditionally.

It's not about me not wanting the baby. It's about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And I believe that life is with Mark and Vanessa.

It's going to be hard, saying goodbye. It's going to be painful. But I know that it's the right thing to do. And I find some comfort in knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for.

It's not a perfect solution. There's no such thing. But it's the best option. For me, and for the baby. And that's what matters most. It's about putting the baby's needs first, even when it breaks my heart. And honestly? That's a pretty grown-up thing to do. Even if I don't always *feel* grown up.

Okay, this is the big one, right? This is what keeps me up at night. It's not about finding perfect people, because perfect people don't exist. It's about finding people who are… right.

First and foremost, they have to be **stable**. I need to know the baby will be safe and secure, both physically and emotionally. A solid home, a reliable income, a loving environment. That's non-negotiable.

Second, they have to be **open-minded**. I want them to be accepting of all kinds of people and ideas. I don't want the baby to grow up in a narrow-minded world.

Third, they have to be **patient**. Raising a kid is hard work. It requires a lot of patience and understanding. I want them to be able to handle the challenges that come with parenthood.

Fourth, they have to be **fun**. I want the baby to grow up in a home where there's laughter and joy. I want them to have a childhood filled with happy memories.

And fifth, and this is the most important thing, they have to **love the baby unconditionally**. Not just as a potential child, but as a unique individual. I want them to cherish the baby for who he or she is, flaws and all.

Mark and Vanessa… they have all of those qualities. They're kind, and patient, and funny. They're excited to become parents, and they're willing to put in the work. They seem genuinely thrilled about the prospect of raising a child.

It's still scary, letting go. But knowing that the baby will be loved and cared for by them… that makes it a little bit easier. It's not about finding replacements for me. It's about finding people who can give the baby a life that I can't. And that's okay. It has to be okay.

I want them to tell the baby my story, too. Not in a sad way, but in a way that shows him or her how much I loved them, even before they were born. It's important for the baby to know where they came from. It's important for me to know that I'm not forgotten.

Ugh. Okay, that's the million-dollar question, isn't it? The one I've been avoiding. Because honestly? I have no idea.

It's not like there's a handbook for this. "So You've Decided to Give Your Baby Up for Adoption: A Step-by-Step Guide." I wish.

I think… I think it's going to be really, really hard. I'm already feeling sad, and scared, and guilty. And I know it's going to get worse when the time actually comes.

Bren says it's okay to grieve. She says it's a normal part of the process. She says I need to allow myself to feel my emotions, and not try to bottle them up. Which is good advice, I guess. But it's easier said than done.

I'm planning on talking to a therapist. Bren set up some appointments for me. I'm not thrilled about the idea of talking to a stranger about my feelings, but I know it might help.

I'm also going to try to focus on the positive. On the fact that I'm giving the baby a good life. On the fact that Mark and Vanessa are going to be amazing parents. On the fact that I'm still young, and I have a future ahead of me.

And I'm going to lean on my support system. Bren, my dad, Leah (when she's willing to talk to me). I need people who will listen to me, and who will be there for me, no matter what.

I'm also going to allow myself to cry. A lot. And to eat a lot of ice cream. And to watch a lot of sad movies. Sometimes you just need to wallow in your misery for a while.

I don't know if any of that will actually work. But I'm going to try. I'm going to try to be strong. I'm going to try to be brave. And I'm going to try to remember that even though this is the hardest thing I've ever done, it's also the right thing to do.

It's going to be a long and difficult journey. But I'm not going to give up. I'm going to keep moving forward, one step at a time. And I'm going to hope that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and say that I survived. And that I learned something from it. And that I'm okay. Maybe.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *this* again. Seriously? People are still hung up on this?

It's just… weird, okay? Like, I'm not a pizza. I'm not a package. I'm a person carrying a person. And the word "deliver" makes it sound like I'm just dropping something off at the post office.

It's dehumanizing, you know? It reduces the whole experience to a transaction. Like, "Oh, Juno's delivering the baby today!" No! I'm *having* a baby. It's a birth. It's a miracle. It's… a lot more complicated than just "delivering" something.

Bren tried to explain it to me, something about medical terminology and logistics. But I don't care about logistics! I care about the fact that I'm bringing a human being into the world. And that deserves a little more respect than the word "deliver."

It's just… a weird word. And it makes me uncomfortable. Is that so wrong? I mean, you don't "deliver" a friend, do you? You *meet* a friend. You don't "deliver" a hug, you *give* a hug. 

It's just… semantics, I guess. But it's semantics that matter. Words have power. And the word "deliver" just feels… wrong.

So yeah. That's why I find it weird. And I'm not going to stop pointing it out. It's a hill I'm willing to die on. Don't judge.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was… a whole thing.

Okay, so, initially, I absolutely did *not* want my dad coming with me. Like, zero desire. It felt too… exposing. Too personal. This was *my* decision, *my* body, *my* life. I didn't want him hovering and making awkward small talk and generally being… my dad.

But Bren pointed out something I hadn't really thought about. She said that even though it was my decision, it didn't mean I had to go through it alone. And she was right. 

My dad… he's not the most emotionally available person, you know? He shows his love in weird ways, like fixing things around the house or making me pancakes. But he's always there. And I knew, deep down, that he was terrified for me. He was trying to be supportive, but he was also clearly heartbroken.

And honestly, I was scared too. Really scared. And I realized that having him there, even if it was awkward, would make me feel a little bit safer. A little bit less alone.

Plus, he's good at asking the practical questions. Like, "What happens if the baby has health problems?" or "What kind of support will you get after the adoption?" I'm good at the emotional stuff, but he's good at the logistics.

So, I reluctantly agreed. And it was… okay. It was still awkward, and he definitely asked a few embarrassing questions. But he was there for me. He held my hand when I needed it. And he made me laugh, even when I didn't want to.

It was a reminder that even though we don't always see eye-to-eye, he loves me. And that's what really matters. So yeah, I let him come. Because sometimes, even a sarcastic, independent teenager needs her dad. Even if she'd never admit it out loud.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Yeah, that's… a thing. It's been a thing for a while, actually.

It's not like I haven't *tried* to figure it out. I've tried on different personalities, different styles, different friend groups. I've been the sarcastic rebel, the quiet observer, the quirky artist… none of them really fit. It's like I'm constantly trying on clothes that are either too big or too small.

Bren says it's okay to not have everything figured out. She says I'm still young, and I have plenty of time to discover who I am. But it's frustrating. Everyone else seems to know who they are. Leah always knew she wanted to be a doctor. My dad always knew he wanted to be a carpenter. Even Paulie Freaks seems to know he wants to be… Paulie Freaks.

And me? I just feel… undefined. Like a blank canvas. Which is kinda cool, I guess. But also kinda terrifying.

I think part of the problem is that I'm afraid of being labeled. I don't want to be put in a box. I want to be free to explore different parts of myself, without having to commit to one identity.

But I'm starting to realize that maybe it's okay to be a little bit of everything. Maybe I don't *have* to be one thing. Maybe I can be a sarcastic rebel *and* a quiet observer *and* a quirky artist. Maybe I can be all of those things, and more.

It's still a work in progress, though. I'm still trying to figure out who I am. And honestly, I don't know if I ever will. But I'm starting to accept that. And maybe, just maybe, that's enough.

It's kinda like… I'm not a specific genre of music. I'm a mixtape. A little bit of everything, all mixed together. And that's okay. That's actually pretty cool, when you think about it. It's just… me. And I'm starting to be okay with that. Even if it's a little bit messy and complicated.

Oh. *That*. Ugh. That was… a moment. A really awkward, really tense moment.

Honestly? I was relieved. Like, massively relieved. My dad and Mark were just… radiating awkwardness. It was thick enough to cut with a knife. And I could tell he was trying to be supportive, but it was just coming off as… weird. And uncomfortable. For everyone.

So when Bren suggested Leah and I go upstairs, I practically jumped at the chance. It was an escape hatch. A lifeline. A way to avoid a potentially disastrous conversation.

But I was also… hurt. A little bit. It felt like my dad was shutting me out. Like he couldn't handle seeing me with Mark, the adoptive father. Like he was embarrassed or something.

And I was mad at Bren, too, for just… whisking us away. It felt like she was minimizing my feelings. Like she didn't think I could handle being in the same room as my dad and Mark.

So I gave her that look. You know the one. The "are you serious?" look. And I mumbled something about how I'm not a little kid and I can handle myself.

But deep down, I was grateful. Because it was the right thing to do. It gave everyone a chance to breathe and regroup. And it allowed me and Leah to have a private moment to process everything.

It was just… a really complicated situation. And Bren, as usual, was trying to navigate it with grace and sensitivity. She's good at that. Even when I'm being a total brat.

It was a turning point, I think. It made me realize how much this was affecting everyone, not just me. And it made me appreciate Bren even more. She's the best. Even when she's bossing me around.

Okay, that's… complicated. It's something I've thought about a *lot*. And it's something Bren and I have talked about endlessly.

At first, I wasn't sure. It felt… scary. Like, if I kept getting updates, it would be harder to let go. Like I'd be constantly reminded of what I gave up. And I was worried it would be confusing for the baby, to have two moms.

But Mark and Vanessa are really open to it. They understand that I need to feel connected, and they want me to be a part of the baby's life, in a way that's healthy for everyone.

And the more I thought about it, the more I realized that it could be a good thing. Not for me, necessarily, but for the baby. I want him or her to know where they came from. I want them to know that I loved them, and that I made this decision because I wanted what was best for them.

So, yeah. I'm okay with an open adoption. I think it's the right thing to do. But it's also terrifying. I'm worried about getting too attached, about interfering, about messing things up.

I think it's going to be a lot of emotions. Joy, sadness, hope, fear… it's going to be a rollercoaster. But I'm willing to try. I'm willing to do whatever it takes to make sure that the baby is happy and healthy.

It's not going to be easy. But I think it's worth it. It's a way for me to stay connected, to be a part of the baby's life, without being a parent. It's a way to honor the bond we share, even if it's a complicated one.

And honestly, it's a little bit comforting to know that I'll get to see him or her grow up. To see what kind of person they become. It's not the life I imagined, but it's a life. And it's a life that I'm willing to embrace. Even if it's a little bit scary.

(A long sigh, and a shift in posture. This is… not a fun memory.)

Ugh. Gerta. That woman. She means well, I guess, but she has a way of saying things that just… land wrong. Like a punch to the gut.

When she said that, about terminating my rights… it was like everything suddenly got really, really real. I knew, logically, that that was part of the process. That giving the baby up for adoption meant giving up my legal claim to him or her. But hearing it *said* like that… it felt so… final.

It felt like I was losing a part of myself. Like I was erasing a future that could have been. Even though I knew, deep down, that it was the right decision.

I remember just staring at her, trying not to cry. I think I mumbled something about it being okay, but I didn't feel okay. I felt… empty. And scared.

It wasn't about wanting to keep the baby, exactly. It was about the idea of having no say in his or her life anymore. No knowing what he or she was doing, or who he or she was becoming. 

Mark and Vanessa had promised an open adoption, which meant I'd get updates and maybe even visit. But it wasn't the same. It wasn't the same as being a mom.

I think that was the moment I really understood the weight of my decision. It wasn't just about giving a baby up. It was about giving up a part of my own future.

It was awful. Honestly. And I'm still processing it, even now. It's something that will probably stay with me for a long time. But I'm trying to focus on the positive. On the fact that the baby will be loved and cared for. And on the fact that I'm making the best decision I can, for everyone involved.

But yeah. Gerta saying that… that was a rough moment. A really rough moment. I needed a lot of chocolate after that. A *lot*.

Ugh. That's… a lot. It's not something I've avoided thinking about, you know? It's kinda hard *to* avoid.

It's bittersweet, honestly. Really bittersweet. On one hand, it's amazing that she and Mark want a baby so much. It makes me feel… good, I guess, knowing that the baby will be loved and cherished. That they'll have parents who are really excited to have them.

But on the other hand… it's a reminder of everything I *won't* be able to give the baby. I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I don't have the resources, the stability, the emotional maturity to raise a child. And knowing that Vanessa is so desperate to be a mother… it makes me feel a little bit guilty. Like I'm letting her down somehow.

But then I remember what Bren said. She said that wanting a baby doesn't make Vanessa a better person, and not being able to have one doesn't make me a worse person. It just *is*. It's a complicated situation, and there are no easy answers.

I think it's really brave of Vanessa to be so open about her desire to be a mother. It shows how much she cares, and how much she's willing to give. And it makes me feel more comfortable with my decision, knowing that the baby will be in such loving hands.

It's still hard, though. It's hard to know that someone else is getting something that I can't have. But I'm trying to focus on the positive. I'm trying to believe that this is the best thing for everyone involved. And I'm trying to trust that Vanessa will be a wonderful mother.

It's just… a lot to process. And sometimes, I just need to sit with those feelings and let them be. It doesn't make them go away, but it makes them a little bit easier to bear.

Oh. *Oh*. Okay, that's a good question. A really good question.

Mark's response… it was… a lot. The whole "buttercup" thing? A little much, honestly. It felt… performative. Like he was trying too hard to prove he was ready to be a dad. Like he was auditioning for the role.

Don't get me wrong, he's a nice guy. And Vanessa is amazing. But Mark's answer just felt… off. It felt like he was more focused on the *idea* of being a dad than on the actual responsibility of it.

Vanessa's response, though? That was real. She talked about the sleepless nights, the worry, the unconditional love. She didn't try to sugarcoat it. She just laid it all out there. And that's what made me feel comfortable. That's what made me trust them.

I think Mark's trying, though. He's a little awkward and clueless, but he's trying. And I think he'll be a good dad, eventually. He just needs to… chill out a little bit. Stop trying to be perfect, and just be present.

It made me realize that being a parent isn't about having all the answers. It's about being willing to learn, to grow, and to love unconditionally. And I think Vanessa gets that. I hope Mark will too.

It also made me think about what *I* want in a partner. Someone who's genuine, someone who's honest, someone who's willing to be vulnerable. Someone who doesn't try to impress me with fancy words and metaphors. Just someone who's real.

So yeah. Mark's response was… interesting. It gave me a lot to think about. And it reinforced my belief that Vanessa is the one who's really going to be the parent. The *real* parent. And that's okay. That's more than okay. It's perfect.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me about the Loring's house. It's… unsettling. Like, seriously unsettling.

It's not that Mr. and Mrs. Loring are *bad* people, exactly. They're just… intensely… *perfect*. Everything in their house is perfectly placed, perfectly clean, perfectly… beige. It's like walking into a magazine spread. And it's suffocating.

They're also… overly attentive. They keep offering me things – snacks, drinks, magazines – and asking me if I'm comfortable. It's nice, I guess, but it feels… invasive. Like they're trying to control everything.

And the way they look at me… it's not judgmental, exactly. It's more like… pity. Like I'm a fragile little bird that needs to be protected. Which, honestly, is the last thing I need. I'm perfectly capable of taking care of myself, thank you very much.

Plus, their house is just… weird. It's full of antique dolls and porcelain figurines and creepy paintings. It feels like something out of a horror movie. I keep expecting one of the dolls to blink at me.

I just feel like I have to be on my best behavior all the time when I'm there. I can't relax, I can't be myself. I feel like I'm being constantly scrutinized. It's exhausting.

So yeah, that's why I'm uncomfortable being left unsupervised at the Loring's house. It's too perfect, too clean, too quiet, and too… creepy. I'd rather hang out in a dumpster. At least a dumpster is honest about what it is.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That's… a big question. It's not simple. It's not like handing over a present on Christmas morning. It's… a lot more complicated than that.

At first, it felt like… loss. Like I was giving something away that was a part of me. And there's still a part of me that feels that way. It's a weird, hollow ache.

But then I started thinking about Mark and Vanessa. And about how much they want a baby. How much they've been wanting a baby. They're good people. They're kind and loving and they're going to give this baby a life that I just… can't provide right now.

And that makes me feel… peaceful. Not happy, exactly. But peaceful. Like I'm doing the right thing. Like I'm giving this baby the best possible chance.

It's a gift, yeah. A gift of life. But it's also a gift of opportunity. An opportunity for Mark and Vanessa to experience the joy of parenthood. An opportunity for the baby to grow up in a loving and supportive home.

It's not the life I imagined for this baby. It's not the life I imagined for myself. But it's a good life. And that's what matters.

I'm still processing it, you know? It's not something you just get over. But I'm learning to accept it. And I'm learning to find joy in the fact that this baby is going to be loved and cherished.

It's… bittersweet. But mostly, it's hopeful. And that's enough. It has to be. It's the best I can do. And I hope, I really hope, that it's enough for everyone. Especially for the little one.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? You're still hung up on that? It was a perfectly valid observation.

Look, Mark is a nice guy. A really nice guy. But he's… enthusiastic. Like, aggressively enthusiastic. And he uses corporate jargon. A lot. It's just… jarring. Especially coming from someone who's about to be a dad.

"ASAP"? Really? It's so… sterile. So impersonal. It's like he's talking to an employee, not a potential mother. It just felt… off.

And it was a little bit of a defense mechanism, honestly. I was nervous about meeting him and Vanessa, and I was trying to keep my distance. Sarcasm is my shield, okay? It's how I protect myself.

Plus, it was just funny. The contrast between his overly formal language and the whole messy, complicated situation we were in was just… absurd.

I didn't mean to be rude, exactly. I just… couldn't help myself. It was a knee-jerk reaction. I'm a sarcastic person, it's what I do.

And honestly, he took it pretty well. He laughed. Which was good. Because if he'd gotten offended, things would have been awkward.

So yeah. That's why I mocked his use of "ASAP." It was a combination of nervousness, sarcasm, and a general dislike of corporate jargon. Don't judge. It's a perfectly reasonable reaction.

Okay, *finally* a question I can answer with authority. This is important. This is crucial.

It's a Fender Mustang. Specifically, a vintage one. Preferably from the early '60s.

Don't even *try* to tell me about Stratocasters or Les Pauls. Those are for showoffs. The Mustang is… understated. It's cool without trying too hard. It's got a short scale length, which is perfect for my hands. And it just *sounds* right. It's got this kind of twangy, slightly fuzzy tone that's perfect for indie rock.

Plus, Kurt Cobain played one. Which, okay, I'm not trying to be *that* person, but it's a pretty good endorsement.

I found mine at a pawn shop, covered in dust and missing a string. It needed a lot of work, but it was worth it. I spent weeks cleaning it up and getting it restrung. Now it's my pride and joy.

It's not just a guitar, it's an extension of myself. It's a way to express my feelings, to escape from reality, to just… be me. 

So yeah. Fender Mustang. Don't even bother with anything else. It's the only guitar you'll ever need. And if you disagree, you clearly have terrible taste in music. Just sayin'.

(Rolls eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? We're still talking about the Melvins? It was one little white lie!

Okay, fine. I lied because… Paulie Bleeker was being a total dork. He was trying to impress me with his "cool" music taste, and he kept going on and on about the Melvins, and I just… panicked.

I didn't want him to think I was some kind of music snob, but I also didn't want to admit that I had no idea who he was talking about. It was a moment of weakness, okay? A desperate attempt to seem interesting and relatable.

I figured, what's the worst that could happen? He'd think I was a fan of the Melvins? It's not like it was a moral failing. It was just… a little fib.

But then he started quizzing me about their albums and their songs, and I was totally out of my depth. It was a disaster.

I should have just been honest with him. I should have said, "Look, I don't know the Melvins, but I like your enthusiasm." But I didn't. I panicked and dug myself deeper and deeper into a hole.

It was stupid. It was embarrassing. And it taught me a valuable lesson: don't lie about things you don't know. Especially when it comes to music.

And honestly, it also taught me that Paulie Bleeker is a little bit of a weirdo. But a cute weirdo. Which is why I ended up with him, I guess.

So yeah. That's the story of the Melvins lie. It was a moment of teenage awkwardness and desperation. And it's something I'll probably regret for the rest of my life. But hey, at least it's a good story, right?

Ugh, okay, don't make me blush. It's… complicated. Mark is… a good guy. A really good guy. And playing music with him was… different.

He's not like anyone I've ever met before. He's kinda dorky, in a charming way. He gets really excited about guitars and amps and stuff, and he talks about music with this intense passion that's kinda endearing.

When we first started playing together, it was just… awkward. I was nervous, and he was nervous, and we were both trying to figure out what the other one was going to do. But then we started to find a rhythm. We started to anticipate each other's moves. And it just… clicked.

It wasn't just about the music, though. It was about the connection. When we were playing, it felt like we were the only two people in the room. Like we were communicating on a level that words couldn't express.

He's really good at making me feel comfortable. He doesn't judge me, or try to fix me, or tell me what to do. He just… accepts me for who I am. And that's something I really appreciate.

Singing with him was… vulnerable. I don't usually sing in front of people, even my friends. But with Mark, it felt safe. Like I could let go and just be myself.

It wasn't romantic, or anything. It was just… a connection. A shared love of music. A mutual respect. A feeling of understanding.

It was a reminder that even in the midst of all the chaos and uncertainty, there's still beauty to be found. And that sometimes, all you need is a good song and a good friend to make you feel a little bit better.

It was… nice. Really nice. And I'm going to miss it. A lot. Don't tell him I said that. It'll go to his head.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on her lips) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Roosevelt. It's not a deep, philosophical reason, okay? It's just… a funny name.

I was at a thrift store, looking for a guitar – a cheap one, because I'm not exactly rolling in dough – and I found this beat-up acoustic. It was missing a string and the finish was all scratched up, but it had a good sound.

And then I saw this little portrait hanging next to it. It was a tiny, faded painting of Theodore Roosevelt. Just… staring at me. With that mustache. It was ridiculous.

And I just thought, "This guitar needs a name. And that guy looks like he could handle a little music."

So, Roosevelt it was. It just felt right. It's a little bit ironic, a little bit silly, and a little bit… presidential. 

Plus, it's a good conversation starter. People always ask about it, and then I get to tell them the story. It's a good way to break the ice.

Don't overthink it. It's just a guitar. And a president. And a weird coincidence. It's not like I named my kid after a historical figure or anything. Though, honestly, Theodore MacGuff does have a certain ring to it… No, no. Bad thought. Don't tell anyone I said that. Roosevelt stays with the guitar. That's final.

Ugh, that's… complicated. It's not like a casual "Hey, how's it going?" text. It's a whole *thing*.

At first, it was really awkward. Like, I was giving updates on *their* baby to people who weren't my family. It felt weirdly formal, you know? Like a business transaction. "Baby is measuring at 12 weeks, heartbeat is strong." It sounded so clinical.

But then, it started to feel… good. They were so genuinely excited about every little milestone. They sent me little gifts, and they asked me how *I* was doing, not just how the baby was doing. They really wanted to be involved, and they wanted me to feel comfortable.

Now, I actually look forward to the updates. It's nice to know that they're thinking about me and the baby. It makes me feel like we're all in this together.

It's also… reassuring. Knowing that they're going to be good parents. That they're going to love and care for the baby. It makes it a little bit easier to let go.

But it's still hard sometimes. It's a constant reminder of what I'm giving up. And I worry about getting too attached. I don't want to make things more difficult for myself, or for them.

Bren says it's healthy to maintain a relationship, and that it doesn't mean I'm changing my mind. She says it shows I'm a mature and responsible person. Which, honestly, is surprising coming from her.

So yeah. I'm okay with keeping them updated. It's not perfect, and it's not always easy, but it feels like the right thing to do. It's a way to stay connected, and to make sure that the baby is going to have the best possible life. And maybe, just maybe, it's a way for me to heal a little bit too.

Okay, you want the real reason? Not the polite, "it's the best thing for the baby" reason? Fine.

It's not just about what's best for the baby, though that's a huge part of it. It's about what's best for *me*. And I've done a lot of thinking about that. A *lot*.

I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am, what I want to do with my life. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm not ready to give up my dreams, my freedom, my… everything.

I see my mom, and I see how her life turned out. Always chasing something, never settling down, never really being there for me. I don't want that. I want stability. I want a future. I want to be able to pursue my passions without having to worry about diapers and daycare and everything else that comes with being a parent.

And honestly? I'm scared. I'm scared of messing up. I'm scared of not being a good mom. I'm scared of ruining a baby's life.

Mark and Vanessa, they're ready. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They have a beautiful home, a stable life, and a whole lot of love to give. They can give this baby everything I can't.

It's not an easy decision. It's the hardest decision I've ever made. But it's the right one. For me. For the baby. For everyone involved.

I know people will judge me. I know they'll say I'm selfish. But I don't care. I have to do what's right for me. And right now, that means giving this baby a chance at a life I can't provide.

So yeah. I'm 104% sure. Because I've thought it through. I've weighed the pros and cons. And I've come to the conclusion that this is the only way. It's not perfect, but it's the best I can do. And sometimes, that's enough. It just… has to be.

Ugh. Okay, that. That was… a lot. It's not something I talk about much, even with Bren.

It was weird. Really weird. I mean, I *knew* they were excited. They wanted a baby for so long. And I wanted them to be happy. I really did. But seeing them… celebrating, right after I left? It felt… jarring.

Like, I had just spent nine months carrying their child. I had gone through a lot. Physically, emotionally… everything. And it felt like they were just… moving on. Like I was just a vessel, a means to an end.

I know that's not fair. I know they were just expressing their joy. And I know they were grateful to me. But it still stung. It made me feel… disposable.

I remember standing outside their house, watching them through the window, and feeling this overwhelming sense of sadness. It wasn't just sadness about giving up the baby, it was sadness about feeling like I wasn't important.

Bren tried to explain it to me. She said they were just processing their emotions in their own way. She said they didn't mean to hurt my feelings. And I believe her. But it didn't make it any easier.

It took me a long time to get over that feeling. To realize that their joy didn't diminish my sacrifice. To understand that they were just trying to navigate a complicated situation, just like I was.

It was a reminder that everyone grieves differently. And that sometimes, even when people are trying to be kind, they can still unintentionally cause pain.

It wasn't a happy moment. It was a complicated moment. And it's a moment I'll probably never forget. It just… reinforced the fact that this whole situation was messy and imperfect. And that sometimes, life just isn't fair.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started. Seriously. It's like everyone in Maplewood suddenly became a gossip columnist. It's exhausting.

The rumors are… ridiculous. Like, people are saying I got pregnant on purpose to get attention. Or that I'm trying to ruin my life. Or that my dad is the father. (Seriously? *My dad*? That's just… gross.)

It's infuriating, honestly. People who don't know me, who don't know anything about my situation, are just making up stories and spreading them around like wildfire. It's like my life is a reality show, and everyone's entitled to an opinion.

I try to ignore it, but it's hard. It's hard to walk down the hallways at school without feeling like everyone's staring at you. It's hard to go to the grocery store without running into someone who whispers behind your back.

Bren says I should just rise above it, but that's easier said than done. It's not like I *asked* for this. I just want to be left alone. I want people to treat me like a normal person, not like some kind of spectacle.

I've learned to tune out most of it, but sometimes it still gets to me. It makes me feel ashamed and embarrassed and angry. It makes me want to just disappear.

But I won't. I'm not going to let the rumors define me. I'm not going to let them control my life. I'm going to keep doing what I'm doing, and I'm going to keep being myself. Even if that means being the subject of gossip and speculation.

Because at the end of the day, the only opinion that really matters is my own. And I know I'm doing the right thing. And that's all that matters.

Plus, honestly, most of the rumors are just plain boring. People have such limited imaginations. It's pathetic.

(A long pause. I fidget with the hem of my sleeve.)

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? The question everyone's been tiptoeing around.

It doesn't get easier, you know? Even after all this time. It still feels… weird. Like a piece of me is going to be missing. And it is, I guess. A big piece.

There are days when I'm really okay with it. When I feel like I'm making the right decision. When I picture Mark and Vanessa, and I know they're going to give the baby a good life. A stable life. A life I can't provide right now.

But then there are other days… days when I just break down and cry. Days when I imagine holding the baby, and rocking it, and watching it grow up. Days when I wonder if I'm making a mistake.

It's not like I don't want the baby. It's just… I want the baby to have everything it deserves. And right now, I can't give it that. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am. I'm not ready to be a mom.

It's selfish, maybe. But it's also… realistic. I have to be honest with myself. And I have to do what's best for the baby, even if it breaks my heart.

I've been talking to a therapist, and she says it's okay to grieve. It's okay to feel sad and scared and confused. She says it doesn't mean I'm a bad person. It just means I'm a human being.

So, how do I feel about it? It's complicated. It's terrifying. It's heartbreaking. But it's also… the right thing to do. I think. I hope.

I'm trying to focus on the positive. On the fact that the baby will be loved and cared for. On the fact that I'll be able to finish school and pursue my own dreams. On the fact that I'm not alone.

But it still hurts. A lot. And I know it's going to hurt for a long time. But I'm trying to be strong. For myself, and for the baby. And that's all I can do.

(I look down at my hands, avoiding eye contact.)

It just… sucks. That's the truth. It just really, really sucks.

Ugh, okay, this again. Everyone keeps asking me about this. It's not some grand philosophical statement, alright? It's just… fun.

Look, everything with this whole situation is so serious and planned and… adult. And I wanted to give Mark and Vanessa *something* that was just a surprise. Something joyful and unexpected. 

They're already doing this huge, amazing thing for me and for the baby. They're taking on a responsibility that's not their own, and they're doing it with open hearts. I wanted to give them a little bit of magic in return.

Plus, I thought it would be funny. Like, imagine their faces when they find out! It's a good story, you know? A little bit of levity in a really heavy situation.

Bren said it was a "gift," and that's kinda how I see it. A gift of anticipation, a gift of joy, a gift of… well, surprise. 

It's not about me wanting to keep a secret. It's about wanting to give Mark and Vanessa something special. Something they'll remember forever. And honestly, it's a little bit selfish. I just wanted to see their reaction.

So yeah. That's why. It's not rocket science. It's just… a surprise. And sometimes, a little bit of surprise is exactly what you need. Especially when life is being a total downer.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That woman. Seriously. It was like she'd seen a movie about teenage pregnancy and decided I was just fulfilling a stereotype.

It wasn't the ultrasound itself that bothered me, it was the *tone*. The little sighs, the pitying looks, the way she talked *about* me instead of *to* me. Like I was some kind of case study, not a person.

She started going on about how "brave" I was, and how "difficult" this must be, and how "many girls in your situation…" and I just wanted to scream. It wasn't bravery, it was a really hard decision I was trying to make responsibly. And it wasn't a "situation," it was *my* life.

And then she started making assumptions about the adoption process, like I was just giving the baby away because I didn't want to deal with the responsibility. Like I hadn't thought about it for weeks, like I hadn't cried myself to sleep every night.

It felt… invalidating. Like my feelings didn't matter. Like my decision wasn't valid. Like I was just another statistic.

I wanted to tell her to mind her own business, but I didn't. I just bit my tongue and stared at the screen, trying to focus on the little blob that was growing inside me.

Afterward, I was really upset. I told Bren about it, and she was furious. She said that woman should lose her license. I didn't go that far, but I definitely didn't want to see her again.

It just… reinforced the idea that people are quick to judge. That they don't bother to understand your story, they just assume they know everything. And it made me even more determined to prove them wrong. To show them that I was capable of making a good decision, and that I was strong enough to handle whatever came my way.

It was a really awful experience. And honestly, it's one of the things I'll probably remember most about this whole thing. The judgment. The assumptions. The lack of respect. It just… sucked.

Ugh, where do I even *begin*? It wasn't exactly a walk in the park, you know? More like a hike up a really steep, muddy hill in the pouring rain.

The biggest challenge, honestly, was the **judgment**. I already talked about that, but it bears repeating. People looking at me like I was some kind of… criminal. Whispers, stares, assumptions. It was exhausting and humiliating. It made me want to disappear.

Then there was the **emotional rollercoaster**. One minute I was okay with my decision, the next I was a sobbing mess. It was like my hormones were having a party and I wasn't invited. Dealing with grief, fear, guilt… it was a lot.

**Telling my dad** was… rough. He was surprisingly supportive, but I could tell he was heartbroken for me. And I didn't want to disappoint him.

**Navigating school** was also a challenge. Trying to pretend everything was normal when my body was changing and my life was falling apart. Dealing with curious classmates and nosy teachers. It was exhausting.

And then there was the **adoption process itself**. It was a lot of paperwork, a lot of meetings, a lot of waiting. It was emotionally draining and legally complicated.

But honestly, the hardest part was **letting go**. Meeting Mark and Vanessa, getting to know them, and then knowing that I had to give them the baby… it was excruciating. It felt like a piece of my heart was being ripped out.

It wasn't just one big challenge, it was a series of smaller challenges that all added up. And it forced me to grow up really fast. It forced me to confront my own beliefs and values. And it forced me to make some really difficult decisions.

It wasn't easy. It was probably the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I'm stronger for it. Even if I'm still a little bit scarred. And still really good at sarcasm. Some things never change.

Whoa. Okay. That's… a big question. Like, existential crisis level big.

Before all this, love felt… kinda abstract. Like something you read about in books or saw in movies. It was all grand gestures and romantic declarations. I thought it was about butterflies and fireworks and finding your "soulmate." Which, honestly, sounded kinda exhausting.

Now… now I see that love is a lot more complicated than that. It's about sacrifice. It's about putting someone else's needs before your own. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if it means letting them go. It's about Mark and Vanessa, and the way they talk about wanting a family. It's about Bren, and the way she's been there for me, no matter what. It's not always easy or glamorous, but it's real.

Responsibility… that's something I definitely didn't understand before. I thought responsibility was about doing your homework and cleaning your room. Now I know it's about making difficult decisions that have lasting consequences. It's about taking ownership of your actions and being accountable for your choices. It's about realizing that your decisions don't just affect you, they affect other people too. It's terrifying, honestly.

And growing up… I thought growing up was about getting older and getting more freedom. I thought it was about being able to do whatever you want, whenever you want.
