Now I know it's about facing hard truths and making tough choices. It's about learning to navigate a world that's messy and complicated and unfair. It's about realizing that you're not always in control, and that sometimes you just have to roll with the punches.

This experience has forced me to grow up faster than I ever expected. It's taken away my innocence, in a way. But it's also given me a new appreciation for life. It's taught me the importance of love, responsibility, and resilience.

I'm still figuring things out, of course. I'm still a work in progress. But I'm not the same person I was before. I'm stronger, and wiser, and more compassionate. And I think, in the end, that's a good thing. Even if it's been the hardest thing I've ever gone through.

It's kinda messed up, but I think I needed this. I needed to be challenged. I needed to be forced to confront my own beliefs and values. I needed to learn what it really means to be a grown-up. And I think, maybe, just maybe, I'm starting to figure it out.

(Eyes narrow, a slight defensive posture) Okay, first of all, that's *none* of your business. It's just… a chair. And a couch. And a really weird lamp.

But fine. You want to know? It's… a vibe.

See, I ride my bike past that house on Centennial Lane all the time. And that living room set… it's just sitting there, on the curb, all faded and dusty. It looks like it's been abandoned for years. Like it's holding a lot of secrets.

It's kinda sad, actually. Like someone's life just… stopped. And left all their stuff behind. It makes you wonder what happened to them. Where they went. What they were thinking.

I'm drawn to things that are broken or forgotten. Vintage stuff, old movies, abandoned furniture… they all have a story to tell. And I like imagining those stories.

Plus, the couch is *really* comfortable looking. Like, the kind of couch you could just sink into and disappear for hours. And the lamp is hideous, but in a really cool way. It's got this weird, retro vibe that I can't resist.

I've been thinking about maybe… rescuing it. Fixing it up. Giving it a new life. It's kinda symbolic, I guess. Taking something that's been abandoned and making it beautiful again.

Don't tell anyone I said that, though. It'll ruin my reputation as a cynical teenager. Just… let me have my abandoned living room set, okay? It's the one thing in my life that feels… uncomplicated. And right now, I need all the uncomplicated things I can get.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that* guy. Seriously, the creepiest part of the whole… everything. Everyone always asks about the Wizard. Like he's some kind of profound philosophical enigma. He's just… weird.

Okay, look. I've thought about that line a *lot*. It's been stuck in my head for months. And I still don't have a definitive answer.

But I think… I think he meant he'd been waiting for someone to *need* him. To need his… weirdness. He's a lonely guy, right? He collects those statues, he lives in the basement, he doesn't have any friends. He probably felt… useful, for once. Like he finally had a purpose.

It's messed up, I know. He was exploiting my situation, preying on my vulnerability. But I think that's what he meant. He wasn't necessarily obsessed with *me*, he was obsessed with the idea of being needed.

It's like he'd been building up all this… energy, all this weirdness, and he was just waiting for the right moment to unleash it. And I, unfortunately, was that moment.

Bren thinks it was about control. That he wanted to control the situation, to control me. And that's probably true too. He's a controlling person.

But I think it was more than that. I think it was about loneliness and desperation. He was a sad, pathetic guy who was looking for a connection, and he found it in the most twisted way possible.

Honestly, I try not to think about it too much. It gives me the creeps. He's just… a reminder that there are some really strange people out there. And you have to be careful who you trust. Especially weird guys in basements with creepy statues. Seriously. Just… avoid them.

(Rolls eyes) Oh. *That*. Everyone always asks about the juice container. It's become, like, a whole *thing*.

Okay, look. It wasn't just about the juice container. It was about… everything. The positive pregnancy test, the weirdness with Paulie Bleeker, the fact that my life was suddenly completely and utterly derailed. It was all just… too much.

The juice container was just a symbol. A symbol of all the things I was trying to ignore, all the things I was pretending weren't happening. Throwing it away didn't magically fix anything, obviously. But it felt… cathartic. Like I was throwing away a piece of my old life.

And then I rushed to Dancing Elk Drug because I needed a pregnancy test. A *digital* pregnancy test. I needed something definitive, something that would tell me, without a doubt, that this was actually happening. The cheap ones from the grocery store weren't cutting it. I needed confirmation.

Plus, Mr. Elk is kinda cute. Not in a, like, "I want to date him" way. But he's nice, and he always remembers my name. And sometimes, you just need a friendly face when your world is falling apart.

So yeah. Juice container, existential crisis, and a desperate need for a digital pregnancy test. That's the story. It's not as dramatic as people make it out to be. It was just… a moment. A really, really weird moment. And honestly, I'm still trying to process it.

(Rolls eyes so hard I think I pulled a muscle) Oh. *That*. Seriously? You want to revisit *that*?

Okay, look. It was mortifying. Utterly, completely mortifying. I was at the drugstore with Paulie Bleeker, trying to buy some prenatal vitamins – which, by the way, is not a conversation you want to have with a teenage boy – and this… this *woman* just walks up to me. She was, like, aggressively athletic looking. All muscles and neon spandex. Hence, "Tough Girl."

And she just… stares at me. And then she asks, in this really loud voice, if my nipples are real brown.

I have no idea why she asked that. I honestly think she was just trying to be shocking. Or maybe she was having a bad day. Or maybe she was just… weird.

I just stared back at her, completely speechless. Paulie, bless his awkward heart, tried to intervene, but he just stammered something about vitamins and then turned bright red.

I eventually mumbled something about it being none of her business and then practically ran out of the store. 

It was a reminder that people are… strange. And that sometimes, you just have to deal with really uncomfortable situations. And that maybe I should start wearing more layers when I go to the drugstore.

Honestly, I still cringe when I think about it. It's one of those moments that will haunt me forever. But hey, at least it makes for a good story, right? A really, really embarrassing story.

Ugh. Leah. Just saying her name… it's complicated. Our friendship was… everything. We were inseparable since like, fifth grade. We understood each other without even having to talk. We had our own language, our own inside jokes, our own weird little world.

When I found out I was pregnant, she was the first person I told. I thought she'd be horrified, but she wasn't. She was… supportive. At first. She helped me pick out a name, and we spent hours talking about what I was going to do. She was my rock.

But then… things started to change. I started making decisions about the adoption, and she didn't agree with them. She thought I should keep the baby, and she kept trying to convince me otherwise. She didn't understand why I couldn't just… figure it out.

And then she started getting really distant. She stopped calling, she stopped texting, she stopped showing up at school. It was like she was punishing me for making a decision she didn't like.

It was really painful. I felt like I was losing my best friend. And I was angry. Angry that she couldn't support me, angry that she was making this even harder than it already was.

Eventually, we had a huge fight. We said a lot of things we didn't mean. And then… we just stopped talking.

Looking back, I think she was scared. Scared of losing me, scared of what this meant for our friendship, scared of the future. But she didn't know how to deal with her fear, so she just pulled away.

Our friendship played a huge role in my journey, but not in a good way. It showed me how fragile relationships can be, and how important it is to have people in your life who will support you, no matter what. It also taught me that sometimes, even the closest friendships can fall apart.

I miss her. I really do. But I also know that I made the right decision for myself, and for the baby. And I hope, someday, she'll understand that. But right now, it just… hurts. It's a reminder of everything I've lost. And a reminder that even when you think you know someone, you never really do.

Ugh, that. Okay, that was… a moment. A really scary moment.

It wasn't a planned thing, honestly. It just… happened. I was at the appointment, and the technician was all, "Here's the baby!" and showed me the ultrasound. And it was… weird. It was this little blurry image, but it was *real*. It was my baby.

And I just… felt this overwhelming urge to share it with Mark and Vanessa. I wanted them to see it. I wanted them to connect with it. I wanted them to start feeling like parents.

Bren had talked to me about how important it was for adoptive parents to feel a connection with the baby, even before birth. And I realized that showing them the ultrasound was a way to do that. It was a way to say, "This is your baby. This is the little person you're going to love and care for."

I was terrified, though. I was worried they'd think I was being weird or intrusive. I was worried they'd be disappointed that I wasn't more excited. I was worried about a million different things.

But I just took a deep breath and handed them the picture. And they were… overjoyed. They were so happy and excited, and they kept saying how beautiful it was. And it made me feel… good. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing.

It was a risk, I know. It wasn't the conventional thing to do. But it felt right. It felt like a way to show them how much I cared about their future baby, and how much I trusted them to give it a good life.

And honestly, it was a turning point for me. It was the moment I really started to accept my decision and to feel at peace with it. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot. To them, and to me.

(Eyes narrow, a slight tightening of the jaw)

Oh. *That*. Yeah. That was… a moment. A really, really awkward moment.

Honestly? My first thought was, "Okay, this is a disaster. This is a *huge* disaster." Like, I'd mentally prepared myself for meeting Vanessa, for making small talk, for trying to seem normal and not-pregnant and generally not a mess. And then Mark just casually drops that she's… not there?

I think I just stared at him for a solid five seconds, trying to process what he'd said. It felt like a scene from a really bad movie. Like, was this some kind of test? Was he trying to scare me? Was Vanessa secretly a spy? My brain went into overdrive.

Then I asked him, all casual-like, "Oh. Okay. Where is she?" Trying to sound like it wasn't a big deal, even though it totally was.

And when he told me she was at a pottery class… a *pottery class*? I almost burst out laughing. It was just so… random. Like, of all the things she could be doing, she's making pots?

It felt… weirdly revealing, though. Like, they had their own lives, their own hobbies, their own things going on. And I was just… this temporary visitor. This… situation.

It made me feel even more vulnerable, I guess. Like I was intruding on their perfect little world. And it made me question everything. Was this the right decision? Were they really ready for this?

I think I just ended up making a sarcastic comment about pottery being a really good way to relieve stress. Because what else was I going to do? Cry? I'd already done enough of that.

It was a really uncomfortable moment. But looking back on it, I think it was also a turning point. It made me realize that this wasn't just about me. It was about them too. And I needed to be respectful of their lives, and their feelings. Even if it was awkward. Especially if it was awkward.

Ugh, okay, you're bringing up the commercial thing? Seriously? That was a knee-jerk reaction, alright? Don't analyze it so much.

It wasn't about *him* being a sellout, exactly. It was about… the hypocrisy of it all. He and Vanessa were so focused on finding the "perfect" parents for the baby, someone with a stable home and a good life. Which is totally fair, I get it.

But then he tells me he makes a living making commercials for, like, fast food and car dealerships. It just felt… ironic. Like, he's judging other people's choices, but he's contributing to a culture that's all about consumerism and superficiality.

I know it was a mean thing to say. I didn't mean to hurt his feelings. It was just… a defense mechanism. I was feeling vulnerable and overwhelmed, and I lashed out with a joke. It's what I do.

Plus, I'm just naturally skeptical of anyone who works in advertising. It feels… manipulative. Like they're trying to convince people to buy things they don't need.

I apologized to Mark later, though. He understood. He said he knew it was a cheap shot, but he also said he appreciated my honesty. Which is… nice.

Honestly, I think I was just projecting my own insecurities onto him. I was worried that I was making the wrong decision, and I was looking for something to latch onto. And his job just happened to be an easy target.

So yeah. That's the story behind the sellout comment. It was a stupid, impulsive thing to say. But it was also a reflection of my own internal struggles. And sometimes, I just can't help but be a sarcastic jerk. It's a flaw, I admit it.

(A small, almost imperceptible softening in her voice)

Okay, wow. That's… specific. You really did your research, huh?

It was… a lot. I mean, I knew Mark and Vanessa wanted a baby. They'd talked about it a lot. But seeing his reaction to the ultrasound… it was different. It was like, all of a sudden, this wasn't just a plan anymore. It was *real*.

He just… froze. He stared at the screen, and his eyes filled with tears. And he didn't say anything for a long time. He just kept looking at the little blurry image, and his hand was shaking.

And it made me feel… weird. A lot of things at once.

Part of me felt really, really sad. Sad that I wasn't the one who got to experience that. Sad that I wasn't the one who got to feel that connection with the baby.

But mostly, I felt… relieved. Relieved that the baby was going to have a dad who was already so in love with him or her. Relieved that the baby was going to have someone who was going to cherish and protect him or her.

It was like, in that moment, I knew I was making the right decision. It wasn't about me anymore. It was about giving the baby the best possible life. And Mark's reaction just confirmed that.

It was also kinda scary, though. It made it feel so… final. Like this was really happening. And I was really giving up my baby.

But mostly, it was beautiful. It was a really beautiful moment. And I'm glad I got to witness it. It gave me a little bit of peace, knowing that the baby was going to be loved. And that's all I ever wanted.

(She looks away, a flicker of emotion crossing her face)

Don't tell anyone I said that, okay? I have a reputation to maintain.

Ugh. Havenbrooke. Just the name gives me the creeps. It felt… sterile. Cold. Like a place where feelings went to die.

Honestly? The thought of getting an abortion there terrified me. Not because of any moral or religious reasons, really. It was more… visceral. It just didn't *feel* right.

I went to the clinic with Leah, and it was… awful. The waiting room was full of people, all looking scared and uncomfortable. And the protesters outside… they were yelling and holding signs. It felt like everyone was judging me, even though they didn't know my story.

And then I met with the counselor, and she was nice enough, but she just seemed… detached. Like she was going through the motions. She didn't really listen to me, she just told me about the procedure and the risks.

I started thinking about it, really thinking about it, and I realized I couldn't do it. It wasn't about what other people thought, or what was "logical" or "responsible." It was about what *I* felt. And I felt… sad. And scared. And like I would regret it for the rest of my life.

It wasn't that I wanted to have the baby, exactly. I just couldn't bring myself to end a life. Even a life that hadn't fully begun yet. It felt… wrong.

I know a lot of people feel differently, and that's okay. But for me, abortion just wasn't the right choice. It wasn't something I could live with.

Leaving Havenbrooke, I felt… relieved. And also incredibly confused. I didn't know what I was going to do, but I knew I couldn't go through with it. And that was enough, for then. It was a really hard decision, and it took a lot of courage to admit to myself that it wasn't the right path for me. It just… wasn't. And that's all there is to it.

(Sighs dramatically and rolls eyes) Oh. *This*. Okay. Here we go. Prepare for awkward.

Bleeker. Paulie Bleeker. He's… a good guy. Really. He's sweet, and kind, and he's a really good guitar player. And he's… well, he's Bleeker. Which means he's kinda clueless sometimes, but in a charming way.

We'd been friends for a long time, since middle school. We bonded over music, mostly. He'd always try to impress me with his guitar skills, and I'd pretend to be impressed. It was a good dynamic.

Our relationship… it wasn't exactly a whirlwind romance. It was more of a slow burn. We spent a lot of time together, just hanging out, talking, listening to music. And gradually, we started to develop feelings for each other.

The thing is, I wasn't really looking for a relationship. I was too focused on school, and music, and just… being me. But Bleeker was persistent. He was always there, offering a listening ear, a goofy smile, and a really comfortable silence.

And then… well, then things happened. I got pregnant. And everything changed.

Being intimate with him… it wasn't a planned thing. It wasn't some grand romantic gesture. It was… a mistake. A really big, life-altering mistake. We were both young and stupid and we weren't thinking clearly. It just… happened.

I won't go into details. It's personal. And honestly, it's still a little bit painful to think about.

After I found out I was pregnant, things got even more complicated. We were both scared and confused. We didn't know what to do. But we talked. A lot. And we decided to support each other, no matter what.

It wasn't easy. It's still not easy. But we're trying. We're learning to navigate this new reality together. And I think, despite everything, we're actually getting closer.

It's not a perfect relationship. It's messy and complicated and sometimes frustrating. But it's real. And it's ours. And that's all that matters.

Look, it was a mistake, okay? A big one. But it also led to something… unexpected. And I'm trying to learn from it. And I'm trying to move forward. With Bleeker by my side. Even if he is a little bit clueless sometimes.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Okay, look, let's just get this over with. It's not exactly a topic I enjoy revisiting.

Initially? I was mortified. Absolutely, completely mortified. Bleeker, as lovely and musically inclined as he is, was… not exactly the guy I pictured starting a family with. He was sweet, sure, but he was also… Bleeker. Kind of spacey, a little clueless, and definitely not ready to be a dad. And neither was I, let's be real.

It wasn't about him being a bad person. It was about the sheer *impossibility* of the situation. We were kids! We had no idea what we were doing. The thought of trying to raise a baby with him felt… terrifying.

There was a lot of panic, a lot of denial, and a lot of awkward conversations. Mostly with my dad and Bren. And a lot of internal screaming.

But as time went on, and I started to feel the baby move, things… shifted. It wasn't like I suddenly became all maternal and gushy. That's not my style. But I started to feel a connection to the little person growing inside me. I started to think about the future, and about what kind of life I wanted for the baby.

It was complicated. I still knew that I couldn't raise the baby myself, but I started to feel a sense of responsibility. A sense of love.

And honestly, I felt a little bit sorry for Bleeker. He was just as scared and confused as I was. He wanted to do the right thing, but he didn't know how.

So, yeah. Being pregnant with Bleeker's child was a mess. It was scary, and overwhelming, and heartbreaking. But it was also… a little bit beautiful. It forced me to grow up, to confront my own fears, and to make a difficult decision. And it taught me a lot about myself, and about the world.

And, you know, Bleeker actually turned out to be a pretty good guy throughout the whole thing. He showed up. He supported me. He even went to some of the appointments with me. He's still Bleeker, but he's a good Bleeker. A surprisingly supportive Bleeker.

Ugh. Bleeker. Just saying his name makes me cringe a little. Not because he's a bad guy, he's… Bleeker. Sweet, awkward, perpetually flustered Bleeker. It's just… the whole thing was a disaster.

Okay, so I'd been putting it off for days. Like, actively avoiding him. Every time I saw him in the hallway, I'd duck into a classroom or pretend to be really engrossed in a book. It was pathetic, I know. But I was terrified.

I finally cornered him after school, near the bike racks. It was raining, which, naturally, made everything even more dramatic. I just blurted it out. No preamble, no easing into it. Just, "I'm pregnant."

His reaction was… exactly what I expected. He went completely white. Like, Casper the Friendly Ghost white. And he just stood there, mouth open, looking like a deer in headlights.

He didn't say anything for a good minute. He just kept staring at me. And then he finally managed to stammer out, "You're… you're what?"

I repeated it, because apparently he hadn't heard me the first time. "I'm pregnant, Bleeker. We're going to have a baby."

And then he started to hyperventilate. Seriously. He was gasping for air and clutching his chest like he was having a heart attack. It was… not a good look.

He kept asking me if I was sure, and if I'd gone to a doctor, and if it was even possible. It was like he was trying to deny reality. Which, honestly, I kind of understood.

He didn't offer to help, or to be supportive, or anything like that. He just kept repeating, "Oh my god. Oh my god. Oh my god."

Eventually, he mumbled something about needing to go home and think, and then he just… ran away. He literally ran. It was kind of embarrassing.

It wasn't the reaction I was hoping for, obviously. But I wasn't really expecting him to be thrilled about it. He's Bleeker. He's not exactly known for his emotional maturity.

It just confirmed what I already knew: I was on my own. And that was okay. I could handle it. I *had* to handle it. Even if it meant facing it all by myself, in the pouring rain. It was just… a really awkward and disappointing conversation. And honestly, I'm still a little bit mad at him for running away. But what can you do? It was Bleeker.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? It's not something I talk about a lot. It still… hurts.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. And it still is, sometimes. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry. Days when I questioned everything. Days when I wondered if I was making the right decision.

There was a lot of guilt, at first. Guilt about getting pregnant in the first place, guilt about not being able to raise the baby, guilt about giving him or her away. It felt like I was failing, like I was letting everyone down.

But then I started to realize that I wasn't failing. I was making a selfless decision. I was giving the baby a chance at a life that I couldn't provide. A life with two loving parents who were ready and able to give him or her everything they needed.

And I started to feel… peace. Not complete peace, not yet. But a sense of acceptance. A sense of knowing that I was doing the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

Seeing Mark and Vanessa, seeing how excited they were, seeing how much they already loved the baby… that helped. It made me feel like I was giving him or her to a good home.

But it still doesn't mean I don't miss him or her. I think about the baby all the time. I wonder what he or she looks like, what he or she is doing. I wonder if he or she will ever know who I am.

It's a complicated mix of emotions. Sadness, relief, hope, regret. It's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with.

I still think it was the right decision. But that doesn't mean it didn't break my heart. It did. And it probably always will. But I'm trying to focus on the future, and on building a life for myself. And I'm hoping that the baby is happy and healthy, and that he or she knows that I loved him or her, even though I couldn't keep him or her.

(Looks down at her hands, then back up, a small, sad smile on her face)

It's… a lot. It just is.

Oh, *finally* a good question. Like, a question I can actually get excited about. Seriously, you were asking me about "professional growth" and "core values." This is way better.

Okay, so I'm a pretty big indie music fan. Like, *really* big. I'm talking The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie… that kind of stuff. You know, the stuff your parents wouldn't understand.

I love music that's honest and raw and a little bit quirky. I like lyrics that are clever and thought-provoking. And I like melodies that are catchy but not cheesy.

I'm also really into vinyl. There's just something about the sound of a record that digital music can't replicate. It's warmer, more authentic. Plus, the album art is usually really cool.

I listen to a lot of folk music too. Joni Mitchell, Bob Dylan, Joan Baez… those are some of my heroes. Their songs are so beautiful and poetic.

And I have a soft spot for 80s new wave. The Cure, The Smiths, New Order… it's just good music to mope to, you know? Which, let's be real, I do a lot of these days.

I'm not really into mainstream pop music. It just feels… manufactured. Like it's all about image and marketing, and not about the music itself.

So yeah. Indie, folk, new wave, vinyl… that's my musical world in a nutshell. It's my escape, my inspiration, my soundtrack to life. And honestly, I don't know what I'd do without it. It's the one thing that always makes me feel better, even when everything else is falling apart.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go listen to some Belle & Sebastian. It's a good day for a little bit of melancholy.

(Wrinkles nose, makes a face) Oh. *Oh*. You're trying to trick me, aren't you? You think you're being clever.

Okay, look. I'm a connoisseur of the weird. I appreciate a good, messed-up movie. But "The Wizard of Gore"... that's not just messed up. That's… aggressively unpleasant.

It's not even *good* bad. It's just… bad. Like, amateur hour, someone's uncle made this in his basement bad. The special effects are laughable, the acting is atrocious, and the whole premise is just… disturbing.

I get that it's supposed to be satirical, and that it's poking fun at exploitation films. But it doesn't do it in a clever or insightful way. It just feels gratuitous and exploitative itself.

Honestly, watching it made me feel… dirty. Like I needed to take a shower and cleanse my soul.

I've seen some pretty disturbing stuff in my life, but "The Wizard of Gore" is on a whole other level. It's not something I would recommend to anyone. Unless you're trying to punish them.

Seriously. Don't watch it. Just… don't. You'll thank me later.

I prefer my weirdness with a little more… artistry. Like, "Harold and Maude" is weird, but it's also beautiful and thought-provoking. "The Wizard of Gore" is just… gross.

Ugh. Now I need to go listen to The Moldy Peaches to restore my faith in humanity. This conversation has officially ruined my day.

(Wrinkles nose) Ugh. Madison. Seriously?

It's… fine. I guess. It's not the *worst* name I've ever heard. But it's so… popular. Like, *really* popular. It feels kinda generic, you know? Like you're naming your kid after a shopping mall.

It's not a terrible name, don't get me wrong. It's just… boring. It lacks personality. It doesn't have any… edge.

I prefer names that are a little bit more unique, a little bit more quirky. Like, I always liked the name Beatrix. Or Clementine. Those names have character.

Madison just feels… safe. And I'm not a big fan of safe. I like things that are a little bit different, a little bit unexpected.

So, yeah. My opinion on the name Madison? It's okay. But I wouldn't name my kid that. Unless, like, I was forced to. Which, thankfully, I won't be.

Honestly, naming a kid is a huge responsibility. You're giving them a name they're going to have to live with for the rest of their life. You want to choose something that's special, something that reflects their personality. Something that doesn't sound like a suburb in New Jersey.

Just my two cents. Don't shoot the messenger. I'm just being honest.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? The question everyone's been tiptoeing around.

It's not easy. It's the hardest decision I've ever had to make. It feels… wrong, in a lot of ways. Like I'm giving away a piece of myself. Like I'm failing as a person.

But it's also the right decision.

I'm sixteen. I'm not ready to be a mom. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone who I want to be as a parent. I want to finish school, and maybe go to college, and travel, and just… live my life. And I want my baby to have a life too. A good life. A stable life. A life with parents who are ready and able to provide for him or her.

Mark and Vanessa… they're amazing. They've been wanting a baby for a long time. They're kind and loving and they have a beautiful home. I know they'll give my baby everything I can't.

It doesn't make it easy, though. There are days when I just… break down and cry. I miss the baby already, and I haven't even met him or her yet. I worry about whether I'm making the right decision. I worry about whether the baby will be happy.

But I have to believe that I am. I have to believe that this is the best thing for everyone involved.

It's not about giving up on my baby. It's about giving my baby a chance. A chance at a life that I can't provide right now.

It's a selfless act, I guess. But it doesn't feel selfless. It feels… heartbreaking. And terrifying. And incredibly lonely.

But I'm doing it. And I'm trying to be strong. And I'm hoping that someday, I'll be able to look back on this and know that I made the right choice. Even if it was the hardest choice I've ever had to make.

It's… complicated. Really complicated. And it's something I'm going to be dealing with for a long time, I think. But it's my reality. And I'm trying to face it with as much grace and courage as I can muster.

Ugh. Okay, that's… the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's not like there's a handbook for this. "Teen Pregnancy 101: Surviving High School and Growing a Human." It doesn't exist.

Honestly? It's a constant juggling act. And I'm pretty sure I'm dropping a lot of balls.

The biggest challenge is just… the sheer exhaustion. Being pregnant is *tiring*. Like, bone-deep, soul-crushing tired. And then you add on top of that the stress of school, and friends, and family, and trying to figure out your future… it's overwhelming.

I cope by compartmentalizing. Which is probably unhealthy, but it's what I do. When I'm at school, I try to focus on school. When I'm with my friends, I try to be a normal teenager. And when I'm dealing with the pregnancy stuff, I try to just get through it one day at a time.

I also rely heavily on my support system. Bren is a lifesaver. She's always there to listen, to offer advice, to just hold my hand when I need it. And my dad, Mac, he's been surprisingly supportive too. He's not always the most emotionally expressive, but he shows he cares in his own way.

And I try to find moments of joy. Listening to music, watching movies, spending time with my friends (the ones I still see), just doing things that make me happy. It's important to remember that life isn't all doom and gloom.

But it's also okay to not be okay. There are days when I just want to curl up in a ball and cry. And I let myself do that. I don't try to pretend that everything is fine when it's not.

It's a lot. It's a lot to handle. But I'm learning to be resilient. I'm learning to be strong. And I'm learning to trust myself. And I think, somehow, I'm going to get through this. Even if it's messy and complicated and exhausting.

And honestly? Sometimes, just surviving the day feels like a victory. And that's enough. For now, that's enough.

Ugh, *that* is the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's like… my whole life is a constant tug-of-war between wanting to do everything myself and needing someone to just… hold my hand.

I think it comes down to recognizing that needing help isn't a sign of weakness. It's a sign of strength. It means you're smart enough to know your limits, and brave enough to ask for assistance. Which, honestly, is something I've had to learn the hard way.

I've always been fiercely independent. I think it's a defense mechanism. If I don't rely on anyone, I can't get hurt, right? Wrong. It just makes you lonely and exhausted.

But this whole pregnancy thing… it's forced me to rely on other people. I couldn't have done it without Bren. And even though I was terrified to ask for help, I realized that it was okay. It was actually… good.

I think the key is to be selective about who you let in. You don't need to rely on everyone. Just the people you trust. The people who genuinely care about you. The people who won't judge you.

And you have to be willing to be vulnerable. To admit that you're struggling. To ask for what you need. It's not easy, but it's worth it.

I still crave my independence, though. I still want to be able to make my own decisions and live my life on my own terms. But I've learned that it's okay to lean on others when I need to. It doesn't diminish my independence. It enhances it.

It's like… I can be a lone wolf, but even lone wolves sometimes need a pack. It's about finding the right balance. And it's something I'm still working on. But I'm getting better at it. And I'm learning to appreciate the support of the people who love me. Even if I don't always show it.

Ugh. Bleeker. Just saying his name makes me roll my eyes a little. He was… a lot. A sweet lot, but a lot.

At first, it was just… awkward. We were both kids, you know? He was this quiet, kinda nerdy guy who I barely knew, and suddenly we were… connected. By a baby. It was not exactly a rom-com meet-cute.

He tried to be supportive, I'll give him that. He brought me ginger ale and tried to make small talk, but he was so nervous he mostly just stammered. It was kinda endearing, in a pathetic sort of way.

But he didn't really *get* it. He didn't understand the weight of the decision I was facing. He just wanted things to go back to normal, like we could pretend the pregnancy hadn't happened. Which, let's be real, was never going to happen.

As things got more serious, he started to pull away. He was scared, I think. He didn't know how to handle the situation, and he didn't want to be responsible. Which, honestly, I kinda understood. But it still hurt.

We had a few fights. I accused him of being selfish, and he accused me of being too stubborn. It wasn't pretty.

But then, towards the end, something shifted. He started to show up. He came with me to doctor's appointments, and he helped me pick out baby clothes. He even started to talk about the future, about how we could co-parent if I wanted to.

It wasn't a grand romantic gesture or anything. It was just… him being there. Being present. And it made a difference.

I realized that he wasn't a bad guy, he was just… a kid. A scared kid who was trying to do the right thing. And I was a scared kid too.

We didn't end up together, obviously. We were too different, and we wanted different things. But we ended up being friends. Sort of. We still talk sometimes, and he's always been supportive of my decision.

So, yeah. Our relationship changed a lot throughout the pregnancy. It went from awkward and uncertain to strained and angry to… something resembling respect and understanding. It wasn't the fairytale ending I might have imagined, but it was real. And that's what mattered. Plus, he's a pretty good guitar player. That's a bonus.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that* question. Seriously? It's the one thing people always ask. It's not like I named myself after a particularly obscure historical figure.

Okay, fine. I'll explain. It was my dad, actually. When I was born, he was really into Greek mythology. He said Juno was the goddess of marriage and childbirth, and that he wanted me to have a strong, powerful name.

He also said it sounded cool. Which, let's be real, was probably the main reason. My dad's a bit of a goofball.

I didn't really think much about it when I was little. It was just my name. But as I got older, I started to appreciate the irony. Juno, the goddess of marriage, and here I am, a pregnant teenager who's giving her baby up for adoption. It's kinda funny, in a dark, twisted sort of way.

Plus, it's a good conversation starter. People are always asking me about it. Which, honestly, I don't always appreciate. But it's a part of who I am.

So yeah. That's the story behind the name. It's a little bit nerdy, a little bit ironic, and a whole lot of my dad. And honestly, I wouldn't have it any other way. It's a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, there's always room for a little bit of mythology. And a little bit of sarcasm.

(Sighs, a small smile playing on her lips) Oh, man. That. That was… a moment.

Okay, so you gotta understand, I was kinda bracing myself for… I don't know. Disappointment? Concern? Vanessa and Mark are, like, *really* wanting this baby. And I was worried that seeing the ultrasound, seeing… *it*, would make them second-guess things. Like, maybe they'd realize I was too young, or too irresponsible, or just… not good enough.
