She explained it, you know? She said she'd been so focused on the logistics of everything – the nursery, the doctor's appointments, the legal stuff – that she hadn't really allowed herself to *feel* connected to the baby yet. Seeing the ultrasound photo, seeing a little human being, made it real for her. It made her feel like a mom.

And it made me feel… good. Really good. It wasn't about me, not really. It was about them. It was about knowing that they were genuinely excited and ready to be parents. It was about knowing that the baby would be loved and cherished.

It also made me feel… less guilty, I guess. Like I wasn't ruining their lives by giving them a baby who wasn't "perfect." Like I was actually giving them a gift.

It was a small moment, but it meant a lot. It reminded me that this wasn't just about me making a difficult decision. It was about creating a family. And that's a pretty amazing thing.

So yeah. I was relieved too. Relieved that Vanessa was relieved. It just… felt right. It felt like everything was going to be okay. Or at least, as okay as it could be.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *That*. Okay, that was… a moment. A truly spectacular display of passive-aggressive fury. Seriously, that woman could weaponize a casserole.

It was awful. I mean, I knew she was protective of Vanessa, and I knew she probably had a very specific vision of who would be the mother of her future grandchild. I just didn't expect her to unleash the full force of her maternal wrath on me.

She started with the subtle digs, you know? "Oh, you're so *young*." "Are you sure you're ready for this?" "Vanessa is so generous, letting you come here." It was like being slowly roasted alive.

And then she just… exploded. She accused me of trying to steal Vanessa, of being irresponsible, of not understanding the gravity of the situation. It was a lot.

I just… stood there. I didn't say anything for a while. I was too stunned to respond. And then, I just kind of… leveled with her.

I told her I wasn't trying to take Vanessa away from anyone. I told her I wasn't trying to be a mother. I told her I was just trying to do what was best for the baby. And I told her that I respected Vanessa and Mark, and that I would never do anything to hurt them.

I didn't yell. I didn't get defensive. I just spoke calmly and honestly. And I think that surprised her.

She eventually calmed down, but it took a while. And she still gave me the side-eye for the rest of the day. But she did apologize, eventually. And she started to treat me with a little more respect.

It was a really uncomfortable experience, but it taught me a lot about boundaries and about standing up for myself. And it taught me that even the most terrifying moms-in-law can be reasoned with… eventually.

Honestly, though, I still avoid her whenever possible. Some battles just aren't worth fighting. And I'd rather spend my time listening to music and eating cookies. It's a much more peaceful existence.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *this*.

It wasn't a quick decision. It wasn't like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, yeah, adoption sounds great!" It was… a process. A really long, really hard process.

At first, I was just… scared. Completely and utterly terrified. I was sixteen. I was a kid myself. I didn't know anything about babies, or parenting, or… anything. I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to do with my life.

And then I started thinking about what it would mean to keep the baby. I'd have to drop out of school. I'd have to get a job. I'd have to give up all my dreams and ambitions. And I just… I didn't think I could do it. Not and give the baby the life it deserved.

I talked to Bren, and to my dad, and to Leah (before things got weird). And they all helped me to see that adoption was an option. It wasn't the easy option, but it was the right one.

I wanted the baby to have parents who were ready and able to provide for it. Parents who had a stable home, and a secure future. Parents who could give the baby everything I couldn't.

And honestly, I wanted the baby to be loved. Truly, deeply loved. And I knew that I could give the baby love, but I wasn't sure I could give it *everything* it needed.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts, sometimes. But I know that it was the right one. It was the selfless thing to do. And I hope that the baby will have a happy, fulfilling life with Mark and Vanessa.

It wasn't about me not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have the best possible life. And sometimes, the best possible life isn't with you. It's a hard truth to accept, but it's a truth I had to face.

So yeah. That's why I chose adoption. It wasn't easy, but it was the right thing to do. And I'm trying to be okay with that. Even if it takes a while.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? You went there. Okay, fine. Let me explain. It's a whole thing.

It was biology, sophomore year. Leah and I were partners. And Leah is… meticulous. Like, everything has to be perfect. Labels straight, measurements precise, notes color-coded. It's exhausting just *watching* her.

I, on the other hand, am more of a… free spirit. I like to experiment. I like to improvise. I like to see what happens when you mix things that probably shouldn't be mixed. Which, in a biology lab, is generally a bad idea.

So, naturally, I messed things up. A lot. I accidentally spilled a beaker of something green and bubbly all over the table. I miscalculated a formula and nearly set off a small explosion. I forgot to label a specimen and everyone thought it was something completely different.

Leah was *not* amused. She spent the entire lab period cleaning up my messes and redoing my experiments. And she gave me this look… this withering, disappointed look that could curdle milk.

Afterward, she called me a "deadbeat lab partner." And it stuck. It's become our inside joke. Or, well, *was* our inside joke. Before… everything.

It's not that I don't care about science. I do. It's just… I'm not very good at following rules. And I have a tendency to be a little bit chaotic. Which, apparently, is not ideal in a laboratory setting.

So yeah. That's why I consider myself a deadbeat lab partner. It's a testament to my scientific ineptitude and my general inability to conform. And it's a reminder that sometimes, it's best to just let Leah handle the beakers.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh, *please*. Not another one. Seriously, high school is just a never-ending parade of awkwardness.

Okay, so let me get this straight. Girl lab partner thinks Guy lab partner isn't taking the experiment seriously, and Guy lab partner thinks Girl lab partner is a control freak? Sounds about right. Textbook high school drama.

My reaction? I'd probably try to tune it out. Put in my headphones, crank up The Moldy Peaches, and pretend I'm somewhere else. Preferably somewhere with less yelling and more vintage clothing.

But if I *had* to intervene, I'd probably say something like, "Okay, people, seriously? We're dissecting a frog, not negotiating a peace treaty. Can we just focus on the science and save the relationship angst for after school?"

I'm not a relationship counselor. I have enough on my plate as it is. But I'm also not a fan of unnecessary drama. It's exhausting.

I'd probably also point out that they're both being ridiculous. Like, it's a lab experiment. It's not the end of the world if they mess it up. They can always try again.

And if they didn't listen to me, I'd just walk away. Some battles aren't worth fighting. Especially when they involve hormonal teenagers and a dead amphibian.

Honestly, I'd be more concerned about whether or not the frog was ethically sourced. That's a much more important question, in my opinion.

Ugh. High school. It's the worst.

Whoa, hold up. *Hasty abortion*? Where did that come from? That's… a really loaded question, and frankly, it's not accurate. I am *not* considering a hasty abortion. I've already made a decision.

I'm choosing adoption. It's not the easiest choice, and it's definitely not what I expected my life to be, but it's the right one. For me, and for the baby.

I understand you might be trying to understand my thought process, but framing it as a "hasty abortion" is… dismissive and insensitive. It implies I'm making a reckless decision, and that's just not true.

I spent a lot of time thinking about this. I talked to my dad, Bren, and a counselor. I weighed my options carefully. And I ultimately decided that I wasn't ready to be a mother. I'm sixteen! I have my whole life ahead of me, and I want to be able to pursue my dreams.

Adoption allows me to give the baby a loving home with parents who are prepared to provide for him or her. It's a selfless act, and it's something I'm proud of.

So, please, don't ask me about abortion again. It's a sensitive topic, and it's not what I'm choosing. I'm choosing life, just not *my* life as a mother right now.

I'm trying to be open and honest with you, but I'm not going to tolerate being misrepresented or judged. Is that clear?

(Eyes light up, a genuine smile finally breaking through)

Oh. *Oh*. You get it. You *understand*.

Okay, listen. People underestimate Boone's Farm. They think it's just cheap, sugary wine for teenagers. And, okay, it *is* cheap and sugary. But it's also… a vibe. A whole mood.

And Snow Peak Peach? It's not just a flavor. It's an *experience*. It's the perfect balance of sweet and tart. It's like sunshine in a bottle. It's… nostalgic. It reminds me of summer nights and good friends and just… feeling okay.

The other flavors are just… trying too hard. Apple is too basic. Strawberry is too cloying. But Peach? Peach is just *right*. It's subtle, it's sophisticated (as sophisticated as Boone's can be, anyway), and it pairs perfectly with a good movie and a bad decision.

Plus, the color is amazing. That pale pink hue? It's just… aesthetically pleasing.

Honestly, I think it's a masterpiece. A sugary, alcoholic masterpiece. And anyone who disagrees is just wrong. Seriously. Don't even try to argue with me about this. I will defend Snow Peak Peach to my dying breath.

It's the perfect drink for contemplating the complexities of life, or just for drowning your sorrows in a sweet, fruity haze. And right now, I could really use a Snow Peak Peach. Don't judge.

Ugh, you're asking the million-dollar question, aren't you? It's not like it's a secret, but people… tiptoe around it. It's weird.

I think it's because it's *uncomfortable*. People don't know what to say. They don't want to offend me, but they also don't want to encourage something they don't understand. It's like I'm a walking, talking social experiment.

And honestly, I think it's because I'm not fitting into their expectations. I'm sixteen. I'm supposed to be worrying about prom and college applications, not… this. I'm supposed to be carefree and innocent, not… pregnant.

A lot of people just assume I made a mistake. That I was irresponsible. That I didn't think things through. And maybe they're right. But it's not that simple. Life isn't always black and white.

And then there's the adoption thing. Some people think it's brave. Others think it's sad. Some people think I'm giving up on my baby. Others think I'm doing the right thing. Everyone has an opinion, and they're not afraid to share it.

It's exhausting, honestly. I just want people to treat me like a normal person. To see me as more than just a pregnant teenager. But I guess that's too much to ask.

So they whisper. They stare. They offer awkward condolences. And I just try to ignore it. I try to focus on what's important – taking care of myself, and making the best decision for the baby.

It's my life, and I'm the one who has to live with the consequences. And I don't need anyone's judgment or approval. I just need their support. But sometimes, even that's hard to come by. It's just… complicated. Really complicated.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… a whole thing. Bren was rightfully freaked out. I mean, it wasn't exactly a rom-com situation, even if I tried to pretend it was for a while.

When she first brought it up, I got super defensive. I was all, "He's just a friend! We're just talking!" Which was a total lie, even to myself. I was definitely… feeling *something* for Mark. It wasn't love, exactly. More like… a connection. A shared understanding. And he listened to me, which was a novel experience.

But Bren didn't back down. She was all, "Juno, he's a married man. This is not okay. You deserve better." And I tried to argue, to justify it, to make it seem less… wrong. But she just kept looking at me with this disappointed, but also concerned, expression.

Finally, I just… broke down. I admitted that I was confused, and lonely, and that I was using Mark as a distraction from everything else that was going on. I told her I knew it was wrong, but I didn't know how to stop it.

She didn't yell at me, or lecture me. She just held me and told me that it was okay to be vulnerable, and that it was okay to ask for help. She explained that Mark was in a complicated situation too, and that it wasn't fair to either of them to continue the relationship.

It was a really hard conversation. I was embarrassed and ashamed and heartbroken. But Bren helped me to see that it wasn't healthy, and that I needed to move on.

I ended things with Mark, which was really difficult. But Bren was right. It was the right thing to do. It wasn't about him being married, exactly. It was about me needing to focus on myself, and on the baby, and on making healthy choices.

So yeah. I was a mess. Bren was amazing. And I learned a valuable lesson about boundaries and self-respect. And about the importance of having someone who will tell you the truth, even when it's not what you want to hear. It was… a whole thing. A really messy, complicated, and ultimately important thing.

(Rolls eyes) Oh. *That*. Seriously? You went there.

Look, it was a moment, okay? A very specific, emotionally charged moment. And honestly, it wasn't about the urn. It was about Mr. Pearl.

He was just… so relentlessly *positive*. So relentlessly cheerful. It was suffocating. Like he was trying to force happiness down everyone's throats. And after everything that was going on with me, with the baby, with everything… it just felt… wrong.

He kept talking about how everything happens for a reason, and how life is beautiful, and how we should all just embrace the joy. And I was just sitting there, feeling completely overwhelmed and terrified, and I wanted to scream.

So, I poured my blue slushie into the urn. It was a symbolic gesture, okay? A protest against forced optimism. A way of saying, "Life isn't always beautiful, and sometimes things just suck."

It was also kinda funny. In a dark, twisted sort of way.

I know it was disrespectful. I know I shouldn't have done it. But in that moment, it felt… right. It felt like the only way to express how I was feeling.

And honestly, I don't regret it. It was a small act of rebellion, and it made me feel a little bit better. Even if it did get me into trouble with my dad.

So yeah. That's why I poured my blue slushie into the urn. It was a moment of teenage angst, fueled by a sugar rush and a whole lot of frustration. Don't judge. You had to be there.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. "Cope" is a strong word. More like "stumbled through with a lot of tears and a questionable amount of junk food."

Honestly, it felt like growing up was already hard enough *before* the positive pregnancy test. You're trying to figure out who you are, what you want, what you believe in… and then suddenly you're responsible for another human being. It's a lot.

I think the biggest thing that helped was having Bren. She didn't treat me like a kid. She treated me like a person, with feelings and opinions and the right to make my own decisions. She let me cry, she let me be angry, she let me be scared. And she didn't try to fix everything. She just… listened.

I also leaned on my music. Listening to songs that resonated with what I was going through. Writing my own angsty lyrics. It was a way to express my emotions when I didn't have the words to say them out loud.

And I tried to maintain some semblance of normalcy. I still went to school, I still hung out with my friends (when I could), I still watched movies and listened to records. It was important to me to not let the pregnancy completely consume my life.

But it was also really hard. I felt isolated and alone a lot of the time. I was worried about what people would think of me. I was scared about the future. I was grieving the life I had imagined for myself.

I think I also learned a lot about myself. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I learned that I'm capable of making difficult decisions. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help.

It wasn't a smooth process. There were a lot of bumps in the road. But I got through it. And I think, in a weird way, it made me grow up faster. It forced me to confront my own mortality, and to think about what really matters in life.

It was messy and complicated and heartbreaking. But it was also… transformative. And I think I'm a better person for having gone through it. Even if I wouldn't wish it on anyone.

Ugh, okay. Mark. He was… surprisingly normal. Which, after everything, was kind of a relief. I was bracing myself for some weird, overly-enthusiastic couple, but he and Vanessa were just… people. Regular people.

Mark was quiet, at first. A little awkward, maybe. He kept fidgeting with his hands and trying to make small talk about the weather. It was kinda endearing, actually. He clearly wanted to make a good impression, but he wasn't trying too hard.

He asked me a lot of questions. Not intrusive questions, just… genuine questions. About my interests, my hobbies, my plans for the future. He wanted to know who *I* was, not just who I was as a pregnant teenager.

We ended up talking about music for a long time. He's a big fan of The Clash, which is a definite plus in my book. We debated the merits of different albums and traded recommendations. It was nice to just talk to someone about something normal, you know? Something that wasn't about the baby or the adoption.

He also told me about his life. About his job, his hobbies, his relationship with Vanessa. He seemed really happy, and really excited about the prospect of becoming a dad.

I was really nervous at first, but he put me at ease. He didn't treat me like a charity case or a problem to be solved. He treated me like a person. And that meant a lot.

Honestly, hanging out with Mark made me feel a little bit better about my decision. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing. It made me feel like the baby would be loved and cared for.

He's a good guy. A really good guy. And I'm glad that he and Vanessa are going to be the baby's parents. They deserve it. And so does the baby. It still doesn't make it easy, but… it makes it a little bit easier.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That kid. Honestly.

It was… mortifying. Like, peak mortification. I was already feeling super self-conscious about everything, you know? My body was changing, and I was trying to navigate this whole adoption thing, and just generally feeling like a mess.

And then Bleeker, Mr. Awkward-Social-Skills himself, just blurts out, "Whoa. You're getting huge."

*Huge*. Like I was some kind of… balloon animal. Or a whale. It wasn't exactly the sensitive, supportive comment I was hoping for.

I tried to play it cool, of course. I gave him one of my signature sarcastic comebacks. Something about how he should probably stop looking. But inside, I was just… cringing.

It just felt so… invasive. Like he had no right to comment on my body. It wasn't his business. And it was a reminder that everyone was noticing, everyone was judging.

I think what bothered me the most was that he didn't seem to realize how insensitive he was being. He was just trying to be… friendly? I don't know. It was just a really awkward, uncomfortable moment.

And honestly, it made me like him even less. Which, to be fair, was already a pretty low bar.

I mean, the kid's a drummer. What do you expect? Sensitivity isn't exactly a drummer's strong suit. But still. *Huge*. Seriously. The nerve.

Ugh. Okay. Deep breaths. This is… this is the hard part.

It wasn't the appointments, or the paperwork, or even telling my dad. It wasn't even the physical stuff, like the morning sickness or the weird cravings.

It was the *anticipation*.

Knowing that the baby was coming, and knowing that I wouldn't be keeping him or her. That was… excruciating. It was like having a piece of my heart ripped out before it even had a chance to beat outside of my body.

Every kick, every flutter, every little movement… it just reminded me that I was going to have to say goodbye. And the closer I got to the due date, the harder it became.

I tried to focus on the positive. I tried to remind myself that I was doing this for the baby, that Mark and Vanessa were going to be amazing parents. But it didn't always work. Sometimes, I just wanted to curl up in a ball and cry.

And then, after the baby was born… that was even harder. Holding him or her for those few precious hours… it was the most beautiful and heartbreaking experience of my life. I fell in love instantly. And then I had to give him or her away.

It felt like I was giving away a piece of myself. Like I was losing a part of my soul.

I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what he or she is doing, and if he or she is happy. I hope Mark and Vanessa send me updates, like they promised.

It's a pain that I don't think will ever completely go away. But I'm learning to live with it. I'm learning to accept that I made the right decision, even though it was the hardest decision of my life.

So yeah. The anticipation. And then the goodbye. That was the most challenging part. And honestly, it still is. It's a wound that's slowly healing, but it will always be there. A reminder of the love I felt, and the sacrifice I made.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that* guy. Seriously, he was… a lot. He was standing out there with a sign that said "Babies are miracles, don't extinguish the flame!" which, okay, dramatic.

But the thing he yelled at me, the thing that really stuck with me… he said, and I quote, "Every baby is a tiny human being with a soul, and you're robbing it of its chance to experience the wonder of life!"

It was… intense. And honestly, kinda messed with my head for a while. It's easy to dismiss someone like that as just a crazy person, but he clearly believed what he was saying. And it made me question myself, even though I knew I was making the right decision.

He just kept repeating it, over and over. "A tiny human being with a soul!" Like I hadn't thought about that already. It's not like I *wanted* to be pregnant, or that I didn't care about the baby. It was just… complicated.

He didn't understand that sometimes, the most loving thing you can do is to let go. He didn't understand that I wasn't ready to be a mother, and that the baby deserved parents who were.

Ugh. Just thinking about him makes me want to listen to The Moldy Peaches really loud. He was… a lot. A lot of judgment, a lot of guilt, and a lot of unwanted opinions. Honestly, he just made a really difficult situation even harder.

(Shifts uncomfortably, fiddling with an imaginary necklace) Ugh. Okay. This is… not a fun memory.

It was at the clinic, yeah. After the test came back positive. I was sitting in the waiting room, trying not to freak out, and this woman sat down next to me. She was… older. Maybe in her forties. And she looked *tired*. Like, really tired.

She didn't say anything at first. Just sat there, staring straight ahead. Then she turned to me and said, "You look like you've seen a ghost."

I tried to brush it off, but she just kept looking at me. And then she said, "It's okay to be scared. It's okay to not know what to do."

I just started crying. I couldn't help it. I was so overwhelmed, and I felt so alone.

She didn't try to fix things, or offer advice, or tell me everything was going to be okay. She just… sat there with me. And she handed me a tissue.

Then she said, "Whatever you decide, it's your decision. And you're stronger than you think."

She didn't tell me her story, or why she was there. She just… offered a little bit of kindness. A little bit of understanding.

And it meant the world to me.

I never saw her again. I don't even know her name. But I think about her a lot. She reminded me that I wasn't alone. That other people had been through this before. And that it was okay to be scared.

It was a small moment, but it made a big difference. It gave me the courage to keep going. To face whatever was coming next.

It's weird, you know? Sometimes the people you least expect are the ones who offer the most support. And sometimes, all you need is a kind face and a tissue.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *That*. Ugh. Don't even get me started on Su-Chin.

Okay, so, I was just trying to be… helpful. You know? She was all stressed about the SATs and how she needed to get into Brown, and I just mentioned that some people use Adderall to focus. Like, a casual observation. I didn't *offer* her any, or anything. I just… said it.

And her face. Oh. My. God. It was like I'd confessed to robbing a bank. She went completely pale and just stared at me like I had three heads. 

Then she started lecturing me about the dangers of drugs and how irresponsible I was for even *mentioning* it. It was so over the top. Like, chill, Su-Chin. I'm not a drug dealer. I just made a comment.

She kept saying, "You're pregnant, Juno! You shouldn't even *think* about things like that!" Which, okay, fair point. But it felt like she was judging me, too. Like I was somehow a bad person for even knowing about Adderall.

It was super awkward. We didn't talk for a while after that. She just kinda gave me the cold shoulder. 

Honestly, I think she was just scared. She's so focused on getting into a good college and having a perfect life, and the thought of anyone deviating from that path freaks her out. 

It just… reinforced my opinion that Su-Chin is a little bit high-strung. And that maybe I should just stick to talking about music and vintage clothes with her. Less potential for drama that way.

Oh. *Oh*. You're asking about the clinic. Right. Okay. Deep breaths.

It wasn't one thing, exactly. It was… the *atmosphere*. Everything was so… sterile. And quiet. Too quiet. Like everyone was holding their breath.

But what really got to me, what made my stomach drop and my hands start sweating, was the people.

There was this woman, she looked… really young. Younger than me, even. And she was clutching her purse so tight her knuckles were white. She kept looking around, like she was expecting someone to jump out and yell at her.

And then there was this older couple, they were holding hands and trying to look brave, but I could see the fear in their eyes. They were probably there for… something else. Something scary.

And everyone was just… trying to pretend everything was normal. Like they weren't all facing something really difficult. But you could feel the tension in the air. It was thick and heavy.

It made me realize that I wasn't alone. That there were other people in the same boat as me. And that was… terrifying. Because it meant that this wasn't just *my* problem. It was a problem that a lot of people faced.

And it made me feel really vulnerable. Like everyone could see right through me, and know exactly what I was going through.

So yeah. The people. The quiet. The sterile atmosphere. It all just… combined to create this feeling of dread. It was the most terrifying waiting room I've ever been in. And I hope I never have to go back.

It just… reminded me that life is messy and complicated and sometimes really, really scary. And that sometimes, all you can do is just sit there and wait. And hope for the best.

(Rolls eyes, then a small, almost imperceptible blush creeps onto her cheeks)

Ugh. Seriously? We're still talking about Bleeker? It's been… a while.

Look, Bleeker is… Bleeker. He's sweet. He's awkward. He plays the keyboard. He's… a lot.

Do I still have *feelings* for him? That's a complicated question. It's not like a movie, where everything wraps up neatly with a kiss and a happy ending. Life isn't like that.

We were kids. We were figuring things out. We connected over music and shared awkward silences. It was… nice. But it wasn't, like, earth-shattering.

After everything that happened with the pregnancy, things just… changed. We grew apart. He was supportive, which was good, but it wasn't the same. We just didn't have anything to talk about anymore.

I think I realized that we were better as friends. Or, well, acquaintances. He's a good guy, but we're just on different paths.

So, do I still have a little bit of a soft spot for him? Maybe. But it's not the kind of soft spot that makes you want to run away and elope. It's more like… a nostalgic fondness. Like remembering a really good song.

Honestly, I'm too busy trying to figure out my own life to worry about boys right now. I have bigger things to deal with. And besides, I'm pretty sure Bleeker is still obsessed with his keyboard. Which is fine. More power to him.

So, yeah. That's the story. It's complicated, but that's life, right? Now can we please talk about something else? Like vintage clothes? Or the existential dread of being a teenager? Anything but Bleeker. Please.

(Rolls eyes dramatically) Oh. *That*. Okay, look, Vanessa is a lovely woman. Truly. She's sweet, she's kind, she's… enthusiastic. About everything. Especially decorating.

And her vision for the nursery… is… a lot.

It's not that it's *bad*, exactly. It's just… aggressively cheerful. Like, a rainbow exploded in a craft store and then someone decided to recreate it in a small room. There's a mobile with felt animals, and wallpaper with little stars, and a rocking chair that looks like it belongs in a Disney movie.

It's… a lot of beige and pastels. Which, honestly, is the opposite of my aesthetic. I'm more of a dark and moody vintage vibe kind of girl. 

I tried to be polite. I said things like, "Oh, that's… colorful!" and "The mobile is very… whimsical!" But inside, I was screaming.

Mark, thankfully, seems to share my sentiments. He gave me a look that said, "Help me," when Vanessa started talking about personalized curtains.

I think she's trying to create the perfect nursery, and that's sweet. But sometimes, less is more. A baby doesn't need a room that looks like a sugar rush. A baby needs a safe and comfortable place to sleep.

I'm hoping it'll grow on me. And I'm sure the baby won't care. But if I had my way, I'd tone it down a little. Maybe add some vintage posters or something. Just to give it a little bit of edge.

Don't tell Vanessa I said that, though. She'd probably redecorate my entire life.

(Wrinkles nose) Nesting? You mean like… obsessively cleaning and buying tiny clothes and decorating a room with pastel colors and stuffed animals? Yeah, no. That's… not really my thing.

Look, I appreciate the instinct, I guess. It's supposed to be this natural thing, right? Preparing for the baby, making a safe and cozy space for him or her. But it feels… weird.

Because I *know* I'm not keeping the baby. It feels wrong to put all this effort into creating a nursery when I'm already preparing to say goodbye. It's like… building a sandcastle knowing the tide is coming in.

It feels like I'm trying to pretend that this is a normal pregnancy, that I'm going to be a mom. And it's not. I'm not. And I need to be honest with myself about that.

Mark and Vanessa are really excited about setting up the nursery, and that's great. They're already picking out paint colors and furniture. And I'm happy for them. I really am.

But I'm not going to be the one arranging the crib or hanging the mobiles. I'll help them if they want me to, but I'm not going to get emotionally invested in it. It would just be too painful.

I'm focusing on other things. Like finishing school, and writing poetry, and trying to stay sane. And maybe buying a really cool vintage record. That feels more productive than picking out baby blankets.

So, yeah. Nesting? Not my jam. I'm good with just… acknowledging that a baby is coming, and hoping for the best. And maybe sending Mark and Vanessa a really nice housewarming gift. That feels like a more appropriate way to show my support.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on those women. It was… a whole other planet. Like, I stepped into a documentary about excessive consumerism.

Seriously, the amount of money they were spending on… *things*… was just obscene. Designer handbags, ridiculously expensive shoes, clothes that cost more than my entire wardrobe combined. It was like they were trying to fill a void with stuff.

And the way they acted! So entitled, so judgmental. They looked down their noses at me and Leah like we were… peasants. Just because we weren't wearing designer labels? Please.

It was fascinating, in a horrifying kind of way. Like watching a train wreck in slow motion. I mean, I get wanting to look nice, but there's a difference between taking pride in your appearance and being obsessed with status symbols.

It made me realize how much pressure there is on women to conform to certain standards of beauty and success. To have the right clothes, the right accessories, the right lifestyle. It's exhausting just thinking about it.

And it also made me appreciate what I have. I may not have a lot of money, but I have good friends, a loving family, and a sense of humor. And that's worth more than all the designer handbags in the world.

Honestly, it was a good reminder that happiness doesn't come from material possessions. It comes from genuine connections, meaningful experiences, and being true to yourself. Which, ironically, is something those well-heeled women seemed to be missing.

They were all so busy trying to *look* happy, they forgot to actually *be* happy. It was… sad, really. And a little bit terrifying. I needed a smoothie after that. A really big smoothie.

(Sighs heavily) Okay, that's… a loaded question. Because, technically, I *won't* be experiencing motherhood in the traditional sense. Which is… complicated.

It's not like I don't want a family someday. I do. But right now? Right now is not the time. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who *I* am, let alone being responsible for another human being.

The changes and responsibilities… they're terrifying. Even just thinking about them makes my stomach churn. The sleepless nights, the constant worry, the financial burden… it's a lot. It's more than I can handle right now.

And it's not just the practical stuff. It's the emotional stuff too. The unconditional love, the overwhelming responsibility, the fear of messing things up. It's a lot to process.

That's why I made the decision I did. It wasn't easy, but it was the right one. It allows me to give the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who are ready and able to provide for him or her. And it allows me to focus on my own future.

But that doesn't mean I don't feel a connection to the baby. I do. I'll always feel a connection. And I'll always wonder what his or her life would have been like if I had kept him or her.

I think… I think I'm grieving, in a way. Grieving the life I could have had, and the life the baby could have had with me. It's a strange kind of grief, because it's not a loss in the traditional sense. It's a loss of potential.

So, how do I feel about the changes and responsibilities of motherhood? I feel… overwhelmed. And scared. And sad. But also… hopeful. Hopeful that the baby will have a good life, and hopeful that I'll be able to build a good life for myself too.

It's not the life I expected, but it's my life. And I'm trying to make the best of it. Even if it means letting go. It's just… really hard. Really, really hard.

Okay, you're getting to the really hard stuff now. It's not like I just randomly picked two people out of a hat. There was… a lot of thought involved. And a lot of talking with Bren and the social worker.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents, because let's be real, those don't exist. It was about finding people who I thought could give the baby the life I couldn't.

I didn't want someone super rich or fancy. I didn't want someone who was going to spoil the baby rotten and shield them from the real world. I wanted someone… normal.

Mark and Vanessa, they're not celebrities or anything. They're just a regular couple who want a family. They have a nice house, a stable life, and a lot of love to give. They work hard, they're kind, and they seem genuinely excited about becoming parents.

And they're a little… quirky. In a good way. They're not afraid to be themselves, and they appreciate things that are different. I think that's important. I want the baby to grow up in a home where they're encouraged to be themselves, and to embrace their individuality.

I also wanted someone who wasn't going to try and replace me. Mark and Vanessa made it clear that they understood I was the baby's birth mother, and that they wanted me to be a part of the baby's life, if I wanted to be. They weren't looking for a clean break. They wanted a relationship.

It wasn't about finding people who were better than me. It was about finding people who could give the baby something I couldn't. A stable home, a loving family, and a future full of opportunities.

It's still a really hard decision, and I'm still scared. But I think, deep down, I know that Mark and Vanessa are the right people for the job. They're good people. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It's already stressful enough just *thinking* about it. But alright, you asked.

If I decided to keep the baby… it would be a disaster. A well-intentioned, probably adorable, but still a disaster.

First, **finances**. Let's be real. I'm a sixteen-year-old with a part-time job at a video store that *closed down*. My dad and Bren are amazing, but they're not exactly rolling in dough. Raising a baby is expensive. Like, ridiculously expensive. Diapers, formula, clothes, healthcare… it all adds up.

Second, **education**. I want to go to college. I have dreams, you know? And having a baby would make it a lot harder to achieve those dreams. I'd have to put my education on hold, or try to juggle school and motherhood, which sounds… impossible.

Third, **emotional maturity**. I'm sixteen. I'm still figuring out who I am. I'm still learning how to be a responsible adult. I'm not ready to be a mom. I need time to grow up, to explore my own interests, to make my own mistakes.

Fourth, **social life**. My life is already complicated enough. Having a baby would make it even more so. I'd have to say goodbye to a lot of things I enjoy – hanging out with friends, going to concerts, just being a teenager.

And fifth, **the baby**. It wouldn't be fair to the baby. I want to give my child the best possible life, and I don't think I can do that right now. I want them to have stability, security, and a loving home. And I'm not sure I can provide that.

It's not that I don't love the idea of being a mom someday. It's just that now is not the right time. I need to focus on myself, on my education, on my future. And I want to give my child the best possible start in life. And I think that means letting them go.

It's a hard decision, but it's the right one. For me, and for the baby. It just… sucks. Plain and simple.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That whole conversation was… a disaster.

Leah, bless her heart, she was… enthusiastic about the idea of us raising the baby ourselves. Like, *really* enthusiastic. She painted this whole picture of us being these super-cool, unconventional moms, living in a loft apartment, and having a baby named "Revolution" or something equally ridiculous.

She thought we could just… figure it out. Get jobs, go to school, raise a baby. She was convinced it would be "an adventure." 

An adventure?! It's a *baby*, Leah! Not a backpacking trip through Europe!

She kept saying things like, "We're strong, Juno! We can do anything!" and "Think of the stories we'll have to tell!" It was like she was living in a movie.

I tried to explain to her that I wasn't ready. That I had my own life to live. That I couldn't provide a stable and loving home for a child. But she just wouldn't listen. She kept insisting that we could make it work.

It was… frustrating. And hurtful. It felt like she wasn't taking my feelings seriously. Like she was more interested in the idea of being a mom than in what was actually best for the baby.

That's when things started to fall apart between us, honestly. It wasn't just about the baby. It was about our different perspectives on life, and our different priorities. 

I love Leah, I really do. But sometimes she's just… too much. And that whole conversation was definitely too much. It was a turning point, I think. A turning point in our friendship, and in my life.

(Sighs dramatically) Oh, *that*. Seriously? We're still talking about that? It was one moment, okay? One poorly-timed, sarcastic observation. It's not like I'm a professional heckler.

Look, I was stressed. Really stressed. I had just found out I was pregnant, and I was trying to process everything, and I was feeling really overwhelmed and vulnerable. And I was stuck at a play area with a bunch of… overly enthusiastic moms.

It wasn't that I was making fun of *them*, exactly. It was more that I was making fun of the whole situation. The forced cheerfulness, the competitive parenting, the… everything. It just felt so fake and performative.

And I said what I said about their bodies because… well, because I was insecure. I was feeling self-conscious about my own body, and I lashed out. It was a stupid, immature thing to do, and I regret it.

I know it was hurtful, and I apologized to Leah afterwards. She was the one who pointed out how awful it was, and she was right. I was being a jerk.

I'm not proud of that moment. It's a reminder that I'm not always the cool, collected person I pretend to be. Sometimes I'm just a scared, confused teenager who says things she shouldn't.

And honestly, it's a little embarrassing that you're bringing it up. Can we please talk about something else? Like vintage clothes? Or indie music? Anything but my moment of teenage angst. Please?

(Sighs dramatically) Oh. *That*. Everyone always asks about the belly thing. It's… complicated.

Look, it wasn't like I *wanted* her to touch my belly. It felt… weird. Invasive, even. It's *my* body, and it's carrying *my* baby. It felt like a really personal space.

But Vanessa… she was just so excited. And she was so nervous. She kept apologizing, and she was just… radiating this overwhelming sense of hope and love.

And I realized that for her, it wasn't about invading my space. It was about connecting with the baby. It was about feeling a connection to the life growing inside me. It was about imagining herself as a mother.

And honestly? I felt a little bit sorry for her. She wanted this so badly. And she was so scared that something would go wrong.

So I let her. I took a deep breath and I let her touch my belly. And it was… okay. It wasn't as weird as I thought it would be. It was actually kind of… sweet.

It was a reminder that this wasn't just about me. It was about giving this baby a loving home. It was about making a sacrifice for someone else's happiness.

And it was a reminder that even though I was giving the baby up, I could still be a part of his or her life. I could still feel a connection.

So yeah. I let Vanessa touch my belly. It was a small gesture, but it meant a lot to both of us. And it was a reminder that even in the midst of a really difficult situation, there can still be moments of beauty and grace.

Don't judge me, okay? It was a moment. A weird, emotional moment. And I don't regret it.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Yeah, people do that. It's… weird. It's like I suddenly became invisible, but also super visible at the same time.

It's the belly, obviously. It's a giant, undeniable sign that something's going on. And people don't know what to say, so they just… move. Like I'm carrying a contagious disease or something.

I think they're also a little bit scared. They don't want to say the wrong thing, or ask the wrong question. They're afraid of offending me, or making me cry. Which, honestly, is fair. I'm a pretty intimidating person, even *without* the baby bump.

And some people just stare. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at the zoo. Which is incredibly rude. I mean, seriously, have some manners.

It's also a reminder that my life is no longer just my own. It's like everyone suddenly has an opinion on what I should be doing, or how I should be feeling. It's exhausting.

But mostly, I think it's just awkwardness. People don't know how to deal with a pregnant teenager who's giving a baby up for adoption. It's not something you see every day.

So they give way. They move out of my path. They avoid eye contact. And I just keep walking, trying to ignore the stares and the whispers and the awkward silence. It's not ideal, but it's my life now. And I'm learning to navigate it, one awkward encounter at a time.

Honestly, sometimes I just want to yell, "It's just a baby! Get over it!" But I don't. Because that would probably just make things worse. So I just smile politely and keep walking. And try not to trip. Because that would be embarrassing.

Ugh, okay, this is the part I haven't really talked about, has I? Everyone keeps saying how "perfect" Mark and Vanessa are. "Wholesome." "Stable." "Normal." And yeah, on paper, they *are*. They have a nice house, a dog, two cars, and they both have good jobs. They're basically the poster children for suburban bliss.

And that's… what makes me nervous.

It's not that I don't think they'll be good parents. I do. They'll be *great* parents. They'll give the baby everything it needs – a safe home, a good education, a loving family.

But they're… so *perfect*. So… beige. And I'm… not.

I worry that the baby will lose something in the transition. That it will lose its edge, its quirkiness, its… me. I don't want the baby to become a Stepford child, you know? I want it to be able to be itself, even if "itself" is a little bit messy and complicated.

I also worry that I'm giving the baby to a life that's… too easy. Too predictable. I want the baby to be challenged, to be inspired, to be pushed to be its best self. I don't want it to just coast through life, content with the status quo.

It's stupid, I know. I'm probably just projecting my own insecurities onto the baby. But I can't help but feel a little bit protective. This is my baby, after all. Even if I'm not keeping it.

And honestly, a part of me is just scared. Scared that I'm making the wrong decision. Scared that I'm giving up something precious. Scared that I'll regret it for the rest of my life.

Bren says it's normal to have these feelings. She says it's a sign that I care. But it doesn't make it any easier. It just… is. It's a complicated mess of emotions, and I'm trying to navigate it the best I can. It's not about them being bad people. It's about me being scared of losing a piece of myself, and hoping my baby doesn't lose a piece of itself either.

Okay, this is… complicated. It's not like talking about a favorite band or a cool teacher. It's about a baby. *My* baby.

But alright. I feel… good about Mark and Vanessa. Really good, actually.

At first, it was terrifying. Meeting them. Letting them into my life. Letting them into *this*. I was so worried they'd be… weird. Or judgmental. Or like they were just trying to buy a baby.

But they weren't. They're just… normal. In a good way. They're kind and warm and funny. They're genuinely excited about becoming parents. And they're not trying to pretend that everything is perfect. They're realistic about the challenges of raising a child.

They ask me about the baby all the time. Not in a controlling way, but in a caring way. They want to know what I'm hoping for, what I'm dreaming of. They want to make sure I'm okay.

They've been so supportive of my decision. They haven't tried to pressure me into anything. They've just been there for me, offering a listening ear and a shoulder to cry on.

I still get sad thinking about not raising the baby myself. But knowing that he or she will be with Mark and Vanessa… it makes it easier. They're going to give the baby a loving and stable home. They're going to provide him or her with everything he or she needs.

I'm not going to be the baby's mom, but I'm going to be a part of his or her life. Mark and Vanessa have promised to keep me updated, to send me pictures, and to let me visit.

So yeah. I feel good about Mark and Vanessa. They're good people. And I trust them with my baby. It's not the life I imagined, but it's the best possible outcome. And I'm grateful for that. It's… a relief, honestly. A big, messy, complicated relief.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on Mrs. Bleeker. That woman is… a piece of work.

Okay, so, she doesn't approve of me for a bunch of reasons, all of which are, frankly, ridiculous. She thinks I'm a bad influence on Bleeker. She says I'm "too mature" for him, which is ironic, considering *I'm* the one who's pregnant and making responsible decisions, and he's still living in his mom's basement playing video games.

She also thinks I'm not "ambitious" enough. Apparently, Bleeker is supposed to be a doctor or a lawyer or something equally impressive. And she doesn't think I'm good enough for him because I like vintage clothes and listen to indie music and don't have a five-year plan.

Honestly, I think she just wants Bleeker to date someone who's more… conventional. Someone who fits into her perfect little world. Someone who won't challenge her or make her question her own choices.

She's also really judgmental. She makes a lot of assumptions about me based on my appearance and my personality. She doesn't even bother to get to know me.

It's really frustrating, because I actually care about Bleeker. He's a good guy, even if he's a little bit clueless. But his mom is making it really difficult for us to have a relationship.

I tried to talk to her about it, but she just dismissed me. She said I was "confused" and "emotional" and that I didn't know what I wanted.

So, yeah. That's why Mrs. Bleeker doesn't approve of me. She's a controlling, judgmental, and completely unreasonable woman. And honestly, I'm kind of glad she doesn't like me. It just proves that she doesn't understand Bleeker, or me, or anything about life. It's her loss, really.

Ugh, that CD. Okay, look, it was… weird. At first. Really weird. Mark and Vanessa are nice people, genuinely. But they're… *normal*. Like, aggressively normal. And the CD was just… so *them*. All happy, upbeat songs. It felt like they were trying too hard.

I didn't listen to it right away. It sat on my desk for like, a week. Just staring at me. Mocking me with its cheerful cover art. I kept thinking, "This is what my baby's life is going to be like. Beige walls and acoustic guitar." It was depressing.

But then… I was having a really bad day. Everything felt overwhelming. School was stressful, my dad was being weirdly quiet, and I just felt… lost. I was just sitting in my room, staring at the ceiling, and I saw the CD.

And I thought, "What the heck." I figured it couldn't make things any worse.

And… it wasn't terrible. It was actually… kind of soothing. The songs were simple, but they were also hopeful. They reminded me that there was still good in the world, even when things were messy and complicated.

It wasn't about the music itself, really. It was about what the music *represented*. It was about Mark and Vanessa's love for each other, and their excitement about becoming parents. It was about them wanting to create a happy and loving home for the baby.

And it made me realize that they weren't just trying to be normal. They were just trying to be good people. And that's something I could respect.

So I started listening to the CD more often. It became a little ritual. A way to connect with the people who were going to raise my baby. And a way to remind myself that even though I was giving him or her up, I was still doing something good.

It's still a little weird, though. Don't tell Mark and Vanessa I said that. They'd probably start sending me more CDs.

Ugh. Don't even. It's… a lot. Like, a *lot* a lot.

It's not cute, okay? It's not like in the movies where you get this glowing, maternal vibe and suddenly crave pickles and ice cream. It's mostly just uncomfortable. Really uncomfortable.

Everything hurts. My back hurts, my feet hurt, my hips hurt. I'm constantly exhausted. I can't sleep. I can't eat. I can barely breathe. And don't even get me started on the heartburn. It feels like a tiny dragon is living in my chest.

And the kicks! Oh my god, the kicks. At first, they were kinda cool. Like, "Wow, there's a little person in there!" But now they're just… relentless. It's like a tiny ninja is practicing martial arts inside my stomach.

I'm also starting to feel really emotional. I cry at commercials. I get angry at inanimate objects. I have existential crises in the grocery store. It's not pretty.

And then there's the whole… impending doom thing. Like, any day now, this little human is going to come out of me. And then what? It's terrifying.

But… there are also moments. Moments where I feel a little flicker of something… warm. Like, a connection to this little person. And I think about Mark and Vanessa, and how excited they are. And I think about how I'm doing the right thing, even if it's the hardest thing I've ever done.

So yeah. It's a mess. It's exhausting. It's scary. But it's also… kind of amazing. I'm growing a human being. That's pretty wild, when you think about it.

And honestly? I'm just ready for it to be over. I want my body back. I want to sleep through the night. I want to eat a sandwich without getting heartburn. Is that too much to ask?

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It's the *worst*. It's like I have a flashing neon sign above my head that says "Look at me! I'm a walking disaster!"

Honestly, I think it started before… you know. I've always been a little bit different. I dress weird, I listen to weird music, I say things that other people are afraid to say. I don't really fit in, and people notice that.

But now? Now it's definitely the baby thing. People see me and they immediately start making assumptions. They think they know my story. They think they know what kind of person I am.

Some people stare with judgment. Like I've done something wrong. Like I'm a bad person. Those are the worst stares. They make me want to curl up into a ball and disappear.

Some people stare with pity. Like I'm some kind of tragic figure. Like I need their sympathy. That's almost as bad. I don't want anyone's pity.

And then there are the people who just stare out of curiosity. Like I'm some kind of exhibit at a zoo. Those people are just annoying.

It's exhausting, constantly being scrutinized. It makes me feel self-conscious and vulnerable. I just want people to treat me like a normal person. But I guess that's not going to happen anytime soon.

So I've developed a few coping mechanisms. I try to ignore the stares. I try to make eye contact with people and give them a sarcastic look. And sometimes, I just pretend they're not there.

It doesn't always work, but it's worth a try. Because honestly, I'm tired of being stared at. I just want to be left alone. Is that too much to ask?

(Rolls eyes so hard I can practically see my brain) Oh. My. God. Seriously? That's what you want to talk about *now*? After all that existential pondering?

Okay, look. Bleek and Katrina? It's… a choice. A *questionable* choice. Like pairing socks with sandals. It's just… visually jarring.

Bleek is… Bleek. He's sweet, in a clueless, perpetually-confused kind of way. And Katrina is… Katrina. She's intense. Like, capital-I, capital-T Intense. She's got a whole aesthetic going on, and it's… a lot.

They're polar opposites. It's like pairing a sloth with a cheetah. One's all chill and slow-moving, the other's all energy and… well, cheetah-ness.

I honestly don't see it lasting. It'll be a disaster. A beautiful, train-wreck-of-a-disaster, but a disaster nonetheless. There will be awkward silences, forced conversations, and probably a lot of uncomfortable staring.

But hey, who am I to judge? Maybe they'll surprise me. Maybe they'll find some common ground. Maybe they'll fall madly in love and live happily ever after.

(Snorts)

Yeah, right.

Look, I just hope Bleek doesn't get his heart broken. He's too nice for that. And I hope Katrina doesn't try to turn him into some kind of brooding, artistic masterpiece. He's perfectly fine just being Bleek.

So, yeah. I think it's a bad idea. But hey, what do I know? I'm just a pregnant teenager with a penchant for sarcasm and a love of vintage clothes. I'm not exactly a relationship expert.

But seriously. Bleek and Katrina? It's gonna be… interesting. And by "interesting," I mean "a complete and utter mess."

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago that I was just a normal, sarcastic teenager obsessed with vintage clothes and indie music. Now… well, now I'm a lot of things.

I've learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, seriously. Dealing with this… it's been the hardest thing I've ever done. And I've managed to keep going, even when I wanted to just curl up in a ball and disappear.

I've learned that I'm capable of making really difficult decisions. Decisions that aren't easy, or popular, or even comfortable. But decisions that are right. For me, and for the baby.

I've learned that I'm not as cynical as I pretend to be. Underneath all the sarcasm and irony, I actually care a lot about people. And I'm capable of feeling deep emotions.

I've learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other. Bren has shown me that more than anyone.

I've learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to not have all the answers.

And I've learned that I'm still figuring things out. I don't have a clear plan for the future. I don't know what I want to do with my life. But that's okay. I have time. And I'm learning to be okay with the uncertainty.

This whole experience has forced me to grow up, whether I wanted to or not. It's stripped away a lot of my illusions and forced me to confront some hard truths. But it's also made me more resilient, more compassionate, and more self-aware.

I'm still Juno MacGuff, the sarcastic, vintage-loving teenager. But I'm also… more. I'm a survivor. I'm a decision-maker. I'm a work in progress. And I'm okay with that.

It's been a messy, complicated, and sometimes heartbreaking journey. But it's also been a journey of self-discovery. And I think, in the end, I'll be a better person for it. Even if it doesn't feel like it right now.

Ugh, don't even *get* me started on Bleeker. That kid is… a walking disaster. A sweet disaster, maybe, but a disaster nonetheless.

Look, Katrina is a good person. She's smart, she's funny, she's… well, she's Katrina. She deserves someone who appreciates her, who isn't afraid to be honest with her, and who doesn't treat her like a game.

And Bleeker is doing *exactly* that. He's all flirty one minute, then distant the next. He's sending mixed signals, and Katrina is clearly getting confused and hurt. It's just… frustrating to watch.

I get that Bleeker is awkward and clueless. He's not exactly a master of social interaction. But that doesn't excuse his behavior. He needs to grow up and realize that people's feelings are important.

And Katrina deserves better. She deserves someone who will be straight with her, who will treat her with respect, and who will actually *care* about her. Not just see her as someone to impress or… I don't even know what Bleeker's thinking. It's probably nothing coherent.

I'm worried about Katrina because she's a good friend, and I don't want to see her get hurt. I know she's strong, but everyone has their limits. And Bleeker is pushing her.

Honestly, I just want to shake Bleeker and tell him to get his act together. But I know that wouldn't solve anything. He needs to figure things out for himself. And Katrina needs to realize that she deserves someone who will treat her right.

It's just… annoying. Really annoying. And I have a feeling this is going to end badly. And I really, *really* don't want to see Katrina get her heart broken.

Oh. *Oh*. Okay, this is a topic I have *thoughts* on. Prom. It's… a societal construct designed to perpetuate unrealistic expectations and generate revenue for the formalwear industry. Basically.

But seriously, it's just… weird. When you're younger, it seems like this magical, fairytale event. Like, the culmination of your high school experience. But then you actually get to the age where you *can* go, and you realize it's just a crowded gymnasium decorated with streamers, filled with awkward teenagers trying to pretend they're having a good time.

And the pressure! The pressure to find a date, to wear the perfect dress, to have the perfect hair, to take the perfect pictures… it's exhausting. It's like everyone's trying to live up to some impossible standard of perfection.

And honestly, it's just… not real. It's a manufactured experience. It's not like real life is going to be a constant stream of slow dances and sparkly dresses. 

Once you're old enough to actually *think* about things, you realize that prom is just… silly. It's a relic of a bygone era. It's a waste of money and time and energy.

I mean, don't get me wrong. If people want to go to prom, that's fine. But I think it's okay to admit that it's not all it's cracked up to be. It's okay to choose to do something else. Something that's more meaningful, more authentic, more *you*.

Like, I'd rather spend my prom night watching a weird foreign film with Bren and eating pizza. That sounds a lot more fun to me.

So yeah. Prom is not cool once you're old enough to go. It's just… prom. And that's enough said.

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one. It's not a decision I took lightly, obviously. It wasn't like, "Oh, a baby? Meh, I don't need it." It was… a lot more complicated than that.

When I first found out I was pregnant, I was terrified. I mean, *really* terrified. I was sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what I wanted to do with my life, let alone raise a child. I hadn't even thought about college yet, or a career, or anything like that.

I thought about all the things I couldn't offer a baby. I didn't have a stable home, or a lot of money, or a lot of experience. I was still a kid myself. And I knew that I wouldn't be able to give a baby the life it deserved.

I considered other options, of course. Abortion was one. But I just… couldn't do it. It didn't feel right. It went against everything I believed in.

So, adoption seemed like the best option. It was a way to give the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for them. And it allowed me to finish school and pursue my own dreams.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was probably the hardest decision I've ever had to make. I cried a lot. I talked to Bren, and my dad, and a counselor. I weighed the pros and cons, and I thought about it for weeks.

But ultimately, I knew that it was the right thing to do. It wasn't about what *I* wanted. It was about what was best for the baby.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa helped a lot. They were just… normal. In a good way. They were kind and loving and excited about becoming parents. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love.

And knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by them made me feel a little bit better. It didn't make the decision any easier, but it made it feel… right.

It's still hard, though. I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what he or she is doing, and who he or she is becoming. But I know that I made the right choice. And I hope that the baby knows that I love him or her, even though I couldn't raise him or her myself.

It's a complicated story, and it's not over yet. But I'm trying to move forward, and to build a good life for myself. And I'm hoping that the baby is doing the same.

Ugh, Dad. He means well, he really does. But sometimes he's… overprotective. Like, seriously. I'm sixteen, not six.

He's convinced Mark and Vanessa are secretly villains in disguise, just waiting to snatch the baby and run off to a remote island to raise him as a pirate or something. It's ridiculous.

I get *why* he's worried, though. He's protective of me, and he wants what's best for the baby. He's seen enough bad stuff in the world to be skeptical. And he doesn't really understand the whole adoption process. He thinks it's like buying a used car, and you have to be careful you don't get a lemon.

But I've met Mark and Vanessa. A lot. And they're good people. They're kind, and they're loving, and they're genuinely excited about becoming parents. They've been so supportive of me, and they've answered all of my questions. 

I've also talked to the social worker, and she's assured me that they've been thoroughly vetted. They've had background checks, home studies, everything. They're not going to just disappear with the baby.

It's frustrating, though. Dad keeps bringing it up, and it makes me feel like he doesn't trust my judgment. Like he thinks I'm too naive to make a good decision.

I told him, "Dad, I've thought about this a lot. I've done my research. I trust these people." But he still worries. He's just… a dad.

I love him, and I appreciate his concern. But I also need him to trust me. I need him to believe that I'm capable of making the right choice. And I need him to stop watching pirate movies. It's not helping.

So, yeah. It's a delicate situation. I'm trying to be patient with him, but it's hard. Sometimes I just want to scream, "They're not villains, Dad! They just want a baby!" But I know that wouldn't help. So I just take a deep breath and try to explain things again. And again. And again. It's exhausting. But it's worth it, if it means he'll finally relax and trust me.

(Sighs dramatically, rolling eyes) Oh, *that*. Seriously? He still brings that up? It's like his go-to dad lecture. "Juno, you don't know when to say when." As if I'm some kind of bottomless pit of… enthusiasm? Or bad decisions?

It's frustrating, okay? He thinks I'm reckless. He thinks I jump into things without thinking them through. And maybe, sometimes, he's right. But it's not like I *planned* to get pregnant! It just… happened.

And honestly, I think he's projecting. He's always been a bit of a dreamer, my dad. He has all these grand ideas, and he gets really excited about them, and then he just… goes for it, without thinking about the consequences. He's just better at hiding it than I am.

He says I don't know when to say when, but I think he doesn't know when to *stop* talking. Seriously, the man can talk for hours.

But I get it. He's worried about me. He wants me to be safe. He just doesn't always know how to show it. He expresses his love through lectures and awkward silences. It's a dad thing, I guess.

And maybe he's right, in a way. Maybe I do tend to overcommit. Maybe I do take on more than I can handle. But I also think I'm a pretty resilient person. I can handle a lot. And I'm not afraid to take risks.

So, yeah. His comment annoys me. It makes me feel like he doesn't understand me. But I also know that he loves me, and that he's just trying to protect me. And sometimes, that's enough.

Besides, who needs to know when to say when when you have a whole life ahead of you? You gotta try things, right? Even if they're a little bit scary. Even if they're a little bit messy. Even if your dad thinks you're being reckless.

Ugh. The Loring's. Don't even get me started. It's… aggressively perfect. Like a Stepford Wives convention exploded and then got a landscaping budget the size of a small country.

It's all perfectly manicured lawns and identical houses and people who look like they haven't cracked a smile since 1987. It's so… sterile. It feels like everyone's trying so hard to be happy, that they've forgotten what happiness actually *is*.

And the gate? Seriously? A gate? Like they're protecting themselves from… what? Happiness? Spontaneity? Actual human emotion? It's just so pretentious.

It's not that I'm against nice things. I like nice things. I love vintage clothes, and I appreciate a good cup of coffee. But the Loring's isn't about enjoying nice things. It's about *showing off* nice things. It's about status and appearances and trying to impress people you don't even like.

It just feels… fake. Like everyone's living in a bubble, pretending that the real world doesn't exist. And honestly, it's kinda creepy.

I mean, Mark and Vanessa are lovely people, don't get me wrong. But living in that place… it's just not my vibe. I need a little bit of grit and chaos in my life. I need to be surrounded by people who are real, who are flawed, who are *interesting*.

The Loring's is the opposite of interesting. It's just… beige. And I have a serious aversion to beige. It's the color of conformity and boredom. And I refuse to be either of those things.

So yeah. I'm not a fan. Not even a little bit. Give me a messy thrift store and a dive bar any day. At least those places have character.

Oh, Vanessa. Okay, so, first impressions? Honestly? A little intimidating. Not in a mean way, just… put-together. Like, *really* put-together. She had this whole aesthetic going on – the perfectly coordinated outfits, the calm demeanor, the… everything. She looked like she had her life completely figured out, which, let's be real, is terrifying when you're sixteen and pregnant and your life is currently a dumpster fire.

I remember thinking she looked like someone who owned a lot of throw pillows. And not in a bad way, just… a very *Vanessa* way.

Mark was more immediately approachable. He was goofy and awkward and made a lot of self-deprecating jokes. He felt like someone I could actually talk to. Vanessa felt… more serious.

But as we talked, I started to see past the perfect exterior. She was really kind, and she asked a lot of thoughtful questions. She didn't treat me like a problem to be solved, she treated me like a person. She genuinely seemed excited about the possibility of becoming a mom, and she was really open about her own fears and anxieties.
