It was a weird decision, I know. But it felt right. And sometimes, you just have to trust your gut. Even if it doesn't make any sense to anyone else.

(Eyes widen, a slight shudder runs through me)

Oh. My. God. Don't even *say* that. Seriously. That is the most horrifying thing I've ever heard. And I've seen a lot of horror movies.

Bren said the same thing, actually. She was all, "You know, if you don't get enough folic acid, the baby could come out… different." And I was like, "Different how?!" And she just gave me this look and said, "Let's just say… unsettling."

The thought of having a baby that looks like Paulie Bleeker… but, like, *wrong*… it keeps me up at night. It's bad enough that I'm pregnant. It's bad enough that I'm giving the baby up for adoption. But to have a baby that's… scary? That's a whole other level of nightmare fuel.

I mean, I like Paulie, okay? He's a good guy. But he's… quirky. And I don't want my baby to be quirky. I want my baby to be… normal. Or at least, not terrifying.

I'm taking all the vitamins Bren tells me to take. I'm eating healthy (mostly). I'm trying to avoid stress. I'm doing everything I can to prevent the "scary neuter-baby" from becoming a reality.

But honestly, I'm still terrified. What if it happens? What if I give birth to a tiny, unsettling version of Paulie Bleeker? I don't think I could handle it.

Just… please don't ever say that again. It's too much. Too much. I need a cookie. And maybe a therapy session. And definitely a very long nap.

Ugh. Bleeker. Okay, look, don't get me wrong. Paulie Bleeker is… a good guy. A *really* good guy. Like, genuinely kind and sweet and… well, Bleeker.

But describing our relationship is… complicated. It wasn't exactly a whirlwind romance, you know? It was more like a slow burn. A really, really slow burn.

We were friends first. We bonded over music, and bad movies, and just generally being awkward teenagers. He was always there, quietly supporting me, even when I was being a total mess. He didn't try to fix me, or change me, or tell me what to do. He just… accepted me for who I was.

And that was really nice. Especially because I wasn't exactly feeling accepted by a lot of other people at the time.

But it wasn't until after… everything… that I started to see him in a different light. I realized how much he meant to me. How much I appreciated his quiet strength and his unwavering loyalty.

He was the one who really understood what I was going through. He didn't judge me for my decision. He just held my hand and listened. And he made me laugh, even when I didn't want to.

It wasn't a perfect relationship. We had our ups and downs. We didn't always know what to say to each other. But we always had each other's backs.

I think what I loved about Bleeker was that he was just… real. He wasn't trying to be someone he wasn't. He was just Paulie Bleeker, the quiet, guitar-playing kid who always knew how to make me smile.

And honestly, that's enough for me. It's more than enough. He's a good egg. A really good egg. And I'm glad he's in my life. Even if he's a little bit… Bleeker-y.

Okay, this is… complicated. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, that's for sure. But it wasn't a disaster either. It was… messy. Like most things in my life.

My dad, Mac, was… quiet. He wasn't exactly thrilled when I told him, obviously. He just kinda stared at me for a long time, and then he asked if I was sure. He's not a big talker, you know? He shows his love through actions, not words. He started making me extra pancakes, and he drove me to all my appointments, and he just… was there. It wasn't what I expected, but it was enough.

Bren, my stepmom, was the real MVP. She was amazing. She didn't judge me, she didn't yell at me, she just… listened. She helped me research adoption, and she went with me to meetings, and she just held my hand when I needed it. She was the one who asked the hard questions, the ones I was too afraid to ask myself. She made me feel like I had options, and that I wasn't alone.

She also took a lot of the heat from my dad. He was worried about what people would think, and she shielded me from a lot of that. She was my advocate, my protector, my friend. I honestly don't know what I would have done without her.

My grandma, she was… well, she was my grandma. She made me knit a baby blanket, even though I told her I wasn't keeping the baby. She said it was "just in case." She also kept offering me weird herbal remedies for morning sickness. It was… endearing, in a slightly annoying way.

Leah… that was the hardest part. She was angry at first. She said I was being selfish, and that I was ruining my life. It hurt, a lot. We didn't talk for a while. Eventually, she came around, but things weren't ever quite the same.

So yeah. My family support was… a mixed bag. But overall, they were there for me. They didn't always understand, and they didn't always agree with my decisions, but they loved me. And that's what mattered. Bren especially. She was the one who held everything together. She's a pretty incredible woman. I'm lucky to have her.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a loaded question. It wasn't pretty, let me tell you. It felt like my whole world was tilting on its axis, and I was just trying to hold on for dear life.

The emotional vulnerability was the worst part. I'm usually pretty good at keeping my feelings bottled up, at being sarcastic and detached. But this… this was different. It was like someone had ripped open a hole in my chest and all my feelings were just spilling out. I cried a lot. Like, *a lot*. And I felt really, really lost.

The identity crisis was right up there with it. I mean, I was sixteen. I was still trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted to do with my life. And then suddenly I was pregnant. It felt like my future had been completely derailed. I didn't know who I was anymore. Was I still Juno, the music-loving, vintage-obsessed teenager? Or was I just… a mom? A failed mom?

I coped… badly, at first. I withdrew from my friends. I stopped doing the things I enjoyed. I just wanted to disappear. But Bren wouldn't let me. She kept pushing me to talk, to feel, to process my emotions.

I started writing poetry, like I told you. That helped. It was a way to get my feelings out without having to talk about them. I also started listening to music. Sad music, mostly. But it helped me to feel less alone.

And I talked to Bren. A lot. She didn't judge me, she didn't try to fix me, she just listened. And she reminded me that it was okay to be scared, it was okay to be sad, it was okay to be confused.

I also realized that my identity wasn't just about being a mom. It was about being Juno. And Juno was still Juno, even if she was pregnant. I still loved music, I still loved vintage clothes, I still loved being sarcastic. Those things didn't disappear just because I was having a baby.

It was a long process. And it's still ongoing, honestly. But I'm learning to accept myself, flaws and all. I'm learning to be kinder to myself. And I'm learning that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to ask for help. And it's okay to not have all the answers.

It wasn't easy, but I got through it. And I think, in a weird way, it made me stronger. It forced me to confront my fears and to grow as a person. And that's something I'm grateful for. Even if it was really, really hard.

Okay, *finally* a question I can answer with enthusiasm. This is important. This is crucial.

My favorite band is The Moldy Peaches. Hands down. No contest.

They're… weird. And quirky. And totally unapologetic. Adam Green's lyrics are hilarious and heartbreaking at the same time. They're not afraid to be vulnerable, or to be silly, or to be completely themselves.

Their music is just… real. It's not polished or pretentious. It's raw and honest and full of emotion. It feels like they're just singing their thoughts out loud, and it's incredibly refreshing.

I discovered them when I was going through a really rough patch, and their music just… got me. It made me feel less alone. It made me laugh when I wanted to cry. It reminded me that it's okay to be different, and that it's okay to be yourself.

"Anyone Else But You" is my anthem. Seriously. It's about wanting to be with someone, even if they're totally wrong for you. It's about the messiness of love and the absurdity of life. It's perfect.

I know they're not everyone's cup of tea. A lot of people think they're too weird or too lo-fi. But I don't care. They're my band. And they've helped me through a lot.

So yeah. The Moldy Peaches. If you haven't listened to them, you're missing out. Just… don't judge me for liking them, okay? They're a little bit dorky, but they're *my* dorky. And that's all that matters.

Challenging? That's like asking if breathing is challenging when you're drowning. It's… a colossal understatement.

It's like, I was already trying to figure out who I was *before* all this happened. You know? Trying to figure out what I liked, what I believed in, what I wanted to do with my life. And then BAM. Unexpected pregnancy. Suddenly, all those questions feel… smaller. Less important. But also, way more complicated.

Being a teenager is hard enough. You're supposed to be figuring out who you are, experimenting, making mistakes. But when you're pregnant, everything feels so… permanent. Like every decision you make has huge consequences.

And it's not just about the baby. It's about my relationship with my dad, with Bren, with Leah. It's about my future. It's about everything.

I feel like I'm being pulled in a million different directions. Everyone has an opinion on what I should do. Everyone thinks they know what's best for me. And it's hard to know what *I* want, what *I* need.

It's like I'm trying to build a house on a foundation of quicksand. Everything feels unstable and uncertain.

And honestly, it's terrifying. I'm scared of making the wrong decision. I'm scared of messing up. I'm scared of the future.

But I'm also trying to be brave. I'm trying to take things one day at a time. I'm trying to focus on what I can control. And I'm trying to remember that I'm not alone.

It's a mess. A really big, complicated mess. But I'm navigating it. And I'm learning a lot about myself along the way. Even if it's not the kind of learning I expected.

So yeah. It's challenging. Beyond challenging. But I'm still here. And I'm still trying. And that's all I can do.

Ugh. Okay, here we go. The big, emotional question. Brace yourself.

Before all this happened, I thought I knew what love was. Like, the romantic kind. You know, crushes and awkward first dates and all that jazz. It was all pretty superficial. It was about butterflies and wanting to impress someone.

But this… this was different. This wasn't about *wanting* something. It was about *having* something, even if it was something I couldn't keep. And realizing that the most loving thing I could do wasn't what *I* wanted, but what was best for the baby.

That was… a hard lesson. It forced me to look beyond my own feelings and consider the needs of another person. A person I hadn't even met yet.

And it made me realize that love isn't always about possession. It's about wanting the best for someone, even if that means letting them go. It's about sacrifice and selflessness and putting someone else's happiness before your own.

As for responsibility… I always thought responsibility was about doing what you're *supposed* to do. Following the rules. Getting good grades. But this showed me that responsibility is about taking ownership of your actions, even when they have unexpected consequences.

It's about facing the music, even when the music is really, really loud and unpleasant. It's about making difficult choices and living with the results. It's about being accountable for your own life, and for the lives of others.

This whole experience has made me see love and responsibility in a completely new light. They're not just abstract concepts anymore. They're real, tangible things that have shaped my life in profound ways.

It's still hard, you know? I still have moments of sadness and regret. But I also have moments of peace and hope. And I know that I made the right decision. And that, in the end, love and responsibility are about doing what's best for everyone involved. Even if it's the hardest thing you'll ever do.

And honestly? I think I'm a better person for it. A little bit more mature, a little bit more compassionate, and a whole lot more grateful for the people who have supported me along the way. It's been… a journey. A really messy, complicated, beautiful journey. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Well, maybe a lifetime supply of vintage dresses. But that's beside the point.

(A long pause. A very long pause.)

Okay. Wow. That's… that's a hard one. I've thought about that moment a lot. Replayed it in my head a million times.

It wasn't what I expected. Not at all. I thought I'd be overwhelmed with sadness, or regret, or… something dramatic. But it wasn't like that.

It was… quiet.

I mean, the room was noisy, with the nurses and the doctors, but inside, it was just… quiet. And this tiny little person was just… *there*. All scrunched up and red and perfect.

I didn't cry. I just… stared. I couldn't believe I'd made this little human. It was… surreal.

And I felt… protective. Immediately. Like, this tiny, fragile thing needed me, even though I was giving him away. It was a weird feeling. A really weird feeling.

I held him for a few minutes. Just skin to skin. And I talked to him. I told him his name, even though Mark and Vanessa hadn't officially decided yet. I told him I loved him. And I told him I was doing this because I wanted him to have a good life.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it also felt… right. Like I was doing the best thing I could for him.

And when I handed him to Vanessa… that was the hardest part. Seeing him in her arms, knowing that he wasn't mine anymore. But she looked so happy. And so did Mark. And I knew, in that moment, that I'd made the right decision.

It wasn't a happy moment, exactly. It was a bittersweet moment. A complicated moment. But it was a moment I'll never forget.

It was the moment I became a mother. And the moment I let go. And it was… okay. It just… was. It still is. It's just… a lot. A whole lot.

Ugh. Paulie. That's… complicated. Okay, look. It wasn't like I *didn't* want to tell him. It's just… I was terrified.

He was… is… a really good guy. Sweet, kind, a little clueless, but genuinely good. And I liked him. A lot. But he was also… still Paulie. He was still figuring things out, still kinda awkward, still living in his dad's basement.

And I was already messing up his life enough by just *being* pregnant. I didn't want to burden him with something so huge, so scary. I didn't want to ruin his senior year, or his chances of getting into college. He had plans, you know? And I didn't want to derail them.

I also didn't want him to feel obligated to stick around. Like he had to be a dad, even if he wasn't ready. I wanted him to be able to live his own life, to pursue his own dreams.

It was selfish, I know. But I was trying to protect him. And I was trying to protect myself. I was scared of his reaction. Scared that he'd be disgusted, or angry, or just… gone.

I thought if I handled everything myself, if I made the decision to give the baby up for adoption, it would be easier on him. It would be like… a clean break.

But it wasn't. It just made things more complicated. It created this distance between us, this unspoken tension. And I realized, too late, that he deserved to know. He deserved to be part of the decision.

I was wrong to keep it from him. It was a mistake. And I'm glad we eventually talked about it. It wasn't easy, but it was necessary.

It just… I was scared. And sometimes, when you're scared, you make bad decisions. It doesn't make it right, but it explains it. Does that make sense? It's still something I regret, honestly. But I'm trying to learn from it.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. That was… mortifying. Seriously.

Okay, so, the story. It's all Leah's fault, mostly. She's a blabbermouth, even if she doesn't mean to be.

She was at a party, and she'd had a little too much to drink – not a lot, but enough to loosen her tongue. And she started talking to Sean Pomery, who, as you know, is basically a walking gossip machine. 

And somehow, in the midst of a rambling conversation about vintage clothes and indie bands, she let slip that I was… "dealing with something." She didn't say "pregnant," exactly. But Sean Pomery is good at connecting the dots.

And then, of course, he told everyone. And Paulie, being Paulie, overheard it.

He confronted me about it later, and I tried to deny it, but he just looked at me with those sad puppy-dog eyes, and I knew he already knew. It was awful.

I was so mad at Leah. I mean, I love her, but she really messed up. But she felt terrible about it, and she apologized a million times.

And honestly, it wasn't the worst thing in the world. Paulie was actually really supportive. He didn't freak out or anything. He just… listened. And he offered to help.

It was a really awkward conversation, though. And I still cringe when I think about it. But hey, that's life, right? Messy and unpredictable and full of embarrassing moments.

So yeah. That's how Paulie found out. Thanks to Leah and Sean Pomery and the power of gossip. It's a truly terrifying thing.

Okay, this is the big one, isn't it? Everyone wants to know *why*. It's not a simple answer, and it took me a long time to figure it out myself.

It wasn't about what *I* wanted, not at first. It was about what was right. And what was right wasn't keeping the baby. I was sixteen, barely knowing what I wanted for *myself*, let alone a whole other person. I wasn't ready to be a mom. I wasn't financially stable, I was still in school, and honestly, I was terrified.

But abortion… that didn't sit right with me. I know it's a valid choice, and I respect anyone who makes that decision, but it just wasn't for me. It felt… wrong. I couldn't explain it, I just *knew*.

So, adoption felt like the only option that felt… okay. It felt like the most selfless thing I could do. It meant giving the baby a chance at a life I couldn't provide. A life with two loving parents who were ready and able to give him or her everything they needed.

Meeting Mark and Vanessa sealed it. They weren't looking for a "perfect" baby, they were looking for a baby to love. They were so kind and genuine, and they made me feel like they truly wanted this. It wasn't just about them getting a baby, it was about giving a baby a home.

It was still the hardest decision I've ever made. It still hurts, sometimes. But I know, deep down, that it was the right one. It wasn't about what I *wanted*, it was about what was best for the baby. And that's what mattered most.

It wasn't a heroic act, or a noble sacrifice. It was just… a responsible decision. A difficult, heartbreaking, but ultimately responsible decision. And I'm trying to be okay with that. I'm trying to believe that I did the right thing. And I'm trying to move forward, knowing that I gave that baby the best possible start in life. Even if it meant giving him or her up. It's complicated, okay? Really complicated.

(A long pause. Juno shifts uncomfortably.)

Ugh. Don't. Just… don't. That was… that was a really bad day. Actually, it was a really bad *week*.

It wasn't about him not wanting to be involved, exactly. It was… the way he said it. Like it was nothing. Like the baby was just… a consequence. A mistake. He kept talking about college and band practice and how his life was "finally getting somewhere." And I just… I just stood there, feeling like I was invisible.

I mean, I knew he wasn't exactly boyfriend material. He was Bleeker, for crying out loud. Sweet, but… clueless. But I thought, maybe, he'd at least *care*. About the baby. About *me*.

It wasn't about wanting him to be a father, not really. It was about wanting him to acknowledge that this was real. That this was a life. That this mattered.

When he said he didn't want to see it… it felt like he was dismissing everything. My feelings, the baby's future, everything. It felt like I was completely alone.

I think that was the moment I really realized that I had to do this on my own. That I couldn't rely on anyone else to make things better. I had to be strong enough to make the right decision, even if it meant doing it without him.

It hurt, okay? It really hurt. But it also… it also made me angry. And that anger gave me strength. It made me determined to find a good home for the baby, and to build a good life for myself.

I don't hate Bleeker. He's just… Bleeker. But that moment… that moment was a turning point. It made me realize that I had to rely on myself. And that sometimes, the people you expect to be there for you aren't. And that's okay. You just have to keep going.

(Juno looks away, fiddling with her hands.)

Can we talk about something else now? Please? That was… a lot.

(A long pause. I fidget with the hem of my imaginary sweater.)

Okay. That… that was a lot. It was… weird. And beautiful. And really, really hard.

I’d spent nine months… well, not *carrying* it exactly, but being… connected to this little person. And then suddenly, there she was. Tiny and perfect and… not mine.

And Vanessa… she was a mess. Seriously. Her hair was all over the place, she was wearing mismatched socks, and she had this goofy, exhausted grin on her face. She looked like she hadn’t slept in days.

And she was just… radiating happiness. Like she’d been waiting her whole life for this moment.

It was… jarring. Because I was feeling so many things at once. Sadness, relief, guilt, hope… it was a total emotional hurricane.

And seeing her, Vanessa, holding the baby… it was like watching someone else’s dream come true. A dream I’d helped make possible.

There was a moment, I remember, where our eyes met. And she just… smiled at me. A genuine, grateful smile. And I realized that she understood. She understood how hard this was for me. And she was so thankful.

It didn’t make the pain go away, not completely. But it made it… bearable. It made me feel like I’d made the right decision.

Because she looked like she was exactly where she was supposed to be. Holding her baby, surrounded by love. And that’s all I ever wanted for that little person.

It was… messy. It was disorganized. It was incredibly happy. And it was the hardest, most beautiful thing I’ve ever seen.

(I look away, blinking back tears.)

I still think about her. About them. I hope they’re happy. I really do. And I hope she gets all the mismatched socks and goofy grins she can handle. Because that’s what a good life looks like, right? A little bit messy, a little bit chaotic, and a whole lot of love.

Ugh. Don't even *start* with that song. It's… complicated. It's like, the soundtrack to a really awkward, slightly heartbreaking, and ultimately kinda sweet disaster.

"Anyone Else But You"… it wasn't just a song Bleeker liked to play on his guitar. It was *our* song, whether we wanted it to be or not. And that's the problem.

It started innocently enough. He played it for me one day after school, and I thought it was… okay. A little cheesy, maybe. But he was so earnest about it, and he looked so hopeful, and I didn't want to hurt his feelings. So I pretended to like it more than I did.

And then it just… escalated. He played it everywhere. At parties, in the car, even during study hall. It became this running joke, but it also felt… suffocating. Like he was trying to define our relationship with a three-minute pop song.

The song is about wanting someone so badly that you're willing to overlook all their flaws. And that's kinda how Bleeker felt about me. He saw me as this perfect, quirky girl, and he didn't want to see the messy, complicated reality.

And I… I liked that he liked me. I liked the attention. But I also felt like he didn't really *see* me. He saw the version of me he wanted to see.

So the song became a symbol of everything that was wrong with our relationship. It was a reminder that we weren't really connecting on a deeper level. It was a reminder that we were both pretending to be someone we weren't.

When we finally broke up, I was relieved. Not because I didn't care about Bleeker, but because I was tired of pretending. I was tired of being someone else's idea of perfect.

And honestly? I can't even listen to that song anymore without cringing. It's just… too much. It's a reminder of a time when I was trying to figure out who I was, and who I wanted to be. And it's a reminder that sometimes, the best thing you can do is let go. Even if it hurts. Especially if it hurts.

Ugh, don't even *start* with the baby shower. It's… complicated. It's not like I'm thrilled about the idea, honestly. It feels… weird. Like celebrating something that's inherently sad.

But I get why people are hesitant. It's not a typical baby shower situation, is it? Usually, baby showers are for people who are excited to become parents, who are planning to raise the baby themselves. I'm… not doing that.

I think people are afraid of saying the wrong thing. They don't want to hurt my feelings, but they also don't want to pretend that everything is okay. It's a really awkward tightrope walk.

And honestly, I think some people just don't understand why I'm doing this. They think I should be keeping the baby, or they think I'm making a mistake. They don't realize that this is the best decision for everyone involved.

Bren tried to explain it to Auntie Bev, but Auntie Bev just kept saying, "But it's a *baby*! You should be happy!" Which, yeah, babies are great. But this isn't about happiness. It's about doing what's right.

So, yeah. People are unsure about the baby shower because it's a weird situation. It's a celebration of something that's also a loss. And it's a reminder that I'm making a difficult decision. It's just… a lot.

I told Bren I didn't really *need* a baby shower. I'd rather just have a quiet dinner with my family and friends. But she said it's important for people to show their support. So, we'll see. I'm bracing myself for a lot of awkward small talk and forced smiles. It's going to be… an experience, to say the least.

Ugh, don't even *remind* me. That was… awkward. And Bren was *not* pleased.

Okay, so, it wasn't like I was having secret rendezvous with Mark and Vanessa or anything. They were just… nice. They wanted to get to know me, and they knew I liked movies and music. So they offered to let me borrow some stuff. It felt… friendly. Like we were bonding over shared interests.

But Bren saw it differently. She said it was inappropriate. That it blurred the lines between our relationship and their role as adoptive parents. She said it created a dynamic where I might feel obligated to them, or where they might feel like they were trying to "buy" my affection.

And honestly, I think she was right. I was so focused on trying to feel connected to them, on trying to make the whole situation feel less… weird, that I didn't stop to think about how it might look to other people. Or how it might make Bren feel.

She said it was important to maintain professional boundaries, even though we all liked each other. She said it was important for me to have space to process my feelings without feeling like I owed them anything.

I was mad at first. I thought she was being overprotective and controlling. But then I realized she was just trying to protect *me*. She was trying to make sure that I was making decisions for the right reasons, and that I wasn't being manipulated or taken advantage of.

It was a good lesson, I guess. A reminder that even when people are being nice, it doesn't mean they're always acting in your best interest. And that sometimes, you need to listen to the people who love you, even when you don't want to.

Plus, Bren makes a really good point. It *was* kinda weird. I just didn't see it at the time. I'm still learning, okay? Give me a break.

Ugh. Don't even *get* me started on my mom. She's… a free spirit. Which is a polite way of saying she's flighty and unreliable and has a serious commitment phobia.

She says I don't know anything about the dynamics of marriage because, well, I haven't *been* married. Which is technically true. But it's not like I've been living under a rock. I've observed people. I've seen how my dad and Bren interact. I've watched enough movies to know that marriage is complicated.

But she doesn't mean it literally, I think. It's more about… her own issues. She's been married and divorced a bunch of times. She's seen the dark side of relationships. She's convinced that marriage is a trap, and that anyone who gets married is a fool.

She thinks I'm naive and idealistic. She thinks I believe in fairy tales and happily ever afters. And she's probably right, to some extent. I do believe in love. I do believe that people can find happiness together.

But she's also projecting her own fears and insecurities onto me. She doesn't want me to make the same mistakes she did. She doesn't want me to get hurt.

It's frustrating, because she doesn't seem to understand that I'm not her. I'm not going to live my life the same way she did. I'm going to make my own choices, and I'm going to learn from my own mistakes.

And honestly, I think she's just scared. Scared of being alone. Scared of getting hurt again. Scared of facing her own demons.

So she tries to control me, to warn me, to protect me. But all she really does is push me away. It's a messed-up dynamic, and I wish she would just… let me live my own life. But that's my mom for you. Always complicated. Always unpredictable. And always, always judging.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment)

Okay. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it's some simple equation.

It wasn't one thing. It was a lot of things. A whole tangled mess of things.

First, I'm sixteen. Sixteen! I'm still figuring out what *I* want to eat for breakfast, let alone how to raise a human being. I'm not ready. I don't have the resources, the stability, the emotional maturity to give a baby the life it deserves.

And it wasn't about not wanting the baby. It was about wanting the baby to have *everything*. A loving home, financial security, parents who are fully prepared and excited to be parents. I could give a baby a birth, but I couldn't give it a life. Not the life it deserved.

I thought about what my mom would do. She'd probably run off to Nepal or something. And that's… not what I wanted. I wanted something stable, something good.

And then I met Mark and Vanessa. They were… perfect. They were kind, and warm, and they just radiated love. They wanted a baby so badly, and they were so excited about the prospect of becoming parents. I knew, when I met them, that they could give my baby a better life than I could.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. There are days when I question myself, when I wonder if I made the right choice. But then I think about Mark and Vanessa, and I think about the baby, and I know that I did.

It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby *up*. Giving it a chance at a good life. And that's something I can live with.

It's not a happy story, but it's my story. And it's the best decision I could have made, for everyone involved. Even if it breaks my heart a little bit every day.

Ugh. That's… a big question. It feels like a lifetime ago, even though it wasn't that long. I learned a *lot*. Mostly things I didn't want to know about myself.

I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty resilient, but this was a whole different level. Dealing with the pregnancy, the judgment, the adoption process… it was exhausting and terrifying. But I kept going. I didn't fall apart. And I'm really proud of that.

I learned that I'm capable of a lot more love than I realized. Even though I knew I couldn't keep the baby, I still felt a connection to it. I cared about it deeply. And that was… surprising. It made the decision even harder, but it also made me feel like a better person.

I learned that I'm not afraid to be vulnerable. I used to be so guarded, so afraid of letting people see who I really was. But this whole experience forced me to open up. To ask for help. To admit my fears. And it was… liberating.

I learned that I'm okay with not having all the answers. I used to think I had to have everything figured out. But life is messy and unpredictable. And sometimes, you just have to trust that things will work out, even if you don't know how.

And I learned that I'm not defined by my mistakes. I made a mistake, a big one. But it doesn't mean I'm a bad person. It just means I'm human. And I'm learning from it.

Honestly, it was a really transformative experience. It changed me in ways I never expected. I'm still figuring out who I am, but I feel like I'm on the right track. I'm more confident, more compassionate, and more resilient. And I'm grateful for that. Even if it came at a cost.

It was… a lot. But I wouldn't trade it. Not really. Because it made me who I am today. And I think, maybe, that's a good thing.

Ugh, okay, this is gonna get a little… emotional. Don't judge me if I get all sappy.

At first, it was… awkward. Really awkward. They were nice, obviously. Super nice. Almost *too* nice. Like they were trying too hard to be perfect. I was suspicious. I mean, who is *that* eager to adopt a baby? It felt… weird.

I kept my distance. I answered their questions, but I didn't really open up. I was scared to let them in, scared to get attached. I was already grieving the loss of my baby, and I didn't want to feel even worse.

But as we spent more time together, things started to change. We went to doctor's appointments together, and we talked about everything – my hopes for the baby, my fears, my dreams. They didn't judge me. They didn't try to fix me. They just… listened.

And I started to see them as people, not just potential parents. I saw their love for each other, their excitement about starting a family, their genuine desire to give a child a good life.

Vanessa started bringing me little gifts – books, CDs, a really comfy sweater. And Mark would always make me laugh with his terrible jokes. They were just… kind. And patient. And understanding.

Slowly, I started to trust them. I started to feel comfortable around them. I started to see them as friends.

By the end of the process, it wasn't just about giving them a baby. It was about giving them a piece of my heart. And it was about knowing that my baby would be loved and cared for by two amazing people.

It was still incredibly hard to say goodbye, of course. But knowing that they were going to be there for the baby, that they were going to give him or her everything I couldn't… that made it a little bit easier.

Our bond changed from being a formal arrangement to something… real. We still keep in touch. They send me pictures and updates, and I send them little notes. It's not the same as being a family, but it's something. And I'm grateful for it. They showed me that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and connection and support. And that's something I'll never forget.

(Long pause. She looks away, fiddling with the hem of her sleeve.)

Regrets… That's a loaded question. It's not like it's a simple yes or no.

There are definitely moments where I wonder "what if?" What if I had kept the baby? What if I had made a different decision? What if things had been different?

I regret getting into the situation in the first place, obviously. I wish I had been more careful. I wish I had thought things through more. But you can't change the past, right?

I regret the pain I caused my dad and Bren. They were so supportive, but I know it was hard for them too. I wish I hadn't put them through that.

And I regret the sadness I feel sometimes. It's a deep, aching sadness that I can't quite explain. It's not necessarily regret about the *decision* itself, but regret about the loss of something I never had.

But… do I regret choosing adoption? No. Not really.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made, and it still hurts sometimes. But I know it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby. Mark and Vanessa are wonderful people, and they're going to give that baby a life I couldn't have provided.

So, yeah. I have regrets. But they're not about the big picture. They're about the small things. The what-ifs and the could-have-beens. And I'm learning to live with them.

It's not about erasing the past. It's about accepting it, and moving forward. And trying to be a better person because of it.

It's… complicated. It's always complicated. But I'm okay. I think. Mostly. And that's all I can ask for, really.

Okay. That's… the big one, isn't it? It's not something I talk about a lot. It still feels… raw.

Okay. This is… important. If someone was listening, and they were in my shoes… I’d want to say a few things. And I’d want them to *really* listen.

First, **you are not alone.** I know it feels like it. I know it feels like the world is crashing down around you. But there are other girls who have been through this. There are people who understand. You don’t have to carry this burden by yourself.

Third, **you have options.** And you deserve to explore all of them. Don’t let anyone pressure you into making a decision you’re not comfortable with. Talk to your parents, your friends, a counselor, a doctor. Get all the information you can. And then, make the decision that’s right for *you*.

Fourth, **don’t let anyone shame you.** This is *your* body, *your* life, *your* decision. People are going to have opinions, but their opinions don’t matter. What matters is what you believe is right.

And finally, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation. You’re going to make mistakes. You’re going to have bad days. But you’re also going to be strong. You’re going to be resilient. And you’re going to get through this.

It’s not going to be easy. It’s going to be the hardest thing you’ve ever done. But you are capable of more than you think. And you deserve to be happy. Even if it doesn’t feel like it right now.

And please, please, *please* reach out for help. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Don’t be afraid to ask. You don’t have to do this alone.

Seriously. Don't. You're stronger than you think, but even the strongest people need a little help sometimes. And remember, this isn't the end of your story. It's just a chapter. And you get to write the rest of it.

Blogging? Oh, right. The whole "blog" thing. That was… Leah's idea. Mostly.

But Leah convinced me it could be… therapeutic. A way to process my feelings, to connect with other people who were going through similar things, to maybe even help someone else. She said it could be a way to take control of the narrative, instead of letting other people define it for me.

And, okay, maybe a tiny part of me thought it could be a way to prove everyone wrong. To show them that I wasn't just some irresponsible teenager. That I was making a thoughtful, difficult decision.

So, I started writing. At first, it was just for me. A way to vent my frustrations and explore my emotions. But then people started reading it. And commenting. And sharing their own stories.

It was… surprisingly empowering. To know that I wasn't alone. To hear from people who understood what I was going through. To be able to offer support and encouragement to others.

The blog became a space where I could be honest and vulnerable, without fear of judgment. It was a place where I could be myself, flaws and all.

It wasn't always easy, though. There were trolls, and haters, and people who just didn't understand. But Leah helped me to ignore them. She reminded me that the important thing was to stay true to myself and to focus on the positive.

So yeah. Leah inspired me to start blogging. And it turned out to be one of the best things I ever did. It helped me to navigate a really difficult time in my life, and it taught me a lot about myself. And it reminded me that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. And a surprisingly supportive online community. Who knew?

(Sighs) Okay. That's… a big question. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment. It was more like a slow, painful, and ultimately… enlightening process.

So yeah. Life is messy. And that's okay. It's not about avoiding the mess, it's about learning to navigate it. And that's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a pretty good lesson, actually. Even if it took a pregnancy to learn it.

Okay. Deep breath. This is… the big one, isn't it? If I could go back and talk to myself the day I found out… well, it would have been a long conversation. But here's what I'd tell someone else, facing the same thing:

First, **it's okay to freak out.** Seriously. It's a huge shock. You're allowed to cry, to scream, to feel completely overwhelmed. Don't try to be strong right away. Just let yourself feel what you're feeling.

Second, **don't make any rash decisions.** Take your time. You don't have to figure everything out right away. Give yourself space to process your emotions and consider your options.

Third, **talk to someone you trust.** A parent, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. You need support right now. You can't go through this alone.

Fourth, **explore all your options.** There are three main choices: parenting, adoption, and abortion. Each one has its own challenges and rewards. Do your research, talk to people who have been through it, and make the decision that's right for *you*.

Fifth, **don't let anyone pressure you.** This is *your* body, *your* life, and *your* decision. Don't let anyone tell you what you should do.

And finally, **remember that you're not alone.** There are millions of people who have been through this before you. You're not the first, and you won't be the last. There are resources available to help you, and there are people who care about you.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be scary. But you're stronger than you think. And you're going to get through this. Just remember to take care of yourself, to ask for help, and to trust your gut.

And if you need to talk, even to a sarcastic, cynical teenager who's been there, done that… well, I'm here. Just… don't expect a pep talk. I'm better at honesty than encouragement. But I'll listen. And I'll try to help. Because nobody should have to go through this alone.

Whoa. Okay. That… that actually makes my throat feel a little tight. It's weird to think about a "child" of mine, even though I know it's happening.

My ideal vision? It's not about them becoming a doctor or a lawyer or anything like that. It's not about them achieving some grand success.

It's about them being **happy**. Truly, genuinely happy.

I want them to find something they're passionate about, something that makes them excited to get out of bed in the morning. Whether it's music, or art, or science, or building robots, or rescuing stray animals… I don't care. I just want them to find something that makes their heart sing.

I want them to be **kind**. To treat others with respect and compassion. To stand up for what they believe in. To make the world a better place, even in small ways.

I want them to be **brave**. To take risks, to try new things, to not be afraid to fail. To learn from their mistakes and keep moving forward.

I want them to be **independent**. To think for themselves, to make their own decisions, to not be afraid to be different.

And I want them to know that they're **loved**. Unconditionally. No matter what.

I know Mark and Vanessa are going to give them all of those things. They're good people. They're going to be amazing parents.

It's going to be hard, letting go. But knowing that they're going to have a good life, a happy life… that's all I can ask for. That's my ideal vision. And I hope, with all my heart, that it comes true.

It's not the future I imagined for myself, but… maybe it's a good one. Maybe it's the best one. And maybe, just maybe, I'll get to see them grow up and become the amazing person I know they're going to be. Even if it's from a distance.

Ugh, okay. This is a big one. There are a *lot* of misconceptions. It's like people automatically assume you're… irresponsible, or unintelligent, or just generally a mess. Like we all just wandered into this situation without a thought in the world.

But the biggest misconception, the one that really gets under my skin, is that we don't *care*.

People think that because we're young, we don't love our babies. That we're just trying to get rid of them so we can go back to having fun. That we're selfish and immature.

That's just… not true.

It takes a *lot* of courage and selflessness to make a decision like adoption. It means putting the needs of your child before your own. It means acknowledging that you're not ready to be a parent, and making the difficult choice to give your baby a better life.

And it hurts. It hurts a lot. It's not something you do lightly. It's not something you do because you don't care. It's something you do *because* you care.

We're not all stereotypes. We're individuals. We have dreams and hopes and fears, just like everyone else. And we're capable of making difficult decisions, even when those decisions are heartbreaking.

So, yeah. The misconception that we don't care. That's the one I wish people would correct. We care deeply. Maybe even more than they realize. And we deserve to be treated with respect and understanding, not judgment and scorn. It's not a life choice anyone *wants* to make, and it takes a lot of strength to navigate. So cut us some slack, okay?

Okay. Here we go. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know *why*. Like it's a simple answer. It's not.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. That's what a lot of people assume, and it's just… wrong. I did want the baby. A lot. But wanting something doesn't automatically mean you can *give* it what it needs.

I was sixteen. Still am, technically. I was still figuring out who *I* was, let alone being responsible for another human being. I was in high school, and I had dreams. I wanted to go to college, maybe travel, maybe become a filmmaker. I knew I couldn't do all those things and be a good mom at the same time. It just wasn't realistic.

And I wanted the baby to have a good life. A stable life. A life with parents who were ready and able to provide for him or her. I knew I couldn't give the baby that. Not right now.

Mark and Vanessa… they were perfect. They were already a family, they had a beautiful home, and they were so excited to become parents. They were everything I wanted for the baby.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. There are days when I question myself, when I wonder if I made the right choice. But then I think about Mark and Vanessa, and I know that the baby is loved and cared for. And that makes me feel a little bit better.

It wasn't about giving up on the baby. It was about giving the baby a chance. A chance at a good life. A chance at a future. And that's what mattered most to me.

It wasn't easy. It still isn't. But it was the right thing to do. For everyone involved. And I'm trying to learn to live with that. It's a process. A really messy, complicated process. But I'm getting there. Slowly but surely.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn't it? It wasn't like picking out a pair of shoes. It was way more complicated than that.

Bren and I went through a whole agency, obviously. We looked at a *lot* of profiles. Lots of happy couples, lots of nice houses, lots of promises of a good life. It was overwhelming. They all seemed… perfect. And that was the problem. They felt… too perfect. Like they were trying too hard to be what they thought I wanted.

Then we met Vanessa and Mark. And it was different. They weren't trying to impress me. They were just… real. They talked about their lives, the good and the bad. They talked about their struggles with infertility, and their hopes for the future. They showed me pictures of their home, which wasn't fancy, but it was cozy and warm.

They asked me questions, not just about the baby, but about *me*. They wanted to know what I liked, what I was good at, what my dreams were. They didn't treat me like a problem to be solved, they treated me like a person.

And they didn't try to sugarcoat things. They were honest about the challenges of raising a child, and they were honest about their own fears and insecurities.

I remember one conversation, Vanessa was talking about how she was nervous about being a mom, and she said, "I just want to be a good mom. I want to give this baby everything they need." And it wasn't a grand, dramatic statement. It was just… honest.

And that's what sealed it for me. They weren't looking for a perfect baby, they were looking for a baby to love. And they weren't looking for a perfect mother, they were looking to be parents.

It wasn't an easy decision, and I cried a lot afterwards. But I knew, deep down, that I was making the right choice. I was giving my baby to a family who would love and cherish him or her, and who would give him or her the best possible life. And that's all I ever wanted.

It still hurts, sometimes. But knowing that he or she is with Vanessa and Mark… that makes it a little bit easier. They're good people. Really good people. And I trust them with my whole heart.

Oh. *Music*. Okay, now you're talking. Forget everything else, this is where I really shine. Music wasn't just something I *liked* during my teenage years, it *was* my teenage years. It was the soundtrack to everything.

It was my escape, first of all. When things got too overwhelming – and let's be real, things got overwhelming a *lot* – I'd just put on my headphones and disappear. It was like a shield against the world.

It was also how I connected with Leah. We'd spend hours making mixtapes for each other, discovering new bands, and arguing about who had the better taste (it was me, obviously). Music was our language.

I was really into indie stuff, you know? The Moldy Peaches, Belle & Sebastian, Death Cab for Cutie. Bands that were a little bit quirky and a little bit sad. They just… understood me. They understood what it felt like to be a teenager, to be confused and awkward and heartbroken.

I also loved oldies. Like, really old. My dad has a huge record collection, and I'd spend hours listening to stuff from the 50s and 60s. It was a way to connect with him, and it also just felt… timeless.

And when I was pregnant, music was even more important. It helped me to process my emotions, to cope with the stress, to feel less alone. I'd listen to sad songs when I was sad, and upbeat songs when I needed a pick-me-up. It was like a therapy session, but with better tunes.

I even started writing my own songs, though I'd never let anyone hear them. They were mostly just angsty teenage ramblings, but they helped me to make sense of everything.

So yeah. Music was everything. It was my friend, my confidante, my escape, my inspiration. It was the one constant in my life, and it helped me to get through some really tough times. I honestly don't know where I'd be without it. It's still a huge part of my life, and I can't imagine ever living without it. It's just… essential.

Ugh. The stigma. Yeah, that was… fun. Said no one ever. It was like suddenly everyone in Maplewood had an opinion on my uterus. And they weren't shy about sharing it.

Honestly, the first few weeks were the worst. The whispers in the hallways at school, the stares at the grocery store, the awkward silences when I ran into people I knew. It felt like everyone was judging me, like I'd committed some kind of terrible crime.

I tried to ignore it at first. I put on my headphones, kept my head down, and pretended it wasn't happening. But that only worked for so long. It's hard to ignore the feeling of being ostracized.

Then I started getting angry. Angry at everyone who was judging me, angry at the situation, angry at myself. I lashed out at people, I said things I didn't mean, and I generally made things worse.

But Bren helped me to see that getting angry wasn't helping anyone. She told me that people are going to judge, no matter what you do. And that the only thing I could control was how I reacted to it.

So I started to focus on the people who *did* support me. My dad, Bren, Leah (eventually), and a few close friends. I surrounded myself with people who loved me for who I was, not for what I'd done.

I also started to talk about it. I talked to my teachers, to the school counselor, to Mark and Vanessa. I realized that the more I talked about it, the less scary it felt. And the more I talked about it, the more I realized that I wasn't alone.

It wasn't easy. There were still days when I felt ashamed and embarrassed. But I learned to accept that I couldn't control what other people thought. All I could control was my own attitude and my own actions.

And honestly, I think it made me stronger. It forced me to confront my own prejudices and to develop a thicker skin. It taught me the importance of self-acceptance and the power of community.

So yeah. The stigma was awful. But I survived it. And I came out on the other side a little bit wiser, a little bit tougher, and a lot more grateful for the people who loved me. And I learned that sometimes, the best way to deal with judgment is to just ignore it and keep being yourself. Even if "yourself" is a pregnant teenager with a sarcastic sense of humor.

Okay. That's… that's the hardest question. It still feels raw, even now.

It was… complicated. A lot more complicated than I thought it would be. I knew it was the right decision, logically. I knew Mark and Vanessa were amazing people, and that they would give the baby a wonderful life. But knowing something and *feeling* something are two very different things.

When I held the baby for the first time… it was like everything changed. All the abstract thoughts and feelings suddenly became very real. It was a tiny, perfect human being, and I was… responsible for it. And then I had to give it away.

It was the hardest thing I've ever done. I cried. A lot. I felt like my heart was being ripped out of my chest. I questioned everything. Was I doing the right thing? Was I being selfish? Was I a terrible person?

But Mark and Vanessa were there. They were so supportive and understanding. They let me hold the baby for as long as I needed. They thanked me for giving them the greatest gift in the world. And they promised to keep me updated on the baby's life.

After I left the hospital, it was… empty. Really empty. I felt like a part of me was missing. I grieved. I mourned the life I could have had. But I also felt a sense of peace. I knew the baby was safe and loved. And I knew I had made the right decision.

It didn't magically fix everything, though. It took a long time to heal. I went to therapy. I talked to Bren. I wrote in my journal. And I slowly started to accept that this was my story.

I still think about the baby sometimes. I wonder what he or she is like. I hope he or she is happy. And I'm grateful to Mark and Vanessa for giving him or her a good life.

It wasn't easy. It was painful. But it was also… beautiful. It taught me a lot about love, and loss, and sacrifice. And it made me a stronger person.

It's a part of my life that I'll always carry with me. And even though it was hard, I wouldn't change it. Because it led me to where I am today. And I'm okay with that. I'm more than okay with that. It just… took a long time to get here.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. It was… not a picnic. It was more like a really uncomfortable, nausea-inducing, emotionally-charged obstacle course.

Physically, it was rough. The morning sickness was the worst. It wasn't just in the morning, either. It was all day, every day. I basically lived on ginger ale and saltine crackers for months. And the fatigue! I was constantly exhausted. I could sleep for twelve hours and still feel like I hadn't slept at all. My body was doing all this stuff without my permission, and it was just… weird.

And then there were the emotional changes. Oh boy. One minute I'd be fine, the next I'd be crying over a commercial for dish soap. My hormones were all over the place. I felt anxious, scared, confused, and just… overwhelmed. It was like my emotions were on a rollercoaster, and I couldn't get off.

I leaned on Bren a lot. She was amazing. She just let me cry, and she held me, and she told me it was okay to feel whatever I was feeling. She also made me eat healthy food, which I didn't always appreciate at the time, but I'm grateful for now.

I also started journaling. Writing down my thoughts and feelings helped me to process everything. It was like getting it all out of my head and onto paper.

And I listened to music. A lot of music. It was a way to escape, to feel something other than sadness and anxiety.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I just wanted to curl up in a ball and disappear. But I kept going. I kept reminding myself that it wouldn't last forever. And I kept focusing on the future, on the possibility of a better life for the baby, and for myself.

It was a really challenging time, but it also taught me a lot about myself. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. Even if it's just a tiny little flicker.

Okay. That's… a really direct question. And it's not something I talk about a lot. It's… personal.

I didn't *have* an abortion. I considered it. Seriously considered it. For a long time. And that's where things got complicated.

It wasn't about being "pro-life" or "pro-choice." It wasn't about politics. It was about… me. And what felt right. And what felt wrong.

I talked to Bren, and to a counselor, and to Leah (before… things changed). And I realized that abortion wasn't something I could do. It wasn't a judgment thing, it just… didn't sit right with me. It felt like… ending something that had already begun.

But going through that process, of really thinking about it, of weighing my options, it made me realize how important it is for *everyone* to have those options. To have the freedom to choose what's best for their own bodies and their own lives.

I met girls who *did* choose abortion, and they had their reasons. And I met girls who chose to carry their pregnancies to term, and they had their reasons too. And I realized that there's no one-size-fits-all answer. There's no right or wrong choice. There's just… what's right for *that* person.

So, my experience didn't make me more "pro-life" or "pro-choice." It made me more… pro-choice in the truest sense of the word. It made me believe that everyone deserves the right to make their own decisions about their own bodies, without judgment or interference.

It made me realize that reproductive rights aren't just about abortion. They're about access to contraception, to prenatal care, to affordable healthcare. They're about empowering women to control their own destinies.

It's a really complex issue, and I don't pretend to have all the answers. But I do know that everyone deserves to be treated with respect and dignity, and to have the freedom to make their own choices. And that's something I'll always believe in.

It's… a lot to think about. And it's not something I enjoy talking about. But it's important. And I wanted to be honest with you.

Okay, "overcome" is a strong word. I'm still kinda terrified, if I'm being honest. It's not like the fear just magically disappeared. It's more like… I learned to live with it. And to push through it.

The biggest fear, obviously, was messing everything up. Like, being a terrible mother, or making the wrong decision about the adoption, or just… ruining my life. It was paralyzing.

What helped? A lot of things, actually.

First, Bren. She was amazing. She didn't try to tell me what to do, she just listened. And she reminded me that I was strong enough to handle whatever came my way. She helped me break down the problem into smaller, more manageable pieces.

Second, talking to Mark and Vanessa. Seeing how excited they were to become parents, and how much they wanted a baby, made me feel a little bit better about my decision. It helped me to see that I was giving the baby a chance at a good life.

Third, writing poetry. It sounds cheesy, I know, but it was a way for me to process my emotions and make sense of everything. It helped me to confront my fears and to find a little bit of peace.

And fourth, just… taking things one day at a time. I didn't try to think too far ahead. I just focused on getting through the next hour, or the next day. It was exhausting, but it was also effective.

I also realized that it was okay to be scared. It was okay to be vulnerable. It was okay to ask for help. I didn't have to be perfect. I just had to be real.

And honestly, a little bit of sarcasm helped too. It's my way of coping with stress and making light of difficult situations.

So yeah. Bren, Mark and Vanessa, poetry, one day at a time, and a healthy dose of sarcasm. That's how I "overcame" my fears. It wasn't easy, and it wasn't pretty, but it worked. And I'm still working on it. Because fear is always going to be there, lurking in the background. But I'm learning to live with it. And to not let it control me.

Okay, we're back to *that* again, huh? It's not like I woke up one morning and thought, "Oh, adoption! That sounds fun!" It was… a process. A really hard process.

Honestly, the biggest inspiration was just being realistic. I was sixteen. Sixteen! I was still trying to figure out what *I* wanted to be when I grew up, let alone being responsible for another human being. I was good at school, yeah, but I was also… kinda flaky. I liked to sleep in, and I liked to hang out with my friends, and I liked to listen to music. I wasn't exactly ready to trade all that for diapers and sleepless nights.

And it wasn't just about me. It was about the baby. I wanted that baby to have everything – a stable home, loving parents, financial security. Things I couldn't provide at that point in my life. I didn't want to bring a child into the world and then not be able to give them the best possible start. That felt… selfish.

When I met Mark and Vanessa, it just… clicked. They were so excited, so prepared, so genuinely loving. They talked about wanting a family for so long, and they had a beautiful home and a stable life. I could see that they would be amazing parents.

It wasn't easy, letting go. It still isn't easy. But knowing that the baby would be loved and cared for by them… that made it a little bit easier. It made me feel like I was doing the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

It wasn't about finding the "perfect" parents. It was about finding parents who were a good fit for the baby. And Mark and Vanessa were. They were.

So, yeah. Realism, responsibility, and a whole lot of hope. That's what inspired me to choose adoption. It wasn't a perfect solution, but it was the best one. For everyone involved. And I still believe that. Even now.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. That's… a whole mess of feelings right there. It's like poking a bear with a really long stick.

Let's start with Leah. That's the harder one. We were inseparable. Like, peanut butter and jelly, Batman and Robin, you get the picture. We told each other everything. We dreamed about the future together. And then… I got pregnant.

And everything changed. She was… supportive, at first. But then she started acting weird. Distant. Like I'd done something wrong. And then she started making these little comments, like, "You always were dramatic," and "You always had to be different." It was like she was blaming me for ruining our friendship.

I tried to talk to her, but she just shut me down. She said she needed space. And then she started hanging out with other people. It was… devastating. I still miss her. I miss our inside jokes, our late-night talks, our ridiculous adventures. But I also feel angry. And hurt. And betrayed.

I think she was scared. Scared of what this meant for our future. Scared of being left behind. And maybe she was a little bit jealous. I don't know. But whatever the reason, she's not the same Leah anymore. And I don't know if we'll ever be close again. It sucks. It really, really sucks.

And then there's Paulie. Oh, Paulie. He's… Paulie. Sweet, clueless, and completely overwhelmed. He was excited at first, which was nice. But then he quickly realized what this meant, and he kind of… checked out. He wanted me to just "take care of it," whatever that meant.

He's not a bad guy, he's just… immature. He's not ready to be a father. And honestly, I don't think he ever will be. He's still figuring out who *he* is, let alone how to raise a child.

We don't really have a relationship anymore. We talk occasionally, mostly about practical stuff. Like, who's going to pay for what. But there's no emotional connection. No intimacy. No future.

It's sad, but I'm okay with it. I don't need him in my life. I don't need someone who's going to abandon me when things get tough. I'm better off without him.

So yeah. Those are my relationship dynamics. Messy, complicated, and a little bit heartbreaking. But that's life, right? It's not always pretty. And sometimes, the people you love the most are the ones who hurt you the most. It just… is what it is.

(A long, exasperated sigh) Oh. Here we go. The question everyone wants to ask. The one that makes me want to roll my eyes so hard they get stuck.

Okay, look. I didn't *decide* to become a teenage mother. That's… a really loaded way of phrasing it. It wasn't like I sat down one day and thought, "You know what would be a fun life choice? Pregnancy."

It just… happened.

Paulie Bleeker and I… we weren't exactly careful. It was a moment of… teenage stupidity, honestly. A lapse in judgment. A really, really big lapse in judgment.

I'm not trying to make excuses. I take responsibility for my actions. But it wasn't a conscious decision. It was an accident. A really inconvenient, life-altering accident.

And then, once I found out I was pregnant, I had to make a decision. And that wasn't about *wanting* to be a mother. It was about what was best for everyone involved. For me, for the baby, for Paulie.

It wasn't a glamorous choice, or a romantic one. It was a practical one. A difficult one. And it's something I'll probably be dealing with for a long time.

So, to answer your question, I didn't *decide* to become a teenage mother. Life decided for me. And then I had to figure out how to deal with it. And honestly, it's been the hardest thing I've ever done.

Can we please talk about something else now? Like, vintage clothes? Or the merits of vinyl versus digital music? Anything but this. Please.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, looking down at her hands.)

That's… a loaded question. And honestly? It's something I think about a lot. Not every day, but… it comes up. Especially around birthdays. Or holidays. You know, the milestones.

Regret isn't exactly the right word. It's more like… a sadness. A quiet ache. A wondering. Wondering what life would be like if I'd made a different choice. Wondering what he or she – and I know it's a he now, Mark and Vanessa told me – would be like.

There are moments, yeah, where I think, "What if?" What if I'd kept him? What if I'd figured it out? What if I hadn't been so scared?

But then I remember why I made the decision I did. I remember how young I was, how unprepared I was. I remember how much Mark and Vanessa wanted a child, and how much love they had to give. 

And I remember the letters they send. Pictures. They tell me about his first steps, his first words, his favorite toys. They tell me he's happy. And that… that makes it okay.

It doesn't erase the sadness, but it makes it bearable. It reminds me that I did the right thing, even if it was the hardest thing.

So, do I regret it? No. Not really. I miss him, of course. I always will. But I also know that he's loved and cared for, and that he has a good life. And that's all I ever wanted for him.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's not a simple answer. But that's life, right? It rarely is. And I'm learning to accept that. To accept the sadness, the regret, and the joy, all at the same time. It's not easy, but it's… okay. It just is.

Ugh, don't even *ask*. It was… a feat of sheer willpower and a frankly alarming amount of caffeine. And Bren. Seriously, Bren was a lifesaver.

Okay, so, first of all, Maplewood High was surprisingly accommodating. Once they realized I wasn't just ditching class to hang out at the mall, they actually tried to help. I got extra time on assignments, and they let me leave early for doctor's appointments.

But it was still hard. Really hard. Morning sickness made it difficult to concentrate, and I was constantly exhausted. And then there was the emotional stuff. Dealing with the pregnancy, the adoption plan, the judgment from other people… it was a lot to handle.

I had to be really organized. I made a schedule and stuck to it as much as possible. I broke down my assignments into smaller tasks, and I rewarded myself for completing them.

I also leaned heavily on my friends. Leah, before… things got weird. And a few other people who were really supportive. They helped me to stay motivated and to remember that I wasn't alone.

And Bren. Oh, Bren. She drove me to school, she made me dinner, she listened to me cry, she helped me with my homework. She basically kept me alive.

I also had to learn to say no. I couldn't do everything. I had to prioritize my health and my education. And that meant saying no to parties, and social events, and anything else that might distract me from my goals.

It wasn't glamorous. It wasn't easy. And there were definitely days when I wanted to just give up. But I didn't. I kept going. Because I knew that finishing high school was important. It was a step towards a better future.

And honestly, it was a little bit of spite. I wanted to prove to everyone who doubted me that I could do it. That I wasn't just some teenage statistic. That I was capable of achieving my goals, even in the face of adversity.

So yeah. Caffeine, organization, supportive friends, and a whole lot of stubbornness. That's how I did it. And I'm really proud of myself for finishing. It was one of the hardest things I've ever done. But it was also one of the most rewarding.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know this. It's not a simple answer, and it's not something I talk about easily.

It wasn't a moral thing, not exactly. I'm not super religious or anything. And I don't think anyone should be judged for their choices about their body. That's their business, and nobody else's.

It was more… a feeling. A gut feeling. I went to the clinic, I sat in the waiting room, and I just… couldn't do it. It felt wrong. Like I was ending something that hadn't even had a chance to begin.

I know that sounds vague and maybe even a little silly. But it's the truth. It wasn't a logical decision, it was an emotional one.

And honestly, I think a part of me wanted to experience being pregnant. It was weird, and scary, and uncomfortable, but it was also… amazing. I felt connected to this little person growing inside me. And I wanted to give that person a chance at life.

I also thought about my mom. She always talked about how important it was to follow your heart. And in that moment, my heart was telling me to choose adoption.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But I knew that I couldn't raise a baby right now. I wasn't ready. And I wanted to give the baby a life that I couldn't provide.

So I chose adoption. And I don't regret it. It's still sad, and it still hurts, but I know that I made the right decision. For everyone involved.

It's just… complicated. And it's something I'm still processing. But I'm okay. I'm getting there. And I'm learning to be okay with the fact that sometimes, the hardest choices are the best ones. Even if they don't feel like it at the time.

Okay, that's a good question. A *real* question. Not one of those "what's your five-year plan" kinda things.

And yeah. Absolutely. A thousand times yes.

Honestly, the whole idea that a "traditional" family – mom, dad, 2.5 kids, white picket fence – is the *only* way to raise a happy, healthy kid is… kinda ridiculous. It's like saying a painting has to be done with only blue paint to be beautiful. It's just not true.

What a kid really needs isn't a specific gender combination of parents, or a certain kind of house, or a particular income level. What a kid needs is **love**. And stability. And support. And someone who's going to be there for them, no matter what.

Mark and Vanessa, the couple who are adopting the baby… they're amazing. They're kind, and patient, and they're so excited to become parents. They're going to give that baby a loving home, and that's what matters. It doesn't matter that they're a couple, or that they don't have any biological children.

And single parents can be incredible parents too. It's not easy, but it's possible. And same-sex couples? They're just as capable of raising a child as anyone else.

I mean, look at my own family. My mom wasn't around much, and my dad and Bren are a blended family. It wasn't always perfect, but we made it work. And I turned out… okay. Mostly.

The important thing is that the child feels loved and safe and supported. It doesn't matter what the family looks like. It matters what the family *is*. And if a non-traditional family can provide that, then absolutely, a child can thrive.

It's not about fitting into a mold. It's about creating a loving environment where a child can grow and flourish. And that's something that can happen in any kind of family. Period.

Ugh. Don't even get me started. I'm full of flaws. It's a wonder anyone tolerates me.

But if I had to pick just one… it's probably my **cynicism**.

I know, I know. It's my whole *thing*. The sarcastic, witty, world-weary teenager. But it's also a defense mechanism. I use sarcasm to keep people at arm's length, to protect myself from getting hurt.

I automatically assume the worst in people and situations. I'm quick to judge, and I'm not always willing to give people the benefit of the doubt. It's a really unattractive quality, I know.

And it's not just about other people. I'm also really hard on myself. I set impossibly high standards, and then I beat myself up when I don't meet them. It's exhausting.

Bren says I'm afraid of being vulnerable. And she's probably right. It's easier to be cynical and sarcastic than to let people see the real me. The scared, insecure, confused me.

It's a weakness because it prevents me from forming genuine connections with people. It prevents me from trusting others. And it prevents me from being truly happy.

I'm trying to work on it, though. I'm trying to be more open-minded, more forgiving, and more willing to let people in. But it's hard. It's really hard.

So yeah. My biggest flaw? Cynicism. It's a work in progress. Don't hold your breath waiting for me to become a ray of sunshine. But I'm trying. I really am. Just… don't tell anyone I said that. It'll ruin my reputation.

Ugh, Mark. Don't get me wrong, he's a good guy. Really. But talking about him… it's complicated.

Before Mark, relationships were… abstract. Like something you read about in books or see in movies. I hadn't really *experienced* one, you know? Just a few awkward crushes and a lot of teenage angst.

Then there was Mark. And it wasn't a typical romance, obviously. It was… different. We weren't falling in love, or anything. It was more like… a shared responsibility. A shared journey.

He was so… mature. And patient. And understanding. He didn't treat me like a kid, even though I was. He listened to my concerns, and he respected my decisions. He never tried to tell me what to do, or pressure me into anything.

And that was… surprising. I expected him to be awkward, or judgmental, or just plain weirded out. But he wasn't. He was just… normal. In a good way.

Seeing how he interacted with Vanessa, too, that changed things. They had this easy, comfortable connection. They communicated openly and honestly. They supported each other. It was… nice. It made me realize what a healthy relationship could look like.

It also made me realize that love isn't always about grand gestures and passionate declarations. Sometimes, it's about the small things. About being there for someone, about listening to them, about making them feel safe and loved.

It didn't make me suddenly want to find a boyfriend, or anything. I'm still not really interested in that. But it did change my perspective on relationships. It made me realize that they can be a source of strength and support. And that they require effort, and communication, and a whole lot of patience.

It also made me realize that I deserve to be treated with respect and kindness. And that I shouldn't settle for anything less. Which is a good lesson to learn, I think. Even if I'm still a little bit cynical about the whole thing. Relationships are messy. But they can also be beautiful. And I think Mark and Vanessa showed me that.

Okay, look. This is the real stuff, right? Not the "professional growth" or "core values" nonsense. This is about someone actually *going through it*.

If you're in a situation like I was… pregnant, scared, and completely overwhelmed… the first thing I want you to know is: **you are not alone.** Seriously. It feels like it, I know. But you're not. There are people who care about you, and there are people who can help.

Don't be afraid to **talk to someone.** Anyone. Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher. Just… get it off your chest. Holding it inside will only make it worse.

And **don't let anyone tell you what to do.** This is *your* decision. *Your* body. *Your* life. People will have opinions, and they'll probably share them whether you ask for them or not. But ultimately, you have to do what's right for *you*.

**Take your time.** Don't rush into anything. Explore all your options. Talk to different people. Think about what you want, and what you can handle. There's no right or wrong answer. There's just the answer that's right for *you*.

**Be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation. You're going to have good days and bad days. You're going to feel a lot of different emotions. That's okay. Allow yourself to feel those emotions. Don't beat yourself up.

And **remember that you are strong.** You are capable of getting through this. You are resilient. You are worthy of love and happiness.

It's going to be hard. It's going to be scary. But you can do it. And you will get through it.

And if you need someone to talk to, even just to vent, please reach out. There are people who care. And you deserve to have support.

Just… breathe. And remember that you're not alone. That's the most important thing.

Oh, man. My dad, Mac. He's… a character. He's a good guy, really. Just… not always the most *expressive* guy. When I was little, it was kinda like he was always trying to fix things.
