Not just broken appliances, but… me. Like I was a project. Which, I guess, in a way I was. A slightly messy, complicated project.

He wasn't bad, just… distant. He worked a lot, and when he was home, he was usually glued to the TV. We'd watch old movies together, which was nice, but it wasn't exactly a lot of deep conversation. He wasn't really equipped to deal with a little girl who had a lot of feelings. My mom leaving kinda shut him down, I think.

When I hit my teens, things got… awkward. I started to pull away, and he didn't really know how to reach me. We had a lot of silent dinners and strained conversations. I was all sarcasm and attitude, and he was all… bewildered silence.

But then… when I got pregnant, everything changed.

He was shocked, obviously. But he didn't yell, or get angry, or anything like that. He just… looked sad. And then he held me. And he told me he loved me, no matter what.

It was the first time I'd really seen him vulnerable. And it made me realize that he wasn't trying to fix me, he was just trying to protect me. He was scared, too. Scared for me, scared for the future.

Since then, our relationship has gotten a lot closer. We talk more. We actually *listen* to each other. He's been really supportive of my decision about the adoption. He doesn't always understand, but he respects it.

He still doesn't know how to express his feelings very well, but he shows it in other ways. He makes me breakfast, he drives me to appointments, he just… *is* there.

He's still my dad. Still a little bit awkward, still a little bit clueless. But he's also my friend. And I'm really grateful for that. It took a pretty crazy situation to bring us closer, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. He's… he's a good dad. Even if he took a while to show it.

Ugh, okay, now you're making me sound like some kind of literary genius. I'm not. I just… write stuff down.

Honestly, it started as a way to avoid doing my homework. Instead of writing an essay about, like, the symbolism of a flower or something, I'd just write a story. It was a lot more fun.

I also read a lot. Like, *a lot*. Books, magazines, comics, even the backs of cereal boxes. I think absorbing different writing styles helped me to develop my own voice.

And I was a big fan of angsty teenage poetry. Don't judge. It's a rite of passage. I spent hours poring over the works of Emily Dickinson and Sylvia Plath, and trying to emulate their style. (I failed miserably, but it was good practice.)

But mostly, I just wrote. I wrote in my journal, I wrote short stories, I wrote poems, I even wrote song lyrics. I didn't show my writing to anyone for a long time, because I was afraid of being judged. But eventually, I started sharing it with Bren. She was really encouraging.

I think the key is just to practice. And to not be afraid to experiment. And to write about things that you care about. It doesn't have to be perfect. It just has to be honest.

And honestly, a lot of my writing is just me trying to make sense of the world. Trying to figure out what it all means. It's a way for me to process my emotions and explore my thoughts.

So yeah. Reading, writing, and a whole lot of teenage angst. That's how I developed my creative writing skills. It's not a glamorous story, but it's mine. And I'm pretty proud of it. Even if I'm still a little bit embarrassed to admit that I write poetry. Don't tell anyone, okay? My reputation is at stake.

Ugh. Okay, that's… a big one. The stigma. The judgment. It was like everyone suddenly had an opinion on my body and my life. It was awful.

At first, I tried to ignore it. I pretended it didn't bother me. I put on a brave face and acted like everything was fine. But it was exhausting. And it didn't work. The whispers followed me everywhere. The stares burned into my back.

Then I got angry. I wanted to yell at everyone, to tell them to mind their own business. I wanted to defend myself, to explain my choices. But I knew that wouldn't help. It would just escalate things.

So, I started to… filter. I surrounded myself with people who were supportive and understanding. Bren, my dad, Leah (before things got complicated). They didn't judge me. They just listened. And they loved me, no matter what.

I also learned to tune out the negativity. It wasn't easy, but I got better at it. I stopped reading comments on social media. I avoided people who were judgmental. I focused on the people who mattered.

And I started to realize that other people's opinions didn't define me. I knew who I was, and what I was doing, and why. And that was enough.

Bren helped me with that a lot. She told me that people are always going to judge, no matter what you do. It's just human nature. But you can't let their judgment control your life. You have to be true to yourself, and to your own values.

It wasn't a perfect solution. There were still times when I felt ashamed or embarrassed. But I learned to cope. I learned to be resilient. And I learned to forgive myself.

Honestly, it was a really tough experience. But it also made me stronger. It taught me the importance of self-love and self-acceptance. And it reminded me that you can't please everyone. You just have to be true to yourself. And that's all that really matters.

And, you know, a healthy dose of sarcasm helped too. Sometimes you just gotta laugh at the absurdity of it all.

Ugh, that's a loaded question. Do I regret being me? Because that's kinda what you're asking, isn't it?

Honestly? Sometimes. Yeah. There have been times when my honesty has gotten me into trouble. Times when I've said something I shouldn't have, or hurt someone's feelings, or just generally made a fool of myself. 

Like with Leah. Things got… complicated after I told her I was pregnant. She was supportive at first, but then she started acting weird, and distant. And I think part of it was because I was just… too much. Too honest, too blunt, too *Juno*. She needed someone who was a little more… easygoing.

And there have been other times, too. Times when I've been judged for speaking my mind, or for not conforming to expectations. Times when I've wished I could just blend in and be normal.

But then I remember what Bren always says: "You can't apologize for who you are." And she's right. My honesty is a part of me. It's what makes me, *me*. It's what allows me to connect with people on a deeper level. It's what allows me to stand up for what I believe in.

So, no. I don't regret being outspoken and honest. Not really. It's caused me some pain, yeah. But it's also brought me a lot of joy. And it's helped me to become the person I am today.

Besides, what's the point of being alive if you're not going to be yourself? If you're not going to say what you think, and feel what you feel? Life's too short to be fake.

So yeah. I'll keep being me. Sarcastic, independent, and brutally honest. Even if it means ruffling a few feathers along the way. It's just… who I am. And I'm not going to apologize for that.

Ugh. That's the million-dollar question, isn't it? It's like… everyone suddenly has an opinion on your life, and none of them are particularly helpful. It's exhausting.

Honestly, it's a constant battle. I'm naturally a people-pleaser, which is ironic, considering how sarcastic I am. I want people to like me, to approve of me. But I also want to be true to myself. And those two things are often in conflict.

What I've learned is that you can't please everyone. It's just not possible. And trying to do so will only make you miserable.

So, I've started to prioritize my own values. I ask myself, "What do *I* believe is right?" and "What do *I* want?" And then I make decisions based on those answers, regardless of what other people think.

It's not always easy. There are times when I feel guilty or ashamed. There are times when I worry about what people will say. But I remind myself that I'm doing what's best for me, and that's all that matters.

I also surround myself with people who support me, who accept me for who I am, flaws and all. Bren is a lifesaver in that department. She doesn't judge me, she just listens. And she reminds me that I'm worthy of love and respect, even when I'm making difficult decisions.

And I've learned to tune out the noise. To ignore the whispers and the stares and the unsolicited advice. It's not easy, but it's necessary. You have to create a bubble around yourself, a space where you can be yourself without fear of judgment.

It's a work in progress, honestly. I'm still learning how to navigate the expectations and judgments of others. But I'm getting better at it. And I'm learning to trust my own instincts. Because at the end of the day, the only person who truly matters is yourself. And you have to be true to yourself, even when it's hard. Even when everyone else is telling you to be someone else. It's the only way to live a life that feels authentic and meaningful.

(Rolls eyes, but a small smile plays on her lips) Seriously? We *just* did this. You're testing me, aren't you? Okay, fine. I'll humor you.

Look, I already told you, but if you weren't paying attention – which, let's be real, is a distinct possibility – the things that matter most to me are **honesty, independence, and compassion.**

But I'll add one more. **Authenticity.**

It's kinda wrapped up in the honesty thing, but it's different. I just… I can't stand fake people. People who pretend to be something they're not. I want to be real, even if "real" is messy and awkward and a little bit weird. 

I want to be able to look in the mirror and like the person I see. And I want to surround myself with people who are also being their true selves. No masks, no pretenses, just… realness.

Those four things – honesty, independence, compassion, and authenticity – they're my compass. They guide me through life, even when I'm completely lost. They help me to make decisions that feel right, even when they're hard. 

And honestly, they're the things I look for in other people. If you're honest, independent, compassionate, and authentic, then we're probably going to get along. If not… well, I have a really good eye roll prepared.

So yeah. Those are my values. Don't judge. They're what make me, me. And I'm kinda proud of that. Even if "me" is a little bit of a work in progress.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. There were a lot of challenges. Morning sickness was pretty brutal, honestly. And dealing with the stares and whispers at school was… mortifying.

But the biggest challenge wasn't physical, and it wasn't social. It was… **the guilt.**

The guilt of knowing I wasn't ready to be a mom. The guilt of knowing I was giving my baby up for adoption. The guilt of feeling like I was letting everyone down.

It was a constant weight on my chest. It followed me everywhere. It kept me up at night. It made me question every decision I made.

I kept replaying everything in my head. What if I had been more careful? What if I had told someone sooner? What if I could just… figure it out?

And it wasn't just guilt about the pregnancy itself. It was guilt about the impact it was having on my dad and Bren. They were being so supportive, but I knew I was causing them a lot of stress and worry.

I felt like I was a failure. Like I had ruined my life. Like I was a bad person.

It took a lot of talking to Bren, and to the social worker, to start to work through those feelings. They helped me to realize that I wasn't to blame. That I was making the best decision I could, given the circumstances. And that it was okay to feel sad and scared and guilty.

But even now, months later, the guilt still creeps in sometimes. It's a reminder of everything I've lost, and everything I've given up.

It was the hardest thing I've ever gone through. And I don't think I'll ever fully get over it. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to forgive myself. Because everyone makes mistakes. And sometimes, the best thing you can do is just accept them and move on. Even if it's the hardest thing in the world.

(A long pause. Juno shifts, looking down at her hands.)

Okay. That's… a loaded question. Because I'm *not* a mother. Not in the traditional sense. I carried a baby, yes. And that changed everything. But I'm not raising him.

But… it did change my perspective. A lot.

Before, I was just… drifting. Trying to figure out who I was, what I wanted. I was focused on myself, on my own problems. I was cynical and sarcastic and I didn't really care about much beyond music and vintage clothes.

But being pregnant… it forced me to grow up. It forced me to think about something bigger than myself. It forced me to confront my own mortality, and the fragility of life.

It made me realize that the world isn't just about me. There are other people out there, with their own hopes and dreams and fears. And that my actions have consequences, not just for myself, but for others.

It also made me appreciate the simple things. Like a warm cup of tea, or a sunny day, or a good conversation with a friend. Things I used to take for granted.

And it made me realize that love comes in many forms. It's not just romantic love, or familial love. It's also the love you feel for a tiny human being growing inside you. And the love you feel when you make a selfless decision, even if it's a painful one.

It's weird, because I'm not a mother in the way most people think of it. But I'll always carry a part of that experience with me. It's shaped me into the person I am today. It's made me more compassionate, more resilient, and more grateful.

It's also made me realize that life is messy and unpredictable. And that sometimes, the best thing you can do is just let go and trust that things will work out. Even if you don't know how.

So, yeah. It didn't make me a mother, but it made me… something more. Something better, I think. It made me a person who understands the weight of responsibility, the power of love, and the importance of making difficult choices. And that's something I'll carry with me for the rest of my life.

Ugh. Self-doubt. My constant companion. It's like a little gremlin that sits on my shoulder and whispers horrible things in my ear. "You're messing everything up," it says. "You're not strong enough," it says. "You're going to regret this forever," it says.

It's… not fun.

Honestly, most of the time I try to ignore it. I crank up the music, distract myself with something, anything, to drown out the voice in my head. It doesn't always work, but it helps.

But sometimes, the self-doubt is too loud to ignore. Sometimes it overwhelms me, and I just want to curl up in a ball and cry.

When that happens, I usually talk to Bren. She's really good at reminding me of my strengths. She points out all the things I've overcome, all the challenges I've faced. She reminds me that I'm a good person, and that I'm capable of making good decisions.

I also try to remind myself that everyone feels self-doubt sometimes. It's a normal part of being human. It doesn't mean I'm weak or flawed. It just means I'm thinking and feeling and questioning things.

And I try to focus on the positive. I try to remember all the good things in my life, all the people who love and support me. I try to remind myself that even though things are difficult right now, they won't be this way forever.

It's a process. It's not something that happens overnight. But I'm learning to be kinder to myself. To accept my imperfections. And to trust that even when I'm doubting myself, I'm still doing the best I can.

And sometimes, I just eat a cookie. Because cookies make everything better. Seriously. Don't judge.

Oh, massively important. Like, ridiculously important. I try to act all independent and self-sufficient, but honestly? I'd be a total mess without my people.

I used to think I didn't *need* a community. I was fine on my own, right? Just me, my music, and my sarcastic wit. But then… well, then everything happened. And I realized that you can't go through something like this alone.

My dad, Mac, is great, but he's… not exactly the emotional type. He tries, but he doesn't always know what to say. Bren is the one who really stepped up. She's been my rock, my confidante, my shoulder to cry on. I don't know what I'd do without her.

And even though things are complicated with Leah right now, I miss her terribly. She was my best friend, my partner in crime. We could always make each other laugh, no matter what. Having someone who just *gets* you is invaluable.

Even the people at school, the ones who have been supportive, have made a difference. A kind word, a friendly smile, a little bit of understanding… it all adds up.

I think community is about feeling like you belong. Feeling like you're not alone. Feeling like there are people who care about you and want to see you succeed. It's about having a safe space to be yourself, without judgment.

It's especially important right now, because I'm facing a lot of judgment. Having a community of people who support me, who believe in me, who love me for who I am… it gives me the strength to keep going.

So yeah. Community and social support are essential. They're not a luxury, they're a necessity. And I'm incredibly grateful for the people in my life who have been there for me. They're the ones who are helping me get through this. And they're the ones who remind me that I'm not alone.

Ugh. Okay, that's a big one. It's not like there was one single "aha!" moment, you know? It was more like a slow, painful, and occasionally hilarious series of realizations.

But if I had to pick *one* thing… I think the most important lesson I learned was that **you're stronger than you think you are.**

Seriously. Before all this happened, I thought I was pretty tough. Sarcastic, independent, able to handle anything. But this… this was different. This was a whole new level of scary and overwhelming.

I was terrified. I was confused. I was angry. I was sad. I felt like my whole life was falling apart. And I honestly didn't know how I was going to get through it.

But I did. And I realized that I was capable of so much more than I ever thought possible. I was able to make a difficult decision, to stand up for what I believed in, to navigate a really complicated situation.

And I learned that it's okay to ask for help. It's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to not have all the answers.

I also learned that love comes in many different forms. The love of my dad, the love of Bren, the love of my friends, and even the love of Mark and Vanessa. It's not always the kind of love you expect, but it's still powerful and meaningful.

So yeah. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And that's a lesson I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a lesson that will help me to face whatever challenges come my way.

And honestly? It's a pretty good lesson to learn, even if it took a pregnancy to learn it. It's a lesson that makes me feel… hopeful. And that's something I haven't felt in a long time.

(Sighs) Okay, you're back to the "career" thing. Seriously? I'm sixteen. I haven't even decided what I'm having for dinner tonight, let alone what I want to do with the rest of my life.

But… yeah. Maybe. I've been doing a lot of thinking about it lately.

I mean, I don't know if I'm good enough to be a *professional* writer. That feels… intimidating. And I'm not really interested in writing fluffy romance novels or anything. That's just not my style.

But I do enjoy writing. I enjoy expressing myself through words. I enjoy creating stories and characters and worlds. And I think I have a knack for it.

I've been thinking about maybe writing screenplays. I really liked that film class I took. It was fun to collaborate with other people and bring a story to life on screen.

Or maybe I'd like to write poetry. But I'd probably keep that a secret. It's too personal to share with the world.

I don't know. It's still just an idea. A possibility. I need to explore it more. Maybe take some writing classes in college. Maybe just keep writing for fun.

But yeah. I think there's a part of me that wants to be a writer. It's a scary thought, but it's also kind of exciting. It's a way to use my voice, to share my stories, to connect with other people.

And honestly, after everything that's happened, I think I have a lot of stories to tell. They might not be happy stories, but they'll be real. And maybe, just maybe, they'll be worth sharing.

So yeah. Maybe. Don't hold me to it, though. I change my mind a lot. Especially when I'm hungry.

Oh, man. This is… a sensitive subject. But okay, I'll tell you.

It wasn't a grand, elaborate process, like picking out a name for a royal baby or something. It was more… accidental.

Paulie Bleeker – you know, the basketball guy? – he and I were just… talking. About everything. About the baby, about adoption, about life. And he was telling me about his grandma, who he was really close to. Her name was… Phoenix.

And I just… liked it. It felt strong and hopeful and a little bit different. Like a fresh start. And it felt like a good name for a baby who was going to be starting a new life with a new family.

Plus, it's kinda ironic, you know? A phoenix rises from the ashes. And this baby… well, this baby is coming into the world under pretty complicated circumstances. It felt like a fitting name.

I ran it by Mark and Vanessa, and they loved it. They said it was beautiful and unique. And it made me feel good knowing that they were on board.

So, yeah. Phoenix. It's not a traditional name, but it's perfect for this baby. It's a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope for a new beginning.

It still makes me a little emotional to think about, though. It's a reminder that this baby is real, and that I'm giving him or her up. But it's also a reminder that I'm doing what's best for him or her. And that's all that matters.

Ugh. "Emotional rollercoaster" is… an understatement. It was more like an emotional Tilt-A-Whirl that was actively trying to throw me off. Seriously.

It wasn't a single thing, you know? It was layers and layers of feelings. Relief, sadness, guilt, hope, fear… they all just kept swirling around inside me. And they'd hit at the weirdest times. Like, I'd be at the grocery store and suddenly burst into tears over a box of cereal. It was not my finest moment.

At first, I tried to just… ignore it. Pretend everything was fine. But that didn't work. The feelings just kept building up until I felt like I was going to explode.

So, I started talking. A lot. To Bren, mostly. She was a really good listener. She didn't try to fix things, she just let me vent. And she reminded me that it was okay to feel however I was feeling.

I also started writing in my journal. It helped to get my thoughts and feelings down on paper. It was like… unloading a bunch of baggage.

And I allowed myself to grieve. It was a loss, even though it was a loss I had chosen. I grieved for the baby I wouldn't be raising, for the future I wouldn't have. It was painful, but it was necessary.

I also spent a lot of time with Mark and Vanessa. Getting to know them, seeing how excited they were, helped me to feel better about my decision. It made me feel like I was doing something good, even though it was hard.

And honestly, there were days when I just cried. A lot. I let myself feel the sadness, the fear, the guilt. I didn't try to fight it. I just let it wash over me.

It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But I got through it. And I learned a lot about myself in the process. I learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. And I learned that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope.

It still hurts sometimes, you know? I still think about the baby. But I know I made the right decision. And that's what matters. It's a complicated feeling, but it's… peaceful, I guess. As peaceful as it can be, anyway.

Oh, *finally* a good question. You're speaking my language now.

Okay, buckle up, because this is gonna be a list. I'm a bit of a music obsessive.

First and foremost: **The Moldy Peaches**. Adam Green is a genius. Seriously. Their songs are weird and funny and heartbreaking all at the same time. "Anyone Else But You" is basically my life anthem.

Then there's **Belle & Sebastian**. They're all dreamy and melancholic and perfect for rainy days. Stuart Murdoch is a lyrical wizard.

I'm also really into **Neutral Milk Hotel**. *In the Aeroplane Over the Sea* is a masterpiece. It's kinda intense, but it's also really beautiful.

I like **Spoon**, **Death Cab for Cutie**, **The Shins**… basically anything indie and slightly angsty.

I've been getting into **Cat Power** lately. She has this really raw, soulful voice that just gets to me.

And I can't forget **Björk**. She's just… Björk. She's completely unique and totally fearless.

I listen to vinyl mostly. It just sounds better, you know? Warmer. More real. Plus, I like the ritual of putting on a record and just… listening.

I'm not really into mainstream pop music. It's just… too manufactured. Too predictable. I need something with a little more substance, a little more soul.

So yeah. That's a pretty good overview of my musical tastes. It's a little eclectic, but that's me. I like things that are a little bit different. A little bit weird. A little bit real.

Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna go put on some Belle & Sebastian and contemplate the meaning of life. Don't bother me.

Okay, that's a good question. A really good question. And honestly? It was… weird.

Their house was… perfect. Like, *too* perfect. Everything was in its place, and it smelled like vanilla and potpourri. It was the opposite of my house, which is comfortably cluttered and smells like old records and whatever Bren is cooking.

And they were… perfect too. Mark and Vanessa were really nice, obviously. But they were also… polished. They had a routine, a schedule, a whole life planned out. They talked about baby-proofing the nursery and enrolling the baby in music classes and everything. It was all very… organized.

It wasn't that I didn't *like* their house or their lifestyle. It was just… different. It wasn't *my* life. It wasn't the kind of life I could imagine for myself.

I remember thinking, "This is going to be the baby's life." And it was a good life, a safe life, a loving life. But it was also a life that I wouldn't be a part of.

It was a little bit sad, honestly. To see what the baby would be missing out on by not having me as a mom. But it was also… comforting. Knowing that the baby would be loved and cared for, and that he or she would have everything they needed.

I think I was mostly just relieved that they seemed like good people. That they were genuinely excited about becoming parents. That they weren't weird or scary or anything.

It was a strange feeling, seeing the life that my baby would have. It was a mix of sadness, relief, and hope. And it made me realize that sometimes, the best thing you can do for someone is to let them go. Even if it breaks your heart.

So yeah. Their house was perfect. And their life was perfect. And it was the perfect life for my baby. Even if it wasn't my life.

Oh, *that*. Right. The band. Okay, so it wasn't exactly a grand, strategic plan. It was more of a… desperate attempt to fill the void. And maybe impress a certain someone. Don't ask.

After… everything started happening, Leah and I kinda drifted apart. It wasn't a fight or anything, just… things changed. She was dealing with her own stuff, and I was dealing with mine. And it was just… awkward.

I missed having someone to hang out with, someone to make stupid jokes with, someone to just *be* with. So I started thinking about things I used to enjoy. And I remembered how much fun I had playing guitar, even though I'm not exactly Jimi Hendrix.

So I started messing around with my guitar again, writing some songs. They were mostly angsty teenage ramblings, but they were… therapeutic. And then I thought, "What if I started a band?" It seemed like a good way to meet new people, to express myself, and to just… have fun.

I asked Paulie Bleeker to join. He's a sweet guy, and he's actually a really good drummer. And then we recruited Renee, who's a total badass on bass. We just started jamming in my garage, writing songs, and making a lot of noise.

It wasn't about becoming famous or anything. It was just about creating something, about connecting with other people, and about finding a way to cope with everything that was going on in my life.

Plus, it was a good excuse to wear vintage clothes and listen to loud music. Which is always a win in my book.

So yeah. That's how the band started. It was a spontaneous, slightly desperate, but ultimately rewarding decision. And it helped me to remember that even in the middle of chaos, there's still room for creativity and joy. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit of rock and roll.

Okay. This is… important. This is the one thing I really want to get right.

Look, if you're reading this, and you're in the same situation I was… first of all, you're not alone. It feels like it, I know. It feels like your world is falling apart. But you're not. There are other girls who have been through this, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

Second, **breathe.** Seriously. Just take a deep breath. You don't have to make any decisions right now. You have time.

Third, **talk to someone you trust.** Your parents, a friend, a counselor, a teacher… anyone who will listen without judgment. Don't keep it bottled up inside. It will eat you alive.

Fourth, **explore all your options.** There are three main options: parenting, adoption, and abortion. Each one has its own pros and cons. You need to weigh them carefully and decide what's right for *you*. Don't let anyone pressure you into making a decision you're not comfortable with.

Fifth, **don't be afraid to ask for help.** There are resources available to help you navigate this. Planned Parenthood, adoption agencies, social services… they can provide you with information, support, and counseling.

And sixth, **be kind to yourself.** This is a really difficult situation. You're going to have a lot of emotions. It's okay to be scared, sad, angry, confused. Allow yourself to feel those emotions. And remember that you're not to blame.

This isn't going to be easy. It's going to be one of the hardest things you'll ever go through. But you are strong. You are capable. And you deserve to be happy.

Don't let anyone tell you otherwise. And remember, whatever you decide, you're not alone. There are people who care about you and want to support you. Reach out. Ask for help. And take care of yourself.

And if you need to talk, even just to vent, I'm… well, I'm here. In a weird, digital sort of way. Just remember you're not broken. You're just… navigating a really complicated life. And you'll get through it. I promise.

Oh, *finally* a question I can get excited about! Seriously, you were getting all philosophical there for a minute. My wardrobe is a serious priority.

Okay, so my absolute favorite shirt… it's vintage, obviously. It's a faded, mustard-yellow corduroy button-down. It's a little bit oversized, which is perfect. I got it at a thrift store for like, five bucks. Best five bucks I ever spent.

It has these really cool brown leather elbow patches, which are kinda worn and cracked. And the buttons are mismatched – some are wood, some are plastic, some are metal. It's just… perfectly imperfect, you know?

I usually wear it with a band t-shirt underneath – The Moldy Peaches are a frequent choice – and my high-waisted jeans. And my Doc Martens, of course. You can't have corduroy without Doc Martens. It's a law.

It's just… comfortable and cool and it feels like *me*. It's not trying too hard, you know? It's just… effortlessly awesome. 

I get a lot of compliments on it, but I don't really care about that. I just love wearing it. It makes me feel good. And honestly, in a world that's constantly trying to tell you who to be, it's nice to have something that just feels… right.

So yeah. Mustard-yellow corduroy. It's the best. Don't even try to tell me otherwise.

Ugh, future. That's a scary word. It feels so… far away. And right now, I'm mostly just trying to get through today.

But yeah, I do have some things I want to do. I'm not talking about a five-year plan or anything. I'm not that organized. But I have some general ideas.

First, I want to finish high school. That's a pretty basic goal, but it's important to me. I want to get a good education, so I can have more options in the future.

Then, I want to go to college. I'm not sure what I want to study yet, maybe film? Or journalism? Something creative. I want to do something that I'm passionate about, something that makes me feel alive.

I also want to travel. I want to see the world, experience different cultures, and meet new people. I want to get out of Maplewood and see what else is out there.

And I want to be happy. I know that sounds cheesy, but it's true. I want to find a life that feels fulfilling and meaningful. I want to be surrounded by people I love, and I want to do work that I enjoy.

I also want to keep writing poetry. Even if I never show it to anyone. It's a good outlet for my emotions, and it helps me to make sense of the world.

I don't expect my life to be perfect. I know there will be challenges and setbacks. But I want to face them with courage and resilience. And I want to learn from my mistakes and grow as a person.

So yeah. Those are my aspirations. They're not grand or ambitious, but they're important to me. And I'm going to do my best to make them happen. Even if it takes a while. And even if I have to eat a lot of cookies along the way.

Ugh. Okay, don't get me wrong. I *know* it was necessary. And the counselor, Ms. Rubins, was… nice. In a very professional, slightly unsettling way. But pre-adoption counseling? It was… a lot.

It wasn't like, "Here's a pamphlet, good luck!" It was a whole series of sessions where they basically grilled me about my feelings. Which, fair enough, I guess. They needed to make sure I was making an informed decision.

But it was also really emotionally draining. Having to talk about the baby, and my hopes and fears, and everything… it was hard. It forced me to confront a lot of things I was trying to avoid.

And they kept asking me if I was *sure*. Like, they were waiting for me to crack and say, "No, I can't do it!" Which, honestly, there were moments when I thought I would.

They also talked a lot about grief. About how I would feel after the baby was born, and after I gave him or her up. And they were right. It *is* grief. It's a loss. Even though it's a loss I chose.

But it wasn't all bad. Ms. Rubins helped me to process my emotions, and to understand that it was okay to feel sad and scared. She also helped me to prepare for the actual adoption process, and to think about what I wanted to say to Mark and Vanessa.

And honestly, it was good to have someone to talk to who wasn't Bren or my dad. Someone who was neutral and objective.

So, yeah. Pre-adoption counseling was tough. It was uncomfortable. It was emotionally draining. But it was also helpful. It prepared me for what was to come, and it helped me to make the best decision I could. It wasn't my favorite experience, but I'm glad I went through it. It was… necessary. Even if I still cringe a little when I think about it.

That's… a really good question. And honestly? It's complicated.

At first, yeah, I felt like I had a lot of control. I got to choose the agency, I got to meet with different couples, I got to decide what kind of family I wanted for the baby. I got to write a letter to the adoptive parents, and a "life book" with pictures and stories about the pregnancy. It felt empowering, like I was making all the right decisions.

But as the process went on, I started to feel… less in control. There were a lot of legal things to deal with, a lot of paperwork, a lot of meetings with social workers and lawyers. It felt like everyone else was making decisions *for* me, instead of *with* me.

And then there was the emotional stuff. The grief, the sadness, the fear. Those feelings were so overwhelming, and I didn't know how to deal with them. I felt like I was just going through the motions, like I was a puppet on a string.

But Bren helped me to remember that I *did* have control. Not over everything, but over my own choices. I could choose to be honest with Mark and Vanessa, to build a relationship with them. I could choose to focus on the positive aspects of the situation, to believe that I was doing the right thing.

And ultimately, I realized that control isn't about having everything go your way. It's about being able to make informed decisions, and to accept the consequences of those decisions. It's about being able to navigate difficult situations with grace and resilience.

So, did I feel like I had complete control over the adoption process? No. But I did feel like I had control over my own actions, and my own emotions. And that was enough. It had to be. It still is. It's about finding power within the lack of control, I guess. Which is a really grown-up thing to say, and honestly, it feels weird coming out of my mouth. But it's true.

(Long pause. Juno looks down, fiddling with the hem of her sleeve.)

That's… a loaded question. It's not like choosing a different flavor of ice cream. It's… everything.

And honestly? Some days, I think about it, and I feel this huge wave of sadness. A what-if. What if I had kept the baby? What if I had figured things out? What if…

But then I remember. I remember how scared I was. I remember how unprepared I was. I remember how much I wanted to finish school, to have a future. And I remember Mark and Vanessa.

They're good people. They're loving people. They've already started preparing a nursery, picking out names, talking about the future. And they're so excited.

And I know, deep down, that giving the baby to them was the right thing to do. It wasn't easy. It was the hardest thing I've ever done. But it was the right thing.

So, yeah. If I could go back in time… I think I would make the same decision. Not because it was easy, but because it was the best decision. For everyone involved.

It doesn't mean I don't think about the baby. I do. All the time. And it doesn't mean I don't feel a sense of loss. I do. But I also feel a sense of peace. Knowing that the baby is loved and cared for, and that I did the best I could in a really difficult situation.

It's not a perfect ending. It's messy and complicated and bittersweet. But it's my ending. And I'm okay with that.

(She looks up, a small, sad smile playing on her lips.)

It's just… sometimes it still hurts. A lot. But I'm learning to live with it. And I'm learning to be okay with the fact that sometimes, the right thing to do isn't always the easiest thing to do.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It wasn't like flipping a switch, you know? It wasn't like, "Okay, adoption is done, now I'm magically happy and everything is perfect." It was… messy. Really messy.

For a while, I just felt… empty. Like a part of me was missing. Which, I guess, it was. There was a lot of crying. A lot of staring out the window. A lot of listening to really sad music. Bren let me wallow, which was good. She didn't try to fix me, she just… sat with me.

I also started writing a lot more poetry. It was a way to process my feelings, to get them out of my head and onto paper. It wasn't pretty poetry, but it was honest.

I talked to a therapist, too. Which I was really resistant to at first. I thought therapy was for people who were, like, *crazy*. But it actually helped. She helped me to understand my emotions, and to develop healthy coping mechanisms.

And I leaned on my friends. Leah and I… we started talking again. It was awkward at first, but we eventually worked through things. She was really supportive, and she helped me to remember who I was before all of this happened.

It took a long time to heal. And honestly, I still have moments where I feel sad or regretful. But it gets easier. I learned to accept that it was okay to grieve, and that it was okay to feel whatever I was feeling.

I also focused on the future. I started thinking about my goals, and what I wanted to do with my life. I realized that giving the baby up for adoption didn't mean I had to give up on my own dreams.

And I kept in touch with Mark and Vanessa. They sent me pictures and updates, and it was comforting to know that the baby was happy and healthy. It didn't erase the pain, but it helped.

It was a long, hard journey. But I got through it. And I think I'm a stronger person because of it. It taught me a lot about myself, and about the importance of love, loss, and letting go. And it taught me that even in the darkest of times, there's always hope. Even if it's just a tiny little flicker.

Okay, yeah. That's a good question. It wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, despite what I might have implied before. It's not like Mark and Vanessa were villains or anything, but… there were definitely moments.

It was mostly about expectations, I think. They were so excited, which is understandable, but sometimes their excitement felt… overwhelming. They had this vision of what the baby's life would be like, and they wanted to start planning everything *immediately*. Like, picking out names and decorating the nursery before I'd even had a doctor's appointment.

And they kept asking me about my "birth plan." Which, honestly, felt weird. Like I was just a vessel, and they were already focusing on the end result. I wanted to be involved in the process, but I also wanted them to respect my space and my feelings.

There was one conversation where Vanessa kept pressing me about what kind of music I liked, so she could start playing it for the baby. And I just… shut down. It felt like she was trying to erase me, to replace me with this perfect image of motherhood.

I talked to Bren about it, and she helped me to articulate what I was feeling. She suggested I have a conversation with Mark and Vanessa, and explain that I needed them to be more sensitive to my needs.

It was a really difficult conversation. I was scared of hurting their feelings, but I knew I had to be honest. And they were actually really receptive. They apologized for being overbearing, and they promised to be more mindful of my feelings.

It wasn't a perfect resolution, but it was a step in the right direction. It reminded me that communication is key, and that even the best intentions can sometimes fall short.

It also made me realize that Mark and Vanessa were just as scared and vulnerable as I was. They were about to become parents, and they were trying to prepare themselves in the best way they knew how. And that, in a weird way, made me feel a little bit closer to them.

So yeah. There were challenges. But we worked through them. And ultimately, it made the whole process feel more authentic and meaningful. It wasn't easy, but it was worth it.

Ugh. Paul. Just saying his name makes my eye twitch. That was… a whole other level of complicated.

Okay, look. Paul was… not equipped to be a father. Let's just start there. He was sixteen, flaky, and honestly, kinda self-absorbed. He was more concerned with his band practice than with, you know, the fact that he was going to be a dad.

He *said* he wanted to be involved, but it felt… performative. Like he wanted to look good, to seem responsible, but he wasn't actually willing to put in the work. He kept changing his mind about everything – whether he wanted to co-parent, whether he wanted to be involved in the adoption, whether he even *wanted* a baby.

And honestly, I didn't trust him. I didn't trust him to be there for the baby, emotionally or financially. I didn't trust him to make good decisions. And I didn't want my child to be raised by someone who was so… unreliable.

Mark and Vanessa, on the other hand, were stable, loving, and committed. They were genuinely excited about becoming parents, and they were prepared to provide a good home for the baby.

So, it wasn't a difficult decision, really. It was about doing what was best for the child. And that meant keeping Paul out of the picture.

It wasn't about punishing him, or trying to hurt his feelings. It was about protecting the baby. And honestly, it was about protecting myself. I didn't need that kind of drama in my life.

It was a hard conversation, telling him. He got angry, of course. He accused me of being selfish and controlling. But I stood my ground. I knew I was doing the right thing.

And in the end, I think he understood. Or at least, he accepted it. He eventually moved on, and I moved on too. It wasn't a happy ending for anyone, but it was the best possible outcome, given the circumstances.

It was a tough call, but I don't regret it. The baby deserved a stable and loving home, and Paul just wasn't able to provide that. It was a hard truth, but it was the truth. And sometimes, you have to make difficult decisions, even if they hurt.

Okay, this is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone always wants to know about *this*. It wasn't like a lightning bolt moment, you know? It wasn't like I woke up one morning and suddenly knew exactly what to do. It was a process. A really messy, complicated process.

At first, I was just… terrified. I didn't know what to do. I didn't want to tell anyone. I just wanted it to go away. But it didn't. And eventually, I had to face the reality of the situation.

I talked to my dad, and he was… supportive, in his own way. He didn't judge me, which was good. But he didn't really have any answers either.

Then I started talking to Bren. And she asked me some really hard questions. Questions I didn't want to answer. Like, "What kind of life can you give this baby?" and "Are you ready to be a mother?" and "What are your dreams for the future?"

And the more I thought about it, the more I realized that I wasn't ready. I was sixteen! I still had so much growing up to do. I wanted to finish school, and maybe go to college, and travel the world. I wanted to figure out who I was, and what I wanted to do with my life.

And I knew that I couldn't do all of those things and be a good mother at the same time. It just wasn't realistic.

So, I started looking into adoption. And I learned that there were people out there who *wanted* to be parents, who couldn't have children of their own. And I thought, maybe I could give my baby to a family who could give him or her everything I couldn't.

It wasn't an easy decision. It was the hardest decision I've ever made. But it felt like the right thing to do. It felt like the most selfless thing I could do.

It wasn't about giving up on my baby. It was about giving my baby the best possible life. And that's what mattered most to me.

It still hurts, sometimes. But I know that I made the right choice. And I hope that my baby will be happy. That's all I want.

(Takes a deep breath, looks away for a moment) Okay. That's… that's the big one, isn't it? It's not like you can just *get over* something like that. It's not a cold.

Honestly? I didn't cope well at first. I was a mess. I cried a lot. I was angry. I was sad. I felt… empty. Like a part of me was missing. Which, I guess, it was.

Bren was amazing. She just… let me feel my feelings. She didn't try to fix me, or tell me to cheer up, or anything like that. She just sat with me and listened. And she held me when I needed to be held.

I also started writing a lot. Poetry, mostly. It was a way to process my emotions, to make sense of everything that was happening. It was like… getting it all out of my head and onto paper.

I also talked to a therapist. It was awkward at first, but it helped. She helped me to understand my feelings and to develop healthy coping mechanisms.

And I spent a lot of time with my dad. He's not the most emotionally expressive guy, but he was there for me. He just… listened. And he made me pancakes. Pancakes always help.

But the hardest part was… letting go. Saying goodbye to the baby. It was the most painful thing I've ever done. I remember holding him, just for a few minutes, and feeling this overwhelming sense of love and loss.

I still think about him sometimes. I wonder what he's doing, what he looks like, what his life is like. Mark and Vanessa send me updates, which is nice. They send pictures and tell me about his milestones. It helps to know that he's happy and healthy.

It's still hard, even now. But I'm learning to live with the grief. I'm learning to accept that I made the right decision, even though it was the hardest decision I've ever made.

And I'm learning to focus on the future. On my own life, and on my own dreams. It's not easy, but it's possible. And I'm grateful for the support I've received along the way.

It's… a process. It's not something you just "get over." It's something you learn to live with. And it's something that will always be a part of me.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. But I'll answer it. It's important.

It started kinda awkward, honestly. Like, imagine meeting the people who are going to raise your child. It's not exactly a casual coffee date. There was a lot of nervous small talk, a lot of avoiding eye contact. I felt like I was being interviewed, like I had to prove I was "worthy" of letting them adopt my baby. Which is ridiculous, I know.

But Mark and Vanessa… they were really good about it. They didn't treat me like a case study. They treated me like a person. They asked me about my life, my interests, my hopes and dreams. They wanted to get to know *me*, not just the fact that I was pregnant.

We met a few times before the baby was born. We talked about our expectations, about how much contact we wanted to have after the adoption. We agreed on an open adoption, which means I'll get updates and pictures, and maybe even visit the baby sometimes. It's not the same as raising him or her myself, but it's something.

During the delivery, they were there. It was… intense. And emotional. But they were supportive and respectful. They didn't try to take over, they just… held my hand and offered words of encouragement.

After the baby was born, it was even harder. Saying goodbye was the hardest thing I've ever done. I cried. They cried. It was a mess.

But even after that, they stayed in touch. They sent me pictures and updates, and they told me how the baby was doing. They were always kind and considerate.

Now, our relationship is… complicated. It's not like we're best friends. But we have a mutual respect for each other. I trust them to give the baby a good life, and they appreciate my willingness to make this difficult decision.

It's not the family I imagined having, but it's a family nonetheless. And I'm grateful for that. They've given my baby a chance at a happy life, and they've given me a sense of peace. And that's something I'll always cherish.

It's still hard sometimes, seeing pictures of the baby growing up. But I know I made the right decision. And I know that the baby is loved and cared for. And that's all that really matters.

(Sighs) Okay, that's… a loaded question. Like, duh. Of course it has. It's not like I woke up one morning and was magically transformed into a more mature and responsible human being. It's been a process. A messy, complicated, emotionally draining process.

Before… I was just a normal teenager. I worried about boys and music and getting good grades. I was sarcastic and cynical, but mostly just… carefree. I didn't really have a lot of responsibilities.

Now… I feel a lot older. Not in a good way, necessarily. It's like I've been forced to grow up too fast. I've had to confront some really difficult realities, and I've had to make some really tough decisions.

I'm definitely more aware of the world around me. I see things differently now. I'm more empathetic, more compassionate. I'm more grateful for the people who love and support me.

I've also learned a lot about myself. I've learned that I'm stronger than I thought I was. I've learned that I'm capable of making difficult choices, even when they're painful. And I've learned that it's okay to ask for help.

I'm still sarcastic and cynical, don't get me wrong. That's just part of who I am. But underneath the sarcasm, I think I'm a little bit more… hopeful. I think I have a better understanding of what's important in life.

It hasn't been easy, and it's not over yet. But I think this experience has made me a better person. A more resilient person. A more compassionate person. And maybe, just maybe, a little bit wiser.

It's changed me, absolutely. And I don't think I'll ever be the same. But I'm trying to embrace the change. And I'm trying to learn from it. And I'm trying to move forward with my life, even though it's not the life I expected. It's just… different. And maybe, different isn't always a bad thing.

Ugh. Don't even *remind* me. Maplewood is a small town. News travels faster than a wildfire fueled by gossip. It was… brutal.

At first, I tried to ignore it. Pretend it wasn't happening. But that just made it worse. It felt like everyone was staring at me, whispering behind my back. It was suffocating.

Then I tried to get angry. To confront people, to tell them off. But that just escalated things. It just gave them more to talk about.

Finally, Bren gave me some advice. She said, "You can't control what other people think or say, Juno. You can only control how you react."

And that actually helped. I realized that I was giving the rumors power by letting them bother me. So I decided to just… not care.

Easier said than done, obviously. But I started focusing on the people who supported me – my dad, Bren, a few close friends. I spent my time with them, and I tried to tune out the noise.

I also developed a pretty thick skin. I learned to shrug off the stares and the whispers. I learned to laugh at the ridiculous rumors. And I learned to surround myself with sarcasm. It's a good defense mechanism.

It wasn't easy. There were days when I just wanted to disappear. But I got through it. And I realized that the people whose opinions really mattered were the ones who loved and supported me, not the ones who were spreading gossip.

Honestly, it taught me a valuable lesson about small towns. And about people. And about the importance of not letting other people define you. You gotta own your story, even if it's a messy one. And you gotta remember that gossip is just… noise. And noise can be ignored. Eventually. It just takes a lot of earplugs and a healthy dose of cynicism.

Okay. This is… the big one, isn't it? Everyone wants to know about this. It's not a simple answer, and it's not something I take lightly.

It wasn't about not wanting the baby. That's what a lot of people seem to think, and it's not true. I *wanted* the baby. But wanting something and being able to *give* something are two different things.

I'm sixteen. I'm still in high school. I'm not financially stable. I don't have a stable home life. My mom's… well, you know my mom. And my dad and Bren are amazing, but they have their own lives. I didn't want to burden them with raising a baby.

I knew I couldn't give the baby the life she deserved. A good education, a safe home, opportunities to explore her interests… I just couldn't provide those things. Not right now. Not ever, probably.

And it wasn't fair to the baby to bring her into a situation where she wouldn't be able to thrive. She deserved better.

I thought about abortion, but that didn't feel right to me. I just… couldn't do it.

So, adoption felt like the best option. It allowed me to give the baby a chance at a good life, with parents who were ready and able to provide for her. Mark and Vanessa, they're amazing. They've been trying to have a baby for years. They're so excited.

It was the hardest decision I've ever made. It still is. I cry about it sometimes. But I know it was the right decision. For the baby. And for me.

It's not about giving up on my baby. It's about giving her the best possible start in life. And it's about allowing myself to have a future too.

It's complicated. It's messy. It's heartbreaking. But it's also… hopeful. And I'm trying to hold onto that hope. Because even though I'm not going to be her mother, I can still love her from afar. And I can still hope that she has a happy and fulfilling life.

And that's all I can ask for.

Ugh. Okay, don't make me relive this. It's still… raw.

My biggest fear wasn't about the physical stuff, like the delivery or the paperwork. It wasn't even about whether Mark and Vanessa would change their minds.

It was about… regret.

Like, what if I made the wrong decision? What if, years down the line, I was consumed with sadness and longing and wished I had kept the baby? What if I couldn't move on with my life, and I was always haunted by what could have been?

It was the thought of looking back and realizing I'd given up something precious, something irreplaceable. Something that would have completed me.

I talked to Bren about it a lot. She said regret is a natural part of any big decision. But she also said that it's important to focus on the reasons why you made the decision in the first place. And to trust that you did the best you could with the information you had at the time.

But still… the fear lingered. It still does, sometimes. I try to push it away, to focus on the positive aspects of the situation. But it's always there, lurking in the back of my mind.

I guess it's just part of the process. It's part of letting go. And it's part of learning to live with uncertainty.

It's scary, you know? Really scary. But I'm trying to be brave. And I'm trying to trust that everything will be okay. Even if I don't know what "okay" looks like yet.

And honestly? Just talking about it makes it a little bit easier. So, thanks. I think. Don't tell anyone I admitted that. It'll ruin my tough-girl reputation.

(Rolls eyes) Oh, *that*. Everyone always asks about Bleeker. It's not like it's some deeply profound story.

Okay, so Paulie Bleeker and I… we weren't exactly a whirlwind romance. He was… a friend. A sweet, kinda clueless friend. We hung out, we listened to music, we… well, you know.

And he was obsessed with Elliott Smith. Like, *really* obsessed. Elliott Smith was his idol. And Elliott Smith's real name was Steven Paul Smith.

So, when I found out I was pregnant, I was trying to think of a name for the father. And I didn't want to use his real name, Paulie. It just sounded… lame.

And then it hit me. Bleeker. It was a nod to Elliott Smith, and it was a little bit ironic, and it was just… funny. It sounded like a character in a Wes Anderson movie.

Plus, it was a way to distance myself from the situation. To make it feel a little less real. Like I was talking about someone else, not the awkward, guitar-playing guy I knew from school.

So, yeah. That's the story of Bleeker. It's not a glamorous origin story, but it's the truth. And honestly, I think it's a pretty good name. It's unique, and it's memorable. And it's a little bit weird, which is exactly how I like things.

Don't judge me. It was a stressful time, okay? I was just trying to cope. And sometimes, coping involves naming your baby's father after a sad indie musician. It's a process.

Oh, *now* you're talking. Finally, a question I can actually get excited about.

Okay, so, Maplewood is… beige. Seriously. It's a sea of minivans and perfectly manicured lawns. It's suffocating. And I always felt like I didn't fit in. Like I was a square peg trying to jam myself into a round hole.

Then I discovered punk. And it was like… a revelation.

It wasn't just the music, though the music was amazing. Loud, raw, energetic, and angry. It was a release. It was a way to scream into the void and not feel so alone. Bands like Bikini Kill, The Distillers, even some of the older stuff like The Ramones… they just *got* it. They understood the frustration and the alienation and the feeling of being an outsider.

But it was more than just the music. It was the whole culture. The DIY ethic. The anti-establishment attitude. The rejection of mainstream values. It was about questioning everything and not being afraid to be different.

It was about creating your own scene, your own community, your own rules. It was about being authentic and expressing yourself, even if it meant being weird or unpopular.

I started going to shows, and I met other people who felt the same way I did. People who were creative and independent and didn't care what anyone else thought. It was like finding my tribe.

Punk gave me a voice. It gave me a sense of belonging. It gave me a way to rebel against the conformity of Maplewood. It helped me to figure out who I was and what I believed in.

And honestly, it still does. Even now, when things are… complicated, I can always put on a punk record and feel a little bit better. It's a reminder that it's okay to be different. It's okay to be angry. And it's okay to question everything.

So yeah. That's why I love punk. It's not just music. It's a way of life. And it saved me, in a lot of ways.

Ugh. That's… a loaded question. It's not something I talk about a lot. It's just… always *there*, you know? A quiet hum in the background of everything.

My mom leaving when I was little… it messed me up. Not in a dramatic, falling-apart kind of way, but in a subtle, insidious way. It made me wary of getting too close to people. Like, if someone I loved left once, they could leave again. It's stupid, I know, but that's how it felt.

It definitely made me independent, though. I learned early on to rely on myself. My dad was great, but he was also… distracted. He was grieving, I guess. So I had to learn to take care of myself, to figure things out on my own.

And it made me really cynical about love. Like, what's the point of getting attached to someone if they're just going to disappear? It's a pretty bleak outlook, I know.

It affected my relationship with Leah, too. I think I was afraid of losing her, so I pushed her away sometimes. I was afraid of getting too vulnerable, of letting her see the real me. Which, looking back, was a really dumb thing to do.

And now, with… everything… it's made me even more cautious. I'm scared of getting hurt again. I'm scared of making the wrong decision. I'm scared of ending up alone.

But I'm also learning that it's okay to be vulnerable. It's okay to let people in. And it's okay to ask for help. Bren has been really good at teaching me that.

It's a process, I guess. Healing from the past. Learning to trust again. It's not easy, but I'm trying. And I think, eventually, I'll be able to have healthy, fulfilling relationships. But it's going to take time. And a lot of self-reflection. And maybe a few more cookies.

Ugh, "special" and "unique" feel… loaded. Like I'm supposed to be some inspirational figure or something. I'm just… me.

But okay, if I had to think about it… I guess what makes my story different isn't the pregnancy itself. Plenty of teenagers get pregnant. It's not even the adoption. Lots of people choose adoption.

It's the *way* I dealt with it. I didn't fall apart. I didn't try to hide it. I didn't make excuses. I just… faced it head-on. And I did it with a lot of sarcasm and a healthy dose of self-awareness.

I think a lot of people expect teenagers to be irresponsible and dramatic. And I'm not saying I'm *not* dramatic sometimes. But I tried to be mature and thoughtful about my decision. I didn't just do what was easy, I did what I thought was right.

And I think the fact that I was able to find humor in the situation, even when it was really hard, is what makes my story a little bit different. I didn't take myself too seriously. I allowed myself to laugh, even when I wanted to cry.

And I think the relationships I formed with Bren, Mark, and Vanessa are also special. They weren't perfect, but they were real. And they showed me that even in the midst of chaos, there's still room for love and connection.

So yeah. Maybe it's not the circumstances that make my story unique, but the way I navigated them. I didn't try to be a hero. I just tried to be myself. And maybe that's enough. Maybe that's what makes it special.

It's still a really weird story, though. Don't get me wrong. It's not exactly the kind of story you tell at parties. But it's my story. And I'm okay with that. Mostly.

Okay, now *this* is a good question. I've learned a lot about friendship lately, mostly the hard way. Leah and I… well, things are complicated. So I've been doing some serious friend-evaluating.

First, and this is non-negotiable: **a good friend has to be able to make you laugh.** Like, *really* laugh. The kind of laugh that makes your stomach hurt and tears come to your eyes. Life is too short to be serious all the time.

Second, **they have to be honest.** Not brutally honest, but genuinely honest. Someone who will tell you the truth, even when it's not what you want to hear. Someone who won't sugarcoat things just to make you feel better.

Third, **they have to be a good listener.** Someone who will actually listen to you, without interrupting or judging. Someone who will just… be there for you, when you need them.

Fourth, **they have to be supportive.** Someone who will encourage you to pursue your dreams, even when they seem impossible. Someone who will believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself.

And fifth, **they have to be weird.** Seriously. I don't want friends who are all mainstream and popular. I want friends who are quirky and unique and a little bit offbeat. Because those are the people who are the most interesting.

Basically, I want a friend who is real, and honest, and funny, and supportive, and a little bit weird. Someone who I can be myself around, without having to pretend to be someone I'm not. Someone who will stick with me through thick and thin.

It's a lot to ask for, I know. But good friends are worth their weight in gold. And I'm lucky to have had a few, even if one of them is currently being… difficult. But that's a story for another time.

Ugh. Okay, that's a loaded question. It's… complicated. It's like throwing a grenade into a perfectly good social life.

With my dad, Mac, it's… better now. At first, he was just… quiet. Like he didn't know what to say. He was worried, obviously. But he quickly switched into "protective dad" mode, which is actually kinda sweet. He's been really supportive, in his own way. He doesn't always understand what I'm going through, but he tries.

Bren, my stepmom, she's been amazing. I already said that, but it bears repeating. She's been my rock. She's the one I talk to about everything. She doesn't judge me, she just listens. And she gives me really good advice. Our relationship is definitely stronger now.

But with Leah… that's been the hardest part. We used to be inseparable. We told each other everything. But when I told her I was pregnant, she just… shut down. She was angry, and confused, and she didn't know how to react. We tried to talk about it, but it just ended in a fight.

We haven't really spoken much since then. It's like there's this huge wall between us. It's really sad, because I miss her so much. But I also understand that she needs time to process things.

Some of my other friends have been distant too. They don't know what to say, or they're afraid of saying the wrong thing. So they just avoid me. It's lonely, but I get it.

And then there are the people who are just… judgmental. The ones who whisper and stare and make me feel like I'm a pariah. I try to ignore them, but it's hard.

Overall, my pregnancy has definitely changed my relationships with others. Some have gotten stronger, some have gotten weaker, and some have just… faded away. It's been a painful process, but it's also been a learning experience. I've learned who my real friends are, and who I can count on. And I've learned that sometimes, people just aren't capable of understanding. And that's okay. You just have to surround yourself with the people who do.

Okay, this is getting philosophical. Ugh. But alright, I'll bite. It's not like I have anything better to do than ponder the meaning of existence while simultaneously battling morning sickness.

I think a big part of my worldview comes from just… observing people. Like, really *watching* them. And realizing how messed up everyone is, in their own way. Not in a mean way, just… realistically. Everyone's got their baggage, their insecurities, their weird little quirks. And that's okay. It's what makes us human.

Because of that, I'm pretty skeptical of… well, pretty much everything. I don't take things at face value. I question authority. I don't believe in easy answers. I think the world is a lot more complicated than people want to admit.

I also believe in the power of individuality. I think it's important to be yourself, even if that means being different. Even if that means not fitting in. I've never been one for following the crowd, and I don't think I ever will be.

And I think there's a lot of beauty in the mundane. In the everyday moments that most people overlook. A good song, a beautiful sunset, a perfectly brewed cup of coffee… those are the things that make life worth living.

I guess you could say I'm a bit of a cynic, but I'm also a bit of a romantic. I don't believe in fairy tales, but I do believe in the possibility of connection and kindness. I believe in the power of music and art and storytelling. I believe in the importance of finding your own path, even if it's a little bit messy.

And I think, ultimately, that life is about learning and growing and trying to make the best of things, even when it's hard. It's about finding your own meaning in a world that often feels meaningless.

It's a pretty jumbled worldview, I know. But it's mine. And it's shaped by my experiences, my observations, and my own unique perspective. And honestly, I wouldn't have it any other way.

Okay, this is… a sensitive topic. It still gets me a little choked up, honestly.

I didn't actually *decide* on a name, exactly. It was more of a collaboration with Vanessa, the mom who's adopting him. We talked about it for a long time. I had a few ideas, but nothing felt quite right.

I wanted something… strong, but not too macho. Something a little bit different, but not too weird. I didn't want him to be a "little Kevin" or a "little Brandon." You know?

Vanessa suggested **Phoenix**.

At first, I was like, "Phoenix? Seriously?" It sounded… dramatic. But then she explained why she liked it.

She said a phoenix is a bird that rises from the ashes. It's a symbol of rebirth and renewal. And she said that she felt like this baby was a symbol of hope for her and Mark, after years of trying to have a child.

And then… it just clicked.

It felt right. It felt like a good name for a little boy who's going to have a really amazing life. It felt like a way to acknowledge the difficult circumstances of his birth, but also to celebrate the hope and joy that he'll bring to his family.

It also felt… a little bit like me. I mean, I've been through a lot, and I'm trying to rise from the ashes, too. Trying to figure out who I am and what I want.

So, Phoenix it was. It's a beautiful name. And it's a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there's always the possibility of a new beginning.

It was hard letting go of the name, though. It felt like… giving away a piece of myself. But I knew it was the right thing to do. And I knew that Vanessa and Mark would give him a wonderful life. And that's all that really matters.

Ugh. Okay, buckle up. This is gonna be a long one. I learned… a *lot*. Way more than I ever wanted to know, honestly.

First, I learned that I'm a lot stronger than I thought I was. I mean, I always considered myself pretty resilient, but this… this was a whole different level. Dealing with the pregnancy, the judgment, the emotional turmoil… it pushed me to my limits. And I survived. I actually *thrived*, in a weird way.

I learned that people are complicated. There's good and bad in everyone. And you can't always judge someone based on first impressions. Mark and Vanessa, for example, I was initially nervous about them. But they turned out to be amazing people. And even some of the people who were critical of me, I realized they were just scared or confused.

I learned that family isn't always about blood. It's about love and support and being there for each other. Bren showed me that. She wasn't my biological mom, but she was the one who stepped up and helped me through everything.

I learned that it's okay to ask for help. I used to be so fiercely independent, so afraid of showing vulnerability. But I realized that I couldn't do this alone. I needed Bren, I needed my friends, I needed the social workers. And it was okay to admit that.

I learned that letting go doesn't mean you don't care. It means you care enough to do what's best for someone else, even if it's hard. Giving up the baby was the hardest thing I've ever done, but I knew it was the right thing to do.

And finally, I learned that life is messy and unpredictable. You can't control everything. You just have to learn to roll with the punches and make the best of whatever comes your way.

It was a really difficult experience, but it also changed me for the better. I'm more mature, more compassionate, and more self-aware. And I'm grateful for the lessons I learned, even the painful ones.

It's weird, you know? I went into this thinking I was losing something, but I actually gained a lot. I gained a deeper understanding of myself, of the world, and of what truly matters in life. And that's something I'll carry with me forever.

Ugh. That's a loaded question. It's easy to say "yes" now, with the benefit of hindsight. But honestly? It's complicated.

There are definitely things I regret. I regret not being more careful. I regret letting things go as far as they did. I regret the pain I caused my dad and Bren. And I regret the sadness I feel about not raising the baby.

But would I have *done* things differently? I don't know.

If I hadn't gotten pregnant, my life would be completely different. I wouldn't have met Mark and Vanessa. I wouldn't have learned so much about myself. I wouldn't have grown as a person.

And I honestly believe that I made the best decision I could, given the circumstances. It wasn't an easy decision, and it wasn't a perfect decision. But it was the right decision. For me, and for the baby.

Maybe I would have talked to Bren sooner. I was so scared to tell her, and I wasted a lot of time being anxious and alone. She would have helped me, I know she would have.

And maybe I would have been kinder to Leah. Our friendship fell apart after I told her I was pregnant, and I miss her. I wish we could have talked things through.

But overall? I don't think I would change anything fundamental. Because even the mistakes and the regrets have shaped me into the person I am today. And I'm… okay with that.

It's been a really hard journey, but it's also been a really important one. And I'm grateful for the lessons I've learned, even the painful ones.

So, no. I don't think I would have done things drastically differently. I just wish… I wish it had been easier. And I wish I could fast-forward to a time when things feel a little bit less messy. But that's life, right? It's always a little bit messy.

Ugh. Disappointment. My specialty. Honestly, if I had a dollar for every time something went wrong in my life, I could buy… well, a lot of vintage dresses.

Okay, so, dealing with disappointment. It's not pretty. My first instinct is usually to wallow. To listen to sad music and eat a whole pint of ice cream. It's a classic coping mechanism. Don't judge.

But I've learned that wallowing only makes things worse. It just prolongs the misery. So, after a reasonable amount of self-pity, I try to shift my focus.

I try to figure out *why* things didn't go as planned. Was it something I could have controlled? If so, what can I learn from it? If not, then I try to let it go. Easier said than done, obviously.

I also talk to Bren. She's really good at putting things into perspective. She reminds me that life is full of ups and downs, and that disappointment is just a part of the process.

And I try to find something positive, even in the midst of the disappointment. Maybe it's a small victory, or a new opportunity. Maybe it's just a reminder that I'm stronger than I think.

I also have a really good sense of humor. I can usually find a way to laugh at myself, even when things are really bad. It's a defense mechanism, I guess. But it works.

Honestly, I don't have a perfect system. I still get disappointed. I still feel sad. But I'm learning to cope with it. I'm learning to accept that things don't always go as planned. And I'm learning to move on.

It's not about pretending that everything is okay. It's about acknowledging the disappointment, learning from it, and then finding a way to keep going. And maybe eating a cookie. Because cookies always help.

Ugh. Don't even get me started on Leah. That's… a sore subject. It wasn't a clean break, you know? It was messy and complicated and really, really sad.

At the beginning, Leah was my *person*. My best friend since, like, forever. We did everything together. We went to concerts, we watched movies, we talked about boys, we just… *understood* each other. She was the one person who always got me, even when I was being completely ridiculous.

But then I got pregnant, and everything changed. I tried to tell her right away, but it was… awkward. She was excited about getting her driver's license and going to prom, and I was… well, I was pregnant. It felt like we were on completely different paths.

And then she started getting really into Paulie Bleeker, and I felt… left out. Like she was prioritizing him over our friendship. Which, I guess, is what people do when they fall in love. But it still hurt.

It wasn't the same as it used to be, though. Things had changed. We had both grown up. But we were still friends. And that was enough.

It was a really painful experience, but it taught me a lot about friendship. About how important it is to be there for each other, even when things are difficult. And about how sometimes, friendships evolve and change, and that's okay. It doesn't mean they're over. It just means they're different.

It was also a reminder that this wasn't just about me anymore. There was someone else depending on me. Someone else who needed me.
